book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: [Introduction to the Investigation] In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. To proceed: This is the book 'Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal' by Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him. I have exerted my utmost effort in investigating, correcting, and extracting its references. I have prefaced it with an introduction containing a summary regarding the knowledge of narrators (Rijal) and the criticism and praise (Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil), then I mentioned what relates to the defects ('Ilal), then I wrote a biography for Imam Ahmad, a brief biography, and then I mentioned the description of the book and the manuscript upon which the work was based. I pray to Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, to accept it with a good acceptance. And I hope from the brothers, the people of knowledge, that they kindly draw attention to any error they observe so that it can be corrected later. And they shall have their reward with Allah. Al-Zahir, Makkah Al-Mukarramah, 20 Safar 1407. Doctor Wasiullah bin Muhammad Abbas.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. Praise be to Allah, we praise Him and seek His help and seek His forgiveness, and we believe in Him and rely upon Him. We seek refuge in Allah from the evils of our own selves and from our bad deeds. Whomever Allah guides, there is none to misguide him, and whomever He leaves astray, there is no guide for him. I bear witness that there is no deity worthy of worship except Allah alone, having no partner, and I bear witness that Muhammad is His slave and Messenger. To proceed: Verily, the best discourse is the Book of Allah, and the best guidance is the guidance of Muhammad, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. The worst of matters are newly invented ones, and every newly invented matter is a bid'ah (innovation), and every bid'ah is a misguidance. Allah created Adam, peace be upon him, and created from him his wife, and dispersed from both of them many men and women. He ordained for them laws which He charged them with through the tongues of His Messengers, from the time of Adam to the Seal of the Prophets, our Prophet Muhammad, upon him and upon the Prophets be blessings and peace. Allah sent His Messengers to convey to their people the messages of Allah, living among them, explaining to them the commands and prohibitions of Allah through their words and deeds, which their people and followers preserved from them and acted upon. Thus, the Messengers of Allah came in succession. And no Messenger was sent except in the language of his people, so He leaves astray whom He wills and guides whom He wills. A Prophet from the previous Prophets used to be sent to his people specifically, but our Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, was sent to mankind generally, so Allah made his message an abrogator of all messages, so

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: it is not open to anyone from the worlds except to follow him, and whoever desires other than his religion as a religion, it will never be accepted from him, and he, in the Hereafter, will be among the losers. (It is He who sent His Messenger with guidance and the religion of truth to manifest it over all religion) (1). (And We have not sent you except comprehensively to mankind as a bringer of good tidings and a warner) (2). Since the previous religions were not destined by Allah to remain forever, He did not undertake to preserve them, nor did He prepare for them those who would undertake their care and maintenance. Thus, they were not safe from distortion, even their holy books revealed to them. That is by the testimony of the Great Quran. (Among the Jews are those who distort words from their [proper] usages and say, "We hear and disobey") (3). And He denounced them in His saying, the Exalted: (So woe to those who write the "scripture" with their own hands, then say, "This is from Allah," in order to exchange it for a small price) (4). As for our Hanif (Monotheistic) White Sharia, Allah has promised and undertaken by His bounty and mercy to preserve it. The Exalted said: (Indeed, it is We who sent down the Dhikr [i.e., the Quran] and indeed, We will be its guardian) (5). And He prepared for it men and women in every era and land, and in every century and time, to preserve it from all aspects.
foot_note:
1. (1) Surah Al-Fath: 28, Surah As-Saff: 9.
2. Surah Saba: 28.
3. Surah An-Nisa: 46.
4. Surah Al-Baqarah: 79.
5. Surah Al-Hijr: 9. (*)

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: He prepared for it men who undertake the memorization of His Book by heart, reciting it, studying it, and preserving it between the two covers; preserving it through its study, correcting its meanings through Tafsir (exegesis), deriving rulings, and everything related to it. Then, reflecting upon it and acting according to what is in it. Since the verses of the Holy Quran are concise, Allah honored His Prophet Muhammad, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, by assigning him to explain the ambiguity within it, and to clarify what needs clarification and detailing. The Exalted said: (And We revealed to you the message that you may make clear to the people what was sent down to them) (1). And the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "Beware, I have been given the Book and something like it with it. Beware, soon a satiated man, on his couch, will say: 'Adhere to this Quran; whatever you find in it as lawful, deem it lawful, and whatever you find in it as unlawful, deem it unlawful.' Beware, the flesh of domestic donkeys is not lawful for you..." (2). And the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, commanded his nation to convey what they know of it to others, so he said: "Convey from me, even if it is one verse" (3). And he said: "Let the one present among you convey to the absent" (4). And he said: "I have left among you two things; you will never go astray after them: the Book of Allah and my Sunnah, and they will not separate until they return to me at the Hawd (Cistern)" (5).
foot_note:
1. (1) Surah An-Nahl: 44.
2. Sahih Al-Jami' As-Saghir 2: 375.
3. Sahih Al-Bukhari 6: 496.
4. Sahih Al-Bukhari 1: 199.
5. Sahih Al-Jami' As-Saghir 3: 39. (*)

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: Thus it became clear that the Dhikr (Remembrance) which Allah promised to preserve and safeguard includes the Holy Quran and the Sunnah of His Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, in all its types. With this blessed mission, Allah sent our Prophet, so he conveyed the message, fulfilled the trust, and strove for Allah with the striving due to Him. He defeated the enemies—polytheists, disbelieving hypocrites, and Jews—so the Peninsula believed in him. Among them were those who submitted (became Muslim) and pretended, while their hearts did not believe, just as he conquered the most malicious of nations, the bitterest enemies of Islam, the sons of apes and pigs, the Jews who did not leave an opportunity without seizing it to plot against Islam and the Muslims. Their leadership turned away from Medina with its malice, cunning, and hatred, and set up camp in Khaybar, exiled, expelled, condemned, and defeated. People lived under the shade of a mercy to the worlds until the religion was completed and the favor of Allah was perfected upon His servants in the form of His Book and the Sunnah of His Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, in its entirety. If a calamity befell them, they returned to it, or if an incident occurred to them, they sought refuge in it. They lived in mutual love and mercy like a single body, among Muslims like the teeth of a comb, with no disagreement or schism, and between exposed enemies, and between hypocrites whom, whenever they kindled the fire of fitnah (sedition), Allah inspired His Prophet so he exposed them and revealed their defects. And the victory belongs to the religion of Allah; the good is dominant and clear, and the evil has hidden and almost ceased to exist. The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, spoke the truth: "The best of people are my generation..." (1). The victory of Allah and the conquest came, and people entered the religion of Allah in multitudes. Allah gave His Prophet the choice between the world and what is with Him, so he chose what is with Allah (2) and passed on to the Highest Companion (Al-Rafiq Al-A'la), pleased and pleasing. The people had barely felt the interruption of news from the heaven and buried the best of creation in the pure soil of Taybah (Medina), when the clattering of the chains of trials rattled in their ears upon the stones of tribulations. The hypocrites and the malicious Jews found an outlet and a breath for their buried hatred, and the ambitious youth flocked with them, those with greed whose hearts the cheerfulness of faith had not mixed with.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: the depths of their hearts were of those whose eyes had not been anointed with the light of Prophethood. So they denied a great pillar from the pillars of Islam: Zakat. Thus, the first back-breaking event occurred, the tribulation of the apostates. Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq undertook the burden of the Rightly Guided Caliphate, and he broke the back of the sedition with determination and a sharp resolve. Al-Siddiqah Aisha, daughter of Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with them both, describes this situation: 'The Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, passed away, and the Arabs apostatized. Hypocrisy raised its head in Medina. Had what descended upon my father descended upon the unshakable mountains, it would have crushed them. By Allah, they did not differ regarding a single point but that my father flew with its fortune and burden in Islam.' Narrated by Imam Ahmad in 'Fada'il al-Sahabah'. He was the Siddiq of this Ummah and its best for this tribulation; he repelled the plot of Satan back to his throat, and the ship of Islam settled upon the Judi of safety, and praise be to Allah, Lord of the Worlds. He fulfilled his vow and met his Lord. Then the Rightly Guided Caliphate of Umar was established, the caliphate of the Muhaddath (inspired one), the one inspired for good, the one who knew people best, so he governed them with the wisdom of the insightful believer and the overwhelming strength of faith. His whip did its work, repelling the deviators from their deviation. He opened vast horizons for occupying people with Jihad and calling to Allah. He busied them with their Lord rather than themselves, and people entered the religion of Allah in crowds, between the obedient believer, the fearful hypocrite, and the hateful one lying in wait. They conspired among themselves and prepared for him a crow from the crows of disbelief, so he pecked him a peck or two and killed him while he was preparing himself for the Fajr prayer. Thus, they bereaved Islam of a genius. Then the caliphate of Dhu Al-Nurayn (Possessor of Two Lights) was established, the modest one of this Ummah and its forbearing one. He was the most connecting of them to his kin and the most fearing of them for his Lord, as stated by Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her. The days of his caliphate were the most flourishing days of the Rightly Guided Caliphate in terms of prosperity and security. During it, Jihad went east and west and sailed the seas.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: And it went to the open desert, the highlands, and the lowlands. Islam entered the areas of fur tents and mud houses. But the Fitna (sedition) did not sleep; rather, it dug for itself an entrance into the fortress of Islam where it laid eggs and hatched. Its chicks flew here and there, building their nests in the capitals of Islam and its cities, fed by the most evil of Allah's creation: The Saba'iyyah Jews. The corrupters fabricated lies against Dhu Al-Nurayn and wove falsehoods around him. His forbearance and noble nature encouraged them to do so, so they slaughtered him in his house while he was reciting the Book of Allah, just as lambs are slaughtered. Uthman bin Affan, may Allah be pleased with him and have mercy on him, was martyred in the house of the Messenger and his city. The sanctities of the Caliphate were violated in the most hideous manner. The Fitna stood up, exposed and active, and disagreement and discord raised their heads. The landmarks became obscured for some of the virtuous companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. The unity of the Muslims did not return since they bade it farewell on that tempting, tempted day. In this suffocating, dark atmosphere, the foster son of Prophethood and the hero of Jihad, the cousin of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, undertook the command of the Caliphate. And what a task this Rightly Guided Caliph undertook! The Muslims pledged allegiance to him while they were divided, a division whose gaps increased every day; if one gap was closed, others opened before him. People from among the Muslims raised the sword in his face, and a group of virtuous ones fought him—he did not deny their virtue. The Islamic society cracked open to reveal the harshest of sects, the Kharijites, who fought him with a fierce war. On the other side, brothers of his in Islam fought him, whose Islam he did not deny, but he said of them: 'They are our brothers who have transgressed against us.' Another sect emerged from the children of Saba and his chicks, the Shia, who claimed to love him and exaggerated regarding him until they deified him. They displayed love for the family of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and spread among the people that they were oppressed, oppressed by the Sahaba, headed by Abu Bakr, Umar, and Uthman. So they made it their habit to curse the Sahaba and declare them disbelievers. The enemies of Islam conspired, and Ali, may Allah be pleased with him, was martyred by a sinful hand after he had spent

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: his night and day suppressing tribulations, finding no tranquility until he met his Lord. The Mother of the Believers, Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, spoke the truth when news of the martyrdom of Ali, may Allah honor his face, reached her, quoting this poetry: 'She dropped her staff and the destination settled her * As the traveler is delighted by the return.' (1) The Caliphate then united, after the resignation of Al-Hassan bin Ali, upon Muawiyah, may Allah be pleased with them both. The division lightened in its intensity, and he governed it with forbearance, patience, wisdom, and endurance. The matter had some calmness and tranquility, though no day passes but that the one after it is worse than it. And the Fitna, even if it was disturbing the inside of the Islamic society, the outside remained formidable due to the blessing of the righteous among the general Muslims and their righteousness. For goodness was the controlling factor in their behavior, their attachment to Allah Almighty, and their undertaking of the call to Allah. How could they not be, when they are the companions of the Messenger of Allah, whom the Messenger, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, raised with his behavior and methodology? They did not forget their duties in commanding the good and forbidding the evil. Then the Tabi'in (Successors) to the companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, took over the matter. They were raised in the laps of the Sahaba and received the guidance and the way of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, from them, and they undertook spreading it among the people. So the spirit of Islam was awake and insightful, and the Islamic society was feared in the eyes of the vindictive enemies, externally and internally. The soldiers of Islam, in the shadow of these internal tribulations, continued to raid and open the hearts of the servants and their lands, spreading the call to Allah. They taught people the Book and Wisdom. The ship of Islam continued to cleave through the waves of internal tribulations alongside Jihad in the path of Allah. The expanse of the Islamic lands widened until it reached the heart of Africa and the gates of Europe and China. Sincere, obedient people entered the religion of Allah, as well as people whose desires aligned with the desire of the Saba'iyyah in every era, so they connected with their clique—the way of Allah regarding those who passed away before.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: When sects emerged and desires differed, lying against the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, became widespread among some factions, because everyone knew well that the saying of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, is the most precious thing to Muslims. So the fabrication of Hadiths began to strengthen desires and opinions. Just as distortion and unjust interpretation of some verses from the Book of Allah began. So the Muslims undertook the preservation of these two sources with all means and capabilities. True history bears witness that the Muslims recognized the value of these two sources—the Book of Allah and the Sunnah of His Messenger—and that they are the cause of every Muslim's happiness and the source of guidance for every believer. It is known from human nature that precious and valuable goods are preserved and protected with exaggerated care using every possible means. The more the value increases, the more the care in preserving it increases. So they undertook the preservation of the Book of Allah in the chests (hearts) and then in the Mushafs between the two covers. They also undertook the preservation of the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, by heart, then by recording it in collections, then by verifying and authenticating it. Muslim narrated in the introduction to his Sahih (15) from Ibn Sirin who said: 'They did not used to ask about the Isnad (chain of narration), but when the Fitna occurred, they said: Name your men to us. So they would look at Ahl Al-Sunnah and take their Hadith, and they would look at Ahl Al-Bid'ah (people of innovation) and not take their Hadith.' And by the success granted by Allah, they deduced sciences to serve it that humanity had not known in its long history, not even a tenth of a tenth of what the Muslims have. Look at those many sciences of Tajweed, Tafsir and its principles, Grammar, Morphology, Rhetoric, and then the Terminology of Sunnah (Mustalah). In every art, there are arts and branches, all to serve these two noble sources. Yes, it is from the miracle of this eternal religion that Allah created for it a people who were the cream of humanity and its extract, and they are the companions of Muhammad, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, who undertook the support of their Prophet, his veneration, his respect, and the sacrifice of their souls and wealth at the signal of his blessed glance. There is no equal to them in any nation among the nations.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: The Book of Allah narrated to us about the Jews when they said to their Prophet Moses: 'Go, you and your Lord, and fight; indeed, we are sitting right here.' While the authentic Seerah (biography) tells us that the companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, one of them said: 'O Messenger of Allah: By the One in Whose hand is my soul, if you commanded us to plunge into the sea, we would plunge into it, and if you commanded us to strike the livers of camels (travel) to Bark al-Ghimad, we would do so' (1) ... They undertook the preservation of this religion from their Prophet and transmitted it to those after them with complete justice and total trustworthiness. It is not hidden from one familiar with the history of Muslims the effort that the companions of the Prophet, peace be upon him, undertook to collect the Noble Quran in a universally agreed-upon Mushaf. Thus, the collection of the Noble Quran and its recording was completed in the era of the best of this Ummah. We believe that it exists in our hands, fresh and tender as Allah revealed it to His Messenger Muhammad, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, preserved in the chests of the young and old of this Ummah without distortion or misspelling affecting it. As for the Prophetic Sunnah, although much of it was recorded in the time of the Sahaba, its greater reliance was on memorization, and it was not recorded in a complete recording like the Noble Quran. So the mission of the Tabi'in and those after them began, and they undertook miraculous efforts to collect the Hadiths of their Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him. In this field, they set magnificent examples that indicate the miraculous nature of this Hanif (monotheistic) religion. 'They preferred traversing wastelands and deserts over luxury in homes and homelands, seeking Sunan in the regions, collecting them with anxiety and travels, and circulating in all districts. To the extent that one of them would travel for a single Hadith for distant parasangs, and for a single word for many days, lest a misguider introduce into the Sunan something to lead astray with it. And if

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: he did, they are the defenders of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, against that lie, and the ones undertaking the support of the religion' (1). The journey of the Muhaddithin (Hadith scholars) to seek Sunan and Athar (traditions) was a confirmation of His Almighty's saying: (For there should separate from every division of them a group [of religious scholars] to obtain understanding in the religion) (2). For regarding the companions of the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, one of them would travel to seek a single Hadith or merely for verification, covering a vast distance, enduring every hardship in this path. Abdullah bin Buraidah said that a man from the companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, traveled to Fadalah bin Ubaid while he was in Egypt. He came to him while he was extending a camel of his. He said: 'Welcome.' He said: 'Indeed, I did not come to you as a visitor, but I and you heard a Hadith from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and I hoped that you might have knowledge of it.' He said: 'What is it?' He said: 'Such and such...' And Jabir bin Abdullah, may Allah be pleased with him, narrates to us the story of his journey, saying: 'A Hadith reached me regarding the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, which I had not heard. So I bought a camel, saddled it, and traveled for a month until I reached the Levant (Sham). I came to Abdullah bin Unays. I said to the doorman: Tell him Jabir is at the door. He said: He went to him and said to him: Jabir bin Abdullah? He came to me and said to me. I said to him: Yes. So he returned and informed him. He stood up, dragging his garment, until he met me and embraced me and I embraced him. I said: A Hadith reached me from you that you heard from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, regarding Qisas (retaliation), which I did not hear. I feared that you might die or I might die before I hear it. He said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him...' and he mentioned it.

1. (1) From the book Al-Majruhin 1, 27. 
2. Surah At-Tawbah: 122. (*)

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: And regarding Wahb bin Abdullah Al-Ma'afiri, he said: A man from the companions of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, from the Ansar came to Maslamah bin Mukhallad, and found him sleeping. He said: 'Wake him up.' They said: 'Rather, we will leave him until he wakes up.' He said: 'I will not do so.' So they woke Maslamah for him. He welcomed him and said: 'Descend (be a guest).' He said: 'No, until you send for Uqbah bin Amir for a need I have with him.' So he sent for Uqbah, and he came. He said: 'Did you hear the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say: Whoever finds a Muslim upon a fault and covers him, it is as if he brought to life a buried female infant from her grave?' Uqbah said: 'I have heard the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, say that' (1). And the Tabi'in followed them with excellence, so they traveled and collected the Sunan from the regions and cities. Then those who followed them with excellence until the Sunnah was fully recorded in the collections (Diwans) that we see filling the libraries of the world. They did not suffice with collection only, but they used every means to purify it from impurities and turbidities. They established rules for it that are the most sophisticated the world has known and the best that human capacity has reached to verify news and authenticate it. Look at the books of Mustalah Al-Hadith (Hadith Terminology) and the types of Hadith sciences therein; you will see what no eye has seen nor ear has heard the likes of before Islam. There is no doubt that the Noble Quran was the first to guide towards verification and authentication in news, saying: (O you who have believed, if there comes to you a disobedient one with information, investigate, lest you harm a people out of ignorance) (2). And towards recording correct, useful, and considered biographies (Seerah) and life stories. For
foot_note:
1. (1) See Seerah Al-Bukhari by the scholar Abdul Salam Al-Mubarakpuri pp. 12 - 14. 
2. Surah Al-Hujurat: 6. (*)

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: the Noble Quran mentioned to us the biographies of many notables, and the points of lesson in them are clear, free from contradiction and impossibilities. Look beside it at the myths and false stories in the books of those before us. The Quran also teaches us that it is not enough to simply record biographies and adhere to truthfulness in them only, but honest criticism must also be directed for the sake of lesson and admonition. Look at examples of that in the story of Adam, Noah, and Yunus, peace be upon them. From this noble Quranic starting point, the People of Hadith (Ahl al-Hadith), may Allah have mercy on them, directed themselves. They exerted their utmost efforts and strove until they collected the biography of the Messenger, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and his Sunnah—in speech, action, and approval—with their chains of narration (Asanid). Were it not for that great effort from this blessed group, we would have been deprived of knowing the conditions of our Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, and it would have been impossible for us to comply with His Almighty's saying: (There has certainly been for you in the Messenger of Allah an excellent pattern) (1). Their efforts did not stop at these limits; they also recorded correct, truthful biographies of the Rightly Guided Caliphs, acting upon his saying, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, in the Hadith of Irbad bin Sariyah: '...So adhere to my Sunnah and the Sunnah of the Rightly Guided Mahdi Caliphs, bite onto it with your molars' (2). And they took steps to collect the biographies of others from the Sahaba. How could they neglect the biographies of the companions of their Prophet when Allah has purified them and praised them, and in their lives, there is news and lessons for us? The books authored specifically about them indicate the efforts expended in this aspect. And since a report—any report—is not trusted and is not acceptable unless
foot_note:
1. (1) Surah Al-Ahzab: 21. 
2. See Sahih Al-Jami' Al-Saghir 4: 132. (*)

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: the reporter is trustworthy, a hafiz (preserver), and just, how can a report about the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, be accepted from just anyone without us knowing his truthfulness from his lying and his correctness from his illusion and error? Therefore, they devised the word 'Isnad' with their special terminology and devised a special science for it known as the science of Criticism, Disparagement, and Praise (Jarh wa Ta'dil). They wrote biographies for the Tabi'in and those after them, and recorded their conditions so that the weak could be known from the hafiz, and the trustworthy from the liar; those whose reports are accepted and those whose Hadiths are rejected. If you see the books of biographies, histories, and generations (Tabaqat), then you see thousands of biographies with everything they reached regarding the narrator's birth, his upbringing until his death, how his entrance and exit were, how he was in his behavior, religion, creed, and dealings with others. Who were his sheikhs from whom he learned? Did he hear all his Hadiths or some of them? Who were the students who received from him? Who are the trustworthy students from him and those whose narrations from him are weak? What is the number of his narrations? How many of them are authentic and how many are weak? Did he remain in his memory and probity as he was in his youth and health, or did he become confused (mixed up) in his later years after he grew old and aged, or after he was afflicted with a disability or an incident in himself or his books? And did he narrate during his state of confusion or not? If he narrated, then who are those who took from him before the confusion, and who are those who took from him after the confusion? And (regarding) those who took before the confusion and after it as well, were their Hadiths distinguished or not? And other such attributes related to the narrator. This is what is known as the Science of the Knowledge of Men (Ilm Ma'rifat al-Rijal) or the Science of Jarh wa Ta'dil. Even the enemies of Islam were dazzled by these sciences, and some of them spoke in praise of it and them, admitting the virtue as witnessed by enemies. Dr. Sprenger said in the introduction to the book 'Al-Isabah': 'The Muslims have the right to take pride in the Science of Men (Rijal) as they wish. For no nation has existed'

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: in the past nor in the present that recorded the biographies and lives of scholars over twelve centuries as the Muslims did. It is possible for us to obtain the biographies of five hundred famous scholars from their books.' End quote (1). The People of Hadith did not limit themselves to collecting biographies; rather, they researched minutely into their narrations, even the narrations of the known trustworthy ones among them. They did not rely on the fact that they were trustworthy and exempt them from research and criticism. For a trustworthy person may have an illusion or make a mistake; it is the nature that Allah created people with. So they researched their narrations in which they had illusions or made mistakes. This is what is known as the Science of Hadith Defects (Ilal al-Hadith). Is it possible, O friend, for there to be methods for research, criticism, verification, and inspection of past news better than what the Muhaddithin have? No. 'Those are my fathers, so bring me the likes of them * If the gatherings gather us, O Jarir.' Besides that, they deduced rulings without unjust analogy or being restricted to the literal meaning. They wrote Jami's (comprehensive collections), Sunan, and thematic books on this. Just as they protected the sanctuary of the Creed (Aqidah) from all its sides. They did not hear a frightening noise but that they flew to it, light and heavy. They did not see a breach but that they garrisoned in it. So they preserved this religion from the deviation of the deviators, the distortion of the extremists, the plagiarism of the falsifiers, and the misguidance of the anthropomorphists, the negators, the describers of modality, and the interpreters. It saddens us after this that some of those hateful towards the Salaf or Salafiyyah stand up and accuse them of not understanding the texts and belittle them, calling them 'Transmitters' (Naqalah) who do not understand. Grave is the word that comes out of their mouths; they speak nothing but lies.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
A Brief Summary on Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil (Criticism and Praise)
Speaking about men (narrators) by way of criticism and praise is not backbiting; rather, it is one of the duties of the Sharia. Ibn Hibban narrated in the book *Al-Du'afa wa Al-Majruhin* (The Weak and The Criticized) from 'Abd al-Rahman bin 'Amr al-Sulami and Hujr al-Kala'i, who said: We came to Al-'Irbad bin Sariyah, and he was among those about whom the verse was revealed: {Nor [is there blame] upon those who, when they came to you that you might give them mounts...} [to the end of the verse]. I said: 'I do not find that which I can carry you on.' So we greeted him and said: 'We have come to you as visitors and seekers of knowledge.' Al-'Irbad said: 'The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, led us in the Fajr prayer one day, then he turned his face towards us and admonished us with an eloquent admonition that caused eyes to shed tears and hearts to tremble. A speaker said: "O Messenger of Allah, this looks like the admonition of a farewell; so what do you entrust to us?" He said: "I enjoin you to have Taqwa (fear/consciousness) of Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, and to listen and obey, even if [your leader is] an Abyssinian slave with mutilated limbs. For indeed, whoever among you lives long will see much difference (disagreement). So adhere to my Sunnah and the Sunnah of the Rightly Guided Caliphs; hold fast to it and bite onto it with your molars. And beware of newly invented matters, for every newly invented matter is a bid'ah (innovation), and every bid'ah is misguidance."' Then he [Ibn Hibban] said: "In his saying, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, 'For indeed, whoever among you lives long will see much difference. So adhere...' is evidence that he, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, commanded his nation to know the weak [narrators] from the trustworthy ones. This is because sticking to the Sunnah, given the lies and falsehoods that have mixed with it, is not possible except by knowing the weak from the trustworthy. The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, knew what would happen regarding this in his nation." He also said: "In his saying, peace be upon him, 'Let the one present among you convey to the absent,'

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: is evidence for the desirability of knowing the weak among the narrators, since it is not possible for the absent to be conveyed what was witnessed except after knowing the authenticity of what is being delivered to those after him (1). Ahmad bin Marwan Al-Maliki narrated to us: Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Hanbal told us, saying: Abu Turab Al-Nakhshabi came to my father, and my father started saying: 'So-and-so is weak, and so-and-so is trustworthy.' Abu Turab said: 'O Sheikh, do not backbite the scholars.' He said: My father turned to him and said: 'Woe to you! This is advice (nasihah); this is not backbiting.' And Muhammad bin Bundar said: I said to Ahmad bin Hanbal: 'It is difficult for me to say: So-and-so is weak, so-and-so is a liar.' Ahmad said: 'If you remain silent and I remain silent, then when will the ignorant person know the authentic from the defective?' (2). Abu Bakr bin Khallad said: I entered upon Yahya bin Sa'id during his illness, and he said to me: 'O Abu Bakr, have I left the people of Basra talking?' I said: 'They mention good things, except that they fear for you because of your speech regarding people.' He said: 'Memorize this from me: For my adversary in the Hereafter to be a man from the common people is more beloved to me than for my adversary in the Hereafter to be the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saying: "A hadith reached you about me which you suspected was not from me, yet you did not deny it?"' (3). Indeed, the Holy Quran itself urges verification, research, and scrutiny. The Exalted said: (O you who have believed, if there comes to you a disobedient one with information, investigate) (4). We also find in the Book of Allah, the Exalted, principles for criticism (Naqd), wounding (Jarh), and modification/praise (Ta'dil). The Exalted said, recounting the words of Solomon, peace be upon him:
foot_note:
1. (1) See Al-Du'afa wa Al-Majruhin 1: 9: 16.
2. Al-Kifayah 92.
3. Sharh 'Ilal Al-Tirmidhi by Ibn Rajab 173 and see Al-Kifayah p. 90.
4. Surah Al-Hujurat: 6. (*)

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: (We will see whether you were truthful or were of the liars) (1). And the Exalted said regarding criticism (Jarh): (And Allah testifies that the hypocrites are liars) (2). And He said regarding praise (Ta'dil): (For the poor emigrants who were expelled from their homes and their properties, seeking bounty from Allah and [His] approval and supporting Allah and His Messenger. Those are the truthful) (3). Then we see the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, regarding reports; he asked, criticized, and praised. And in him, we have a good example. Al-Bukhari narrated from Aisha, may Allah be pleased with her, when the people of the slander (Al-Ifk) said what they said about her. She said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, called for Ali bin Abi Talib and Usama bin Zaid, may Allah be pleased with them both, when the Revelation was delayed, asking them and consulting them about separating from his family. As for Usama, he advised with what he knew of the innocence of his family. As for Ali, he said: 'Allah has not restricted you, and women other than her are many; ask the maidservant, she will tell you the truth.' So he [the Prophet] said: 'Have you seen anything that makes you doubt?' She said: 'I have not seen a matter more than that she is a young girl who sleeps leaving the dough of her family' (4). He has many examples in the Sunnah. Then came the turn of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them; they examined, inspected, and went to great lengths in investigating the hadiths of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. From Qabisah bin Dhu'ayb, who said: The grandmother came to Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq

2. Surah Al-Munafiqun: 1.
3. Surah Al-Hashr: 8.
4. Sahih Al-Bukhari 8: 338. (*)

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: asking him for her inheritance. Abu Bakr said to her: 'There is nothing for you in the Book of Allah, and I do not know of anything for you in the Sunnah of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Go back until I ask the people.' So he asked the people. Al-Mughirah bin Shu'bah said: 'I was present with the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and he gave her the sixth.' Abu Bakr said: 'Is there anyone else with you?' So Muhammad bin Maslamah Al-Ansari stood up and said: 'The same as Al-Mughirah bin Shu'bah said.' So Abu Bakr executed it for her (1). Then comes the turn of the second Caliph, Umar bin Al-Khattab, and he is stricter than his predecessor. From Abu Sa'id Al-Khudri, who said: I was in one of the gatherings of the Ansar when Abu Musa came looking terrified. He said: 'I asked permission to enter upon Umar, but permission was not granted to me, so I returned.' He [Umar] said: 'What prevented you?' I said: 'I asked permission three times and it was not granted, so I returned, and the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: "If one of you asks permission three times and it is not granted, he should return."' He [Umar] said: 'By Allah, you must establish proof for this. Did any of you hear it from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace?' Ubayy bin Ka'b said: 'By Allah, none shall stand with you except the youngest of the people.' I was the youngest of the people, so I stood with him and informed Umar that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said that. And in some narrations: Umar said: 'I merely heard something and I wanted to verify it.' And in a narration, Umar bin Al-Khattab said to Abu Musa: 'Note that I did not accuse you, but I feared that people would attribute sayings to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace' (2). Ibn 'Abd al-Barr narrated with his chain from Abu Hurairah who said: 'Indeed, this knowledge is religion, so look to whom you take it from.' He also narrated from 'Uqbah bin Nafi' and Suhayb that they said: 'O my son, do not accept Hadith from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, except from a trustworthy person' (3).

2. Sahih Al-Bukhari 11: 27, Sahih Muslim 3: 1694, Al-Muwatta 2: 240.
3. Al-Tamhid 1: 45. (*)

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: Then comes the time of the Tabi'un (Successors), and this science evolves and expands further. This is Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib, may Allah have mercy on him, who used to scrutinize men and hadiths. Ibn Mandah narrated via the path of Yazid bin Abi Malik who said: I was with Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib and he narrated a hadith to me. I said: 'Who narrated this to you, O Abu Muhammad?' He said: 'O brother of the people of Sham (Syria), take it and do not ask, for we do not take except from the trustworthy ones' (1). 'Amir bin Sharahil Al-Sha'bi said regarding Qatadah: 'He is a wood gatherer at night (Hatib Layl)' (2). And he said regarding Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i: 'That one narrates from Masruq but did not hear anything from him' (3). Ibn Sirin said: 'Indeed, this knowledge is religion, so look to whom you take your religion from' (4). Qatadah used to accuse Ubadah Abu Yahya of lying (5). Many sayings regarding criticism (Naqd), wounding (Jarh), and praise (Ta'dil) are narrated from Ibn Shihab Al-Zuhri. Al-Zuhri said: 'The scholars are four: Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib in Medina, Al-Sha'bi in Kufa, Al-Hasan Al-Basri in Basra, and Makhul in Sham' (6). Al-Zuhri used to be strict with anyone who narrated a hadith without a chain of narration (Isnad). Al-Dhahabi mentioned his saying regarding Is-haq bin Abdullah:

2. Al-Tahdhib 4: 87.
3. Al-Mizan 1: 74.
4. Introduction to Sahih Muslim p. 14.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: 'May Allah fight you, O son of Abu Farwah! How bold you are against Allah! You do not provide chains for your hadiths; you narrate hadiths that have neither a halter nor reins' (1). Then comes the era of the followers of the Tabi'un (Atba' al-Tabi'in) who studied under the students of the Companions. The art advances with rapid steps, new laws are established, and Allah brings forth the likes of Shu'bah. They travel, inspect, and test the conditions of the men (narrators), and they begin classifying and authoring more broadly than before. Looking at the biography of Shu'bah reveals that he was extremely excessive in verifying what he narrated, and he would not narrate except from those known to be trustworthy, as it is said. He had different methods for verifying reports, among them: He was not satisfied with listening to a hadith just once. Ibn Abi Hatim narrated with his chain to Hammad bin Zaid who said: 'I do not care who opposes me if Shu'bah agrees with me, because Shu'bah was not satisfied to hear a hadith once; he would have its owner repeat it multiple times, while we, if we heard it once, would be sufficient with it' (2). Among his methods is what Ibn Abi Hatim narrated with his chain to Abu Dawud Al-Tayalisi who said: I heard Khalid bin Taliq asking Shu'bah, saying: 'O Abu Bistam, narrate to me the hadith of Simak bin Harb regarding the exchange of silver for gold, the hadith of Ibn Umar.' He said: 'May Allah reform you. This is a hadith that no one raises [to the Prophet] except Simak.' He said: 'So do you fear that I will narrate it from you?' He said: 'No, but Qatadah narrated it to me from Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib from Ibn Umar, and he did not raise it. And Ayyub informed me from Nafi' from Ibn Umar, and he did not raise it. And Dawud bin Abi

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: Hind narrated it to me from Sa'id bin Jubayr and did not raise it, but Simak raised it, so I distinguish it' (1). So Shu'bah showed through this comparison that Simak erred in raising this hadith; rather, it is from the saying of Ibn Umar, stopped (Mawquf) at him. Such methods of verification and investigation are frequently narrated from the followers of the Tabi'un. In this century, the good, the critics of the art emerged, such as Sufyan Al-Thawri [97 - 161], Malik bin Anas the Imam of the Abode of Migration [104 - 179], Abdullah bin Al-Mubarak Al-Marwazi Al-Khurasani [118 - 181], Abu Is-haq Al-Fazari [d. 186], Sufyan bin 'Uyaynah [107 - 197], Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Qattan [120 - 198], Waki' bin Al-Jarrah [128 - 198], and Abdur-Rahman bin Mahdi [135 - 198]. Then Allah brought another people who studied under these noble, blessed notables. They took their methods in research and exploration and added new methods to them. At the forefront of them were Ahmad bin Hanbal, Yahya bin Ma'in, and Ali bin Al-Madini. They have books and writings in this noble art which can be known by reviewing their biographies. Then came the likes of Imam Al-Bukhari Muhammad bin Isma'il, Muslim, Abu Dawud, Al-Tirmidhi, Ibn Majah, Al-Darimi, and others. They added important bricks to this structure, derived new rules, and used the method of Consideration (Al-I'tibar), Comparison, Confrontation, Probing (Al-Sabr), and Selection in a broader way to know the men and distinguish error from correctness. Ahmad said in the biography of Sufyan bin 'Uyaynah: 'He is the most established of people in 'Amr bin Dinar' (2). He also said: 'I and Ali bin Al-Madini were discussing the most established person who narrates from

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: Al-Zuhri. Ali said: Sufyan bin 'Uyaynah. And I said: Malik bin Anas. I said: Malik makes fewer errors from Al-Zuhri, while Ibn 'Uyaynah errs in about twenty hadiths from Al-Zuhri, in such and such hadith. I mentioned eighteen hadiths of them, and I said: Bring what Malik erred in. He brought two or three hadiths. So I returned and looked into what Ibn 'Uyaynah erred in, and behold, they were more than twenty hadiths.' He also said: 'Malik has about three hundred hadiths from Al-Zuhri, and likewise Ibn 'Uyaynah has about three hundred from him' (1). So Imam Ahmad concluded from this comparison and probing that Malik is more established in Al-Zuhri than Ibn 'Uyaynah. Al-Nasa'i mentioned a narration by Abdul-Malik bin Nafi' Al-Shaybani from Ibn Umar: 'I saw a man come to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, with a cup containing Nabidh while he was at the Corner [of the Kaaba], and he gave the cup to him...' Then Al-Nasa'i said: 'Abdul-Malik bin Nafi' is not famous, and his hadith is not used as proof, and what is famous from Ibn Umar is contrary to his story.' Then he mentioned many narrations contradicting this narration and said: "And these are the people of verification and justice, famous for the correctness of transmission, and Abdul-Malik does not stand in the place of one of them, even if a group of his likes supported him. And success is with Allah" (2). It seems to me that this is the only method to know the trustworthy from others among the early narrators. If there is no statement found regarding an early narrator with an authentic chain from a scholar contemporary to him,

2. See Sunan Al-Nasa'i 8: 323. (*)

text: they used this method to judge him and his hadiths. Even if his probity (justice) was not known, it appears they would suffice with concealing his condition and looking at his narrations. If he agreed with the known trustworthy narrators in his narrations, he was deemed trustworthy; and if he opposed them, he was deemed weak. Whoever looks at the speech of Ibn 'Adi in his discussion and Ibn Hibban in his *Du'afa* (Weak Narrators) will see that they used this method with very clear frequency. Ibn Hibban said in the biography of Abdullah bin Lahi'ah: 'I have probed his reports in the narration of the early ones and the later ones from him. I saw confusion present in the narration of the later ones from him, and much that has no basis in the narration of the early ones. So I returned to consideration (Al-I'tibar), and I saw him committing Tadlis (concealing the source) from weak people regarding people whom Ibn Lahi'ah saw as trustworthy, so he attached those fabricated matters to them' (1). This is a brief presentation on the history of Jarh and Ta'dil, and these are some witnesses and examples of their sayings and their methodology in this chapter, showing us the efforts of our Imams, may Allah have mercy on them, in preserving the Prophetic Sunnah.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
Al-'Illah (The Defect)
Al-'Illah linguistically: Sickness. Its possessor is *Mu'tall* (sick). *'Alla al-maridu ya'illu* (the sick person became sick), so he is *'Alil*. In *Al-Qamus*, it says: Al-'Illah with a Kasrah: Disease. *'Alla, Ya'illu, I'talla, and A'allahu Allah* (Allah made him sick), so he is *Mu'all* and *'Alil*. Do not say *Ma'lul*; the theologians say it, but I am not certain/satisfied with it (1) (2).
Al-'Illah technically: Al-'Illah in the terminology of the Muhaddithin (Hadith scholars) is an expression for hidden, obscure causes that impugn the authenticity of the Hadith (3).
The *Mu'allal* and *Ma'lul* Hadith: It is the Hadith in which a defect is discovered that impugns its authenticity, even though its exterior appears free from it (4).
According to this definition: The disconnected (*Munqati'*) Hadith, for example, is not called *Ma'lul*, nor is the Hadith whose narrator is unknown or weak called *Ma'lul*. Rather, it is called *Ma'lul* if its matter turns out to be something of that nature while its exterior appears free from it. Al-Hakim said: "This type is the knowledge of the defects (*'Ilal*) of Hadith, and it is an independent science, other than
foot_note:
1. (1) See Mu'jam Maqayis Al-Lughah 4: 13.
2. Qamus Al-Muhit 4: 21. See also Taj Al-'Arus 8: 32, and Lisan Al-Arab 11: 471.
3. See 'Ulum Al-Hadith by Ibn Al-Salah 81, Al-Taqyid wa Al-Idah 116, Fath Al-Mughith 1: 210, Tadrib Al-Rawi 1: 252, Al-Nukat by Ibn Hajar 2: 710.
4. 'Ulum Al-Hadith 84. (*)

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: the Authentic (*Sahih*), the Sick (*Saqim*), and Criticism and Praise (*Jarh wa Ta'dil*)... A Hadith is only deemed defective (*Yu'allal*) from perspectives where Criticism (*Jarh*) has no entry, for the hadith of a criticized narrator is fallen and flimsy. The defect (*'Illah*) of a Hadith frequently occurs in the hadiths of trustworthy narrators when they narrate a hadith that has a defect, so its knowledge is hidden from them, and the hadith becomes *Ma'lul*. The proof in this, for us, is memorization, understanding, and knowledge, nothing else" (1). So the principle in applying the term *'Illah* is the hidden cause that impugns the authenticity of the Hadith. However, they may expand the usage and apply *'Illah* to every impugning cause, whether apparent or hidden. Indeed, hardly any book of *'Ilal* is devoid of its author including absolute causes of weakness in narration. Some even applied *'Illah* to a non-impugning cause as well, such as a hadith that a precise trustworthy narrator connected (*Wasalahu*) while others sent it (*Arsalahu*) (disconnected it) (2). Ibn Al-Salah said: "The name *'Illah* may be applied to other than what we mentioned of the remaining causes impugning the Hadith, removing it from the state of authenticity to the state of weakness, preventing action upon it, which is the requirement of the word *'Illah* in its original sense. Therefore, we find in the books of *'Ilal* much criticism involving lying, negligence, poor memory, and similar types of criticism. Al-Tirmidhi called Abrogation (*Naskh*) a defect (*'Illah*) among the defects of Hadith. Furthermore, some of them applied the name *'Illah* to what is not impugning among the faces of difference, such as the sending (*Irsal*) by one who sent a Hadith that a precise trustworthy narrator connected (*Asnadahu*), to the point that he said: Among the sections of the Authentic (*Sahih*) is that which is Authentic Defective (*Sahih Ma'lul*), just as some of them said: Among the Authentic is the Authentic Odd (*Sahih Shadh*)" (3).
foot_note:
1. (1) Ma'rifat 'Ulum Al-Hadith 112, 113.
2. See Al-Ba'ith Al-Hathith 71, Tawdih Al-Afkar 3: 33, Tadrib Al-Rawi 1: 257.
3. 'Ulum Al-Hadith 84. (*)

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: As for the saying of the author of *Al-Qamus*: "Do not say *Ma'lul*," he means by it that the linguists do not affirm this word with this meaning in this form. Ibn Al-Salah from the Muhaddithin also agreed with him, as he said: "The people of Hadith call it *Al-Ma'lul*, and that is from them and from the jurists in their speech in the chapter of Analogy (*Qiyas*): the Cause (*'Illah*) and the Effect (*Ma'lul*); it is rejected by the people of language and Arabic" (1). Al-Nawawi also considered it a grammatical error in his *Taqrib* (2). But we say: The usage of the word *Ma'lul* by the people of Hadith with the meaning they intended is not contrary to the language, because Abu Is-haq Al-Zajjaj, the famous linguist, used it in prosody (*'Arud*) close to the meaning used by the people of Hadith (3). Ibn Al-Qutiyyah the linguist (4) said: "*'Alla al-insan* (the human became sick) is sickness, and the thing: a defect (*'illah*) befell it." Al-Jaza'iri mentioned this and then said: "So its usage with the meaning they intended is not objectionable. Rather, some said: Using this term is more appropriate due to its occurrence in the expressions of the people of the art along with its validity in the language. And whoever preserves [knowledge] is a proof against whoever does not preserve" (5). In addition to this, we find its occurrence in the speech of Al-Bukhari, Al-Tirmidhi, Al-Daraqutni, Al-Hakim, and others (6), and they are closer to the correct language before

The Origin of the Science of 'Ilal Al-Hadith:
It seems that the science of 'Ilal Al-Hadith in a simplified, early form was parallel to the science of Hadith collection and criticism from the time of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them. Since illusion (*Wahm*) and error are among the most important elements of the defects of Hadith, and it is possible for some Companions to fall into them, we can exemplify this with incidents proven about the Companions where they corrected each other's illusions. The book *Al-Ijabah fima Istadrakathu Aisha 'ala Al-Sahabah* (The Response Concerning What Aisha Corrected of the Companions) by Al-Zarkashi is the largest collection of this. Just as Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib or some Companions corrected the illusion of Abdullah bin Abbas, may Allah be pleased with them both, in his statement: "The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, married Maymunah while he was in a state of Ihram" (1). Then this science proceeded with narration and updating in every era; whenever narration expanded, its scope expanded and the need for it intensified. Allah destined for it in every era and land brilliant scholars who would sift the narrations and permeate them, extracting from them, letter by letter, the Authentic (*Sahih*), the Sick (*Saqim*), the Weak (*Da'if*), and the Defective (*Ma'lul*).
Importance of the Science of 'Ilal Al-Hadith:
Since it is known that defects of Hadith frequently occur in the hadiths of trustworthy narrators upon whom reliance is placed in narrations, so the general Muhaddithin and the commonality of them do not see a flaw in their hadiths. Therefore, it became the most obscure type of Hadith and the most precise in its path. No one undertakes it except he whom Allah has granted a deep understanding, comprehensive knowledge, awareness of the ranks of narrators, and piercing knowledge of the differences in narrations.

text:
For this reason, no one spoke in this science except individual Imams of this affair and their experts. Abu Abdullah bin Mandah, the Hafiz, said: "Allah has only singled out a small number of people for the knowledge of these reports out of the many who claim knowledge of Hadith. As for the condition of the people who claim abundance of writing Hadith, or are fiqh scholars in the knowledge of Al-Shafi'i and Abu Hanifa, or followers of the speech of Al-Harith Al-Muhasibi, Al-Junayd, Dhul-Nun, and the people of spiritual thoughts, it is not for them to speak regarding anything of the science of Hadith unless they took it from its people and the people of knowledge. Only then can they speak with knowledge" (1). Abdur-Rahman bin Mahdi said: "Knowledge of Hadith is inspiration (*Ilham*). If you said to the scholar who finds defects in Hadith, 'From where did you say this?' he would not have a proof." Al-Hakim mentioned this. He also mentioned with his chain from Abu Zur'ah, and a man said to him: "What is the proof for your finding defects in Hadith?" He said: "The proof is that you ask me about a hadith that has a defect, so I mention its defect. Then you go to Ibn Warah—meaning Muhammad bin Muslim bin Warah—and ask him about it, and do not inform him that you have asked me about it, so he mentions its defect. Then he goes to Abu Hatim and he finds the defect. Then distinguish the speech of each of us on that hadith. If you find a disagreement among us regarding its defect, then know that each of us spoke according to his intent. But if you find the word to be in agreement, then know the reality of this science." He said: "So the man did so. And their word agreed upon it. So he said: 'I bear witness that this science is inspiration'" (2).
A Note Here: We should understand the speech of Abdur-Rahman bin Mahdi in its proper context, which is that his intent by saying "Knowledge of Hadith is inspiration" is not that he may find a defect without having a proof for it. Rather,

his intent (if this saying is authentic from him) is that he attains a strong, firmly established aptitude such that merely by looking at the chain of the hadith and its text, its authenticity or weakness becomes apparent to him, so he judges at the first instance with his insight that it is authentic or defective. Then, if proof is requested from him, he must mention its details. It is not possible to find a defective hadith without a reason for it, but the one finding the defect may be brief in the ruling, mentioning his ruling without showing the reason. Some who have a desire to deny Hadith have used this saying of Ibn Mahdi as evidence, expanding its interpretation and deduction, saying: The Muhaddith may view a hadith agreed upon for its authenticity as weak and vice versa, without being able to establish proof for that, and he is excused in this judgment of his, like the money changer (*Sayrafi*) critic who judges dirhams as counterfeit or sound but is unable to explain the cause. We say: The matter is not as stated; reality contradicts his saying. Here are the books of *'Ilal* before us; if brevity and abbreviation are found in some, then in others you find detail, explanation of the cause, and the reasoning. His likeness is only that of a skilled doctor; if a person whose exterior appears healthy is presented to him, and the illness does not appear in him to the common people, he looks at him at first glance and expresses his opinion generally that he has such-and-such illness. Then if the examination, interpretation, analysis, and X-ray are performed on him, the truth of his saying appears clearly. As Nu'aym bin Hammad said: I said to Ibn Mahdi: "How do you know the authentic Hadith and the sick one?" He said: "Just as the doctor knows the insane" (1).
Divisions of the Defect:
The defect occurs in the Isnad (chain) alone, in the Matn (text) alone, and in both of them. Based on this, it is divided

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
into six divisions:
1 - A defect in the Isnad that does not impugn [validity] at all.
2 - A defect in the Matn without the Isnad that does not impugn at all.
3 - A defect in the Matn that necessitates impugning the Isnad.
4 - A defect in the Isnad that impugns it but not the Matn.
5 - A defect in the Matn that impugns it and the Isnad together.
6 - A defect in the Matn that impugns it without the Isnad (1).
Some Genera of the Defective:
Al-Hakim in *Ma'rifat 'Ulum Al-Hadith* divided the genera of the Defective (*Ma'lul*) into ten divisions, and Al-Suyuti edited them in *Tadrib Al-Rawi* and mentioned examples for them. We will suffice with mentioning the genera only.
1 - That the chain appears outwardly authentic, but it contains someone who is not known to have heard from the one he narrated from.
2 - That the Hadith is Mursal (hurried/disconnected) from one aspect narrated by trustworthy Hafizs (preservers), and is connected (*Musnad*) from an aspect whose exterior is authenticity.
3 - That the Hadith is preserved (*Mahfuz*) from a Companion, but is narrated from someone else due to the difference in the lands of its narrators, like the narration of the Madinans from the Kufans.
4 - That it is preserved (*Mahfuz*) from a Companion, so it is narrated from a Tabi'i, where illusion occurs by declaring what implies its authenticity, while it is not even known from his direction.
foot_note: 1. (1) See Al-Nukat by Ibn Hajar 2: 747, and Tawdih Al-Afkar by Al-San'ani 2: 31-33. See the examples there for each division. (*)

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
5 - That it is narrated with 'An'anah (saying "from so-and-so") and a man has dropped from it, indicated by another preserved path.
6 - That there is a difference regarding a man in the Isnad and other than it, and the preserved version from him is what opposes the [apparent] Isnad.
7 - The difference regarding a man: naming his Sheikh or leaving him unknown.
8 - That the narrator narrates from a person he met and heard from, but he did not hear specific hadiths from him; so if he narrates it from him without an intermediary, its defect is that he did not hear them from him.
9 - That there is a known path [of narration], so one of its men narrates a hadith through other than that path, so the one who narrates it from that path falls into illusion based on the "beaten path" (Al-Jaddah).
10 - That the Hadith is narrated as Marfu' (raised to Prophet) from one aspect and Mawquf (stopped at Companion) from another aspect. Al-Hakim said: "We have mentioned the defects of Hadith in ten genera, and there remain genera we have not mentioned; I only made them as examples for many defective hadiths to which the one deeply learned in this science will be guided, for the knowledge of defects of Hadith is among the most majestic of these sciences" (1).
Some Authors on Defects of Hadith and Their Works:
A number of the Tabi'un, their followers, and those after them are mentioned among those who authored in the science of defects (*'Ilal*) of Hadith. For some, their book has reached us, and for some, their authorship has not been found, but their sayings are transmitted within the books of those after them; if collected, their authorships would be attained. Imam Al-Tirmidhi mentioned in his book *Al-'Ilal Al-Saghir* a group of those who preceded him in authoring on this subject; we mention them among the authors.

I was brought while carried from Marw (Merv), and my father Muhammad bin Hanbal died when he was thirty years old, so my mother took charge of me. Similar to this is the statement of Yaqub Al-Dawraqi: I heard Ahmad say: I was born in the month of Rabi' al-Awwal in the year one hundred and sixty-four. Abdullah bin Ahmad and Ahmad bin Abi Khaythamah said: He was born in Rabi' al-Akhir. His Father: Muhammad bin Hanbal was one of the army commanders in Marw and died about three years after his arrival in Baghdad after Ahmad's birth. His Grandfather: His grandfather Hanbal bin Hilal was one of the sons of the Da'wah (Abbasid cause) and was a governor over Marw (Sarakhs) on behalf of the Abbasid Caliph Al-Mahdi bin Mansur, so Abu Ahmad used to reside there. His Mother: His mother was Safiyyah bint Maymunah bint Abd Al-Malik Al-Shaybani from Bani Amir. His father had stayed with them and married her. Her grandfather from her mother's side was Abd Al-Malik bin Sawadah bin Hind Al-Shaybani, one of the notables of Bani Shayban. His Upbringing: When his father died while Ahmad was small, his mother took charge of him and raised him with a good upbringing, pouring love and extreme affection upon him.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: Salih bin Ahmad said: My father said: My ears were pierced. My mother, may Allah have mercy on her, used to put two pearls in them. When I grew up, I removed them and gave them to her, and she sold them for about thirty dirhams. She used to send him to the Kuttab (Quran school). The signs of nobility, virtue, and righteousness were apparent in him from his childhood. Ibn Al-Jawzi narrated with his chain of narration from Abu Afif who said: Ahmad was in the Kuttab with us, and he was a young boy whose virtue we recognized. The Caliph was in Al-Raqqah, and people were writing to their homes, so they would send their women to the teacher saying: Send Ahmad bin Hanbal to us to write the answers to their letters for them. Perhaps they would dictate something objectionable to him, and he would not write it for them. Abu Siraj bin Khuzaymah said: When he entered upon them, he would not raise his head to look at them. My father said, mentioning him, and he began to marvel at his manners and his good way. He said: I spend on my children and bring them tutors so that they may be educated, but I do not see them succeeding, while this Ahmad bin Hanbal is an orphan boy; look at how he turned out. And he began to marvel. His Seeking of Knowledge and His Journey for It: Traveling to seek Hadith has a great significance. The early ones did not endure the hardships of alienation and travel except to collect knowledge from the scholars and Sheikhs who were scattered in the Islamic cities and capitals. The Imams of Hadith set magnificent examples in this regard that have no parallel in any other group or nation. This is a matter that needs no evidence or examples. Imam Ahmad began seeking Hadith from the Sheikhs of Baghdad. He says: The first one I wrote Hadith from was Abu Yusuf.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: He said: I sought Hadith when I was sixteen years old. Hushaym died when I was twenty years old, and my first hearing from Hushaym was in the year one hundred and ninety-nine (sic - likely 179). Then he traveled to Kufa, Basra, Mecca, Medina, Yemen, the Levant (Sham), and Al-Jazira, and he wrote from the scholars of every land. He narrated in the Musnad from eighty-two and some odd Sheikhs. He says: The first outing I made was to Basra in the year 186, which was the first; the second was in the year 190; and I entered for the third time in the year 194, and Ghundar had died; and I entered in the year 200. Salih said to his father: In which year did you go out to Sufyan bin Uyaynah? He said: In the year 187. We arrived at it, meaning Mecca, and Fudayl bin Iyad had died. It was the first year I performed Hajj. In the year ninety-one, Al-Walid bin Muslim performed Hajj. And in the year ninety-six. I stayed for the year ninety-seven and left in the year ninety-eight. I stayed in the year ninety-nine with Abd Al-Razzaq, and the news of the death of Sufyan, Yahya bin Sa'id, and Abd Al-Rahman bin Mahdi came to us in the year ninety-eight, meaning one hundred and ninety-eight. Abdullah bin Ahmad said: My father went out to Tus walking and went out to Yemen walking. My father said: We did not write anything from Abd Al-Razzaq from his memory except the first session; that was because we entered at night and found him sitting in a place, so he dictated seventy Hadiths to us. Then he turned to the people and said: Were it not for this one, I would not have narrated to you, meaning my father. Perhaps lack of means prevented him, and tight living conditions hindered him from journeys despite his intense desire for them. He said, may Allah have mercy on him: If I had fifty dirhams, I would have gone out to Jarir

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: bin Abd Al-Hamid to Al-Rayy; some of our companions went out, but I could not go out because I did not have it. He said: If I had expenses, I would have traveled to Yahya bin Yahya, meaning Al-Andalusi, in Andalusia. The Imam also went out to Abadan in the year eighty-six and went out to Wasit and stayed with Yazid bin Harun. Through these many journeys, he obtained a large treasure and a vast collection of Hadiths and traditions (Athar). Abdullah bin Ahmad said: Abu Zur'ah said to me: Your father memorized a thousand thousand (one million) Hadiths. It was said to him: How do you know? He said: I reviewed with him and covered the chapters. Al-Dhahabi mentioned it in Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala, then said: This is a true story regarding the breadth of Abu Abdullah's knowledge. They used to count in that the repeated ones, the traditions (Athar), the Fatwas of the Tabi'in, and what was interpreted; otherwise, the strong elevated (Marfu') texts do not reach a tenth of a tenth of that. Al-Dhahabi also mentioned from Abu Zur'ah that he said: I estimated Ahmad's books on the day he died, and they reached twelve loads and sacks. There was not on the back of a book among them 'Hadith of so-and-so' nor inside it 'So-and-so told us' except that he had memorized all of that by heart. The Imam encountered much suffering in his journey. The roads were not paved nor were the vehicles prepared. And even if they were, the emptiness of hand from dirhams prevented riding on mounts and vehicles. Furthermore, he was naturally disposed to self-esteem, so he would not accept a gift or a grant from anyone,

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: rising above prizes and allowances, and accepting for himself lawful earnings through the sweat of his brow. So he used to hire himself out with the camel drivers. Abu Nu'aym narrated in Al-Hilyah from Ishaq bin Rahwayh who said: When Ahmad bin Hanbal went out to Abd Al-Razzaq, his funds ran out, so he hired himself out to the camel drivers until he reached Sana'a. His companions had offered him financial help, but he did not accept anything from anyone. And with his chain of narration from Abd bin Humayd who said: I heard Abd Al-Razzaq say: Ahmad bin Hanbal came to us here and stayed for nearly two years. I said to him: O Abu Abdullah, take this thing and benefit from it, for our land is not a land of trade or earning. Abd Al-Razzaq showed us his palm and extended it with dinars in it. Ahmad said: I am well. And he did not accept from me. It was narrated from Ahmad bin Sulayman Al-Wasiti that he said: It reached me that Ahmad bin Hanbal pawned his bucket (or shoes) at a baker's for food he took from him when he left Yemen, and he hired himself out to some people, camel drivers, when he left Yemen. Abd Al-Razzaq offered him a good amount of dirhams, but he did not accept them from him. It was also narrated from Ali bin Al-Jahm bin Badr who said: We had a neighbor who brought out a book to us and said: Do you recognize this handwriting? We said: Yes, this is the handwriting of Ahmad bin Hanbal. So we said to him: How did he write that? He said: We were in Mecca staying with Sufyan bin Uyaynah. We sought Ahmad bin Hanbal for days but did not see him. Then we came to him to ask about him. The people of the house he was in said: He is in that room. We came to him, and the door was closed on him, and he was wearing old worn-out clothes. We said to him: O Abu Abdullah, what is your news? We haven't seen you for days. He said: My clothes were stolen. I said to him: I have dinars,

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: so if you wish take it as a loan, and if you wish as a gift. He refused to do so. I said: Will you write for me in exchange for taking it? He said: Yes. So I brought out a dinar, but he refused to take it and said: Buy me a garment and cut it into two halves. He signaled that he would use one half as a lower garment (Izar) and wear the other half as an upper garment (Rida'). He said: And bring me the remainder. So I did, and I came with paper and a writing notebook, so he wrote for me; so this is his handwriting. Ibn Al-Jawzi mentioned from Salih that he heard his father say: I went out to Kufa and I used to sleep with a mud brick under my head. I got a fever, so I returned to my mother, and I had not asked her permission. With this proud soul, and with the toil of life and the hardship of living, relying on Allah, he went out in His path traversing the wilderness and wasteland, spreading the bare earth beneath him and wearing the sky as a blanket, using mud bricks and stones as pillows, meeting Sheikhs and receiving Hadith from them, until he became an Imam who is followed, a proof pointed at with fingertips, and to whom journeys are made for taking and hearing. His Taking the Position for Narrating and Fatwa: It was the custom of most Muhaddithin (Hadith scholars), may Allah have mercy on them, that one of them would not sit (to teach) except after the attainment of thought, maturity of opinion, and completion of mental strength. Ibn Khallad Al-Ramahurmuzi said in Al-Muhaddith Al-Fasil, and from him Al-Khatib in Al-Jami' li Akhlaq Al-Rawi wa Adab Al-Sami': 'What is correct in my view by way of tradition and consideration regarding the limit which, when the transmitter reaches it, it is proper for him to narrate, is that he completes fifty, because it is the end of middle age, and in it is the gathering of tradition... And it is not disapproved that he narrates upon completing forty, because it is the limit of maturity and the peak of perfection. The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, was made a Prophet when he was forty

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: years old. And at forty, a person's determination and strength reach their limit, his intellect becomes abundant, and his opinion becomes excellent.' End quote. It seems that Imam Ahmad did not take the position for narrating and Fatwa until after forty. Before that, he was devoted to seeking, taking, and collecting, busy with many journeys to meet Sheikhs. Ibn Al-Jawzi mentioned from Al-Hajjaj bin Al-Sha'ir that he came to Ahmad bin Hanbal and asked him to narrate to him in the year 203 (meaning his age was 39 years then), but he refused to narrate to him. So he went out to Abd Al-Razzaq, then returned in the year four, meaning two hundred and four. Ahmad had narrated, and people had settled around him, and on this day he was forty years old. The Praise of the Imams for Him: When he sat for narrating, the livers of camels were struck (journeys were made) to him, and saddles were tightened towards him from every direction to drink from his abundant spring. His reputation spread in the vast Islamic regions, and his knowledge and virtue became apparent to people among his brothers and companions, until his Sheikhs acknowledged his virtue and praised him with praise that this ascetic, striving, worshipping, jurist Imam deserved. Al-Shafi'i, may Allah have mercy on him, said: I saw in Baghdad three wonders: I saw a Nabataean who leans towards me (engages with me) until it is as if he is an Arab (or: so eloquent he seems Arab), and it is as if he is a Nabataean; and I saw a Bedouin making grammatical errors until it is as if he is a Nabataean; and I saw a young man whose hair has been streaked with grey, if he says: 'Whatever told us,' all the people say: 'He spoke the truth.' Al-Muzani said: So I asked him, and he said: The first is Al-Za'farani, the second is Abu Thawr Al-Kalbi—and he used to make errors—and as for the young man, he is Ahmad bin Hanbal.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: Al-Shafi'i also said: I have not seen two men wiser than Ahmad bin Hanbal and Sulayman bin Dawud. Ibn Abi Uways said, while some People of Hadith were with him: 'The People of Hadith are gone.' Ibn Abi Uways said: 'Allah has kept Ahmad bin Hanbal, so the People of Hadith are not gone.' Ali bin Al-Madini said: 'Ahmad bin Hanbal is our Sayyid (Master).' He used to revere and honor him greatly, and he is who he is in the science of Hadith, to the extent that Al-Bukhari said about him: 'I did not belittle myself except before Ali bin Al-Madini.' Ibn Al-Madini also used to say: 'My master Ahmad bin Hanbal commanded me not to narrate except from a book.' He also said: 'Ahmad bin Hanbal is, in my view, superior to Sa'id bin Jubayr in his time, because Sa'id had equals, while this one has no equal.' He used to say: 'There is no one among our companions who has memorized more than Abu Abdullah Ahmad bin Hanbal, and it has reached me that he does not narrate except from a book, and we have a model in him.' He also said: 'Allah Almighty honored this religion with two men who have no third: Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq on the Day of Apostasy, and Ahmad bin Hanbal on the Day of the Mihnah (Inquisition). Abu Bakr had companions and helpers, while Ahmad had no helpers and no companions.' Abu Abd Al-Salam bin Salam said: 'Knowledge ended up with four: With Ahmad bin Hanbal, and he is the most knowledgeable of them in Fiqh; with Ibn Abi Shaybah, and he is the best memorizer of them for it; with Ali bin Al-Madini, and he is the most knowledgeable of them regarding it; and with Yahya bin Ma'in, and he is the best writer of them for it.' Yahya bin Ma'in said: 'The trustworthy people, or the People of Hadith, are four:

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: Waki', Ya'la bin Ubayd, Al-Qa'nabi, and Ahmad bin Hanbal.' Al-Nasa'i said: 'Ahmad bin Hanbal was the one about whom the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: There will be in my Ummah what was in the Children of Israel, to the extent that the saw will be placed on the parting of his head. That does not turn him away from his religion. Were it not for Ahmad bin Hanbal undertaking this matter, it would have been a disgrace upon us until the Day of Resurrection.' He also said: 'There was not in the era of Ahmad bin Hanbal the likes of these four: Ali bin Al-Madini, Yahya bin Ma'in, Ahmad bin Hanbal, and Ishaq bin Rahwayh. The most knowledgeable of these four in Hadith and its defects was Ali bin Al-Madini. The most knowledgeable of them in Men (narrators) and the one with the most Hadith was Yahya bin Ma'in. The best memorizer of them for Hadith and Fiqh was Ishaq bin Rahwayh.
