However, Ahmad bin Hanbal was, in my view, more knowledgeable about the defects of Hadith than Ishaq, and Ahmad combined knowledge of Hadith, Fiqh, piety, asceticism, and patience.' Abu Zur'ah was asked about Ali bin Al-Madini and Yahya bin Ma'in: Which of them was a better memorizer? He said: 'Ali was more continuous and precise, and Yahya had more understanding of the authentic Hadith and the sickly one. The most comprehensive of them was Abu Abdullah Ahmad bin Hanbal; he was a man of memorization, a man of Fiqh, and a man of knowledge.' He said: 'I do not know anyone among our companions more knowledgeable in Fiqh than Ahmad.' It was said to him: 'Is the choice of Ahmad and Ishaq more beloved to you or the saying of Al-Shafi'i?' He said: 'Rather, the choice of Ahmad and Ishaq is more beloved to me.' He said: 'My eyes have not seen the likes of Ahmad bin Hanbal in knowledge, asceticism, Fiqh, recognition, and every good.' See more of the praise of the Imams who were Ahmad's peers and those after him from his followers in what Ibn Al-Jawzi mentioned in his Manaqib (Virtues) in the fourteenth chapter; it indicates to you the greatness of this Imam and people's love for him.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: Ibn Rajab said in Sharh Ilal Al-Tirmidhi: Among those who authored separate works on his virtues are Ibn Abi Hatim, Ibn Shahin, Al-Bayhaqi, Abu Isma'il Al-Ansari, Yahya bin Mandah, and Ibn Al-Jawzi. I have also authored a separate work on his virtues. * The Distinction of Imam Ahmad Among His Peers: The one who looks into the personality of the Imam will see a virtuous distinction and a distinctive virtue among his peers and contemporaries. It is that he combined reception, narrating, narration (Riwayah), understanding (Dirayah), speech on the defects of Hadith and knowledge of Men, and speech on Fiqh and issues (Masa'il). Allah has immortalized all these traces from him, so he rightfully became an Imam who is followed, whereas we find among his peers those who combined different sciences, but Allah did not decree that these different sciences be transmitted from them. So we find him having dedicated himself to a side without being free for the other sides. Look at the biography of Yahya bin Ma'in, the companion of Imam Ahmad's life, and you will find the confirmation of that. Ahmad bin Uqbah says: I asked Yahya bin Ma'in: How much Hadith have you written, O Abu Zakariya? He said: I wrote with this hand of mine six hundred thousand Hadiths. Ahmad bin Uqbah said: And I think that the Muhaddithin wrote for him with their hands six hundred thousand and six hundred thousand (1). Muhammad bin Nasr Al-Tabari said: I heard Yahya bin Ma'in say: I have written with my hand a thousand thousand (one million) Hadiths (2).

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: He used to love writing Hadith abundantly and would say: 'I desire to come across a Sheikh who has a house full of books, so I can write from him alone' (1). Imam Ahmad said about him: 'Every Hadith that Yahya bin Ma'in does not know is not a Hadith.' And in a narration: 'Is not established.' Ali bin Al-Madini said: 'We do not know anyone since Adam (!) who wrote of Hadith what Yahya bin Ma'in wrote' (2). Despite this large treasure he had in Hadith, he did little in terms of narration and speaking (teaching), and he did not hold the circles known among his peers of Muhaddithin for dictation and narration. It appears that he dedicated himself to a special type of Hadith science, which is the criticism of narrations and Jarh wa Ta'dil (Disparagement and Praise). Thus, we find a large collection from him in this aspect, just as we find many quotations from him in the books of Men (Rijal). What supports this is that Abu Dawud, who is one of the narrators who recorded the material of criticism from him and accompanied him, did not extract (include) in the book Al-Sunan from him except twenty-five Hadiths only, despite the breadth of his book and his inclusion of a large amount of Hadiths of rulings. Whereas his book is full of narration from Ahmad, Musaddad, and others who are like him or below him in collecting narrations (3). Likewise, Imam Al-Ijli, Abu Al-Hasan Ahmad bin Abdullah bin Salih (182 - 261), was one of great reception and great memory. He took from most of the Imams of his era
foot_note:
1. (1) See Introduction to Tarikh Yahya bin Ma'in p. 55. 
2. Tarikh Baghdad 14: 80, 82. 
3. See Introduction to Tarikh Yahya bin Ma'in 62. (*)

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: in all the known scientific centers in that era such as Kufa, Basra, Baghdad, the Levant, Hijaz, and Egypt, as appears from his many journeys and his many Sheikhs. To the extent that in one trip to Basra, he wrote seventy thousand Hadiths apart from the Hadith of Hammad bin Salamah and Al-Qa'nabi. Even Al-Duri exaggerated regarding him with a rare exaggeration and said: He is counted among the likes of Ahmad bin Hanbal and Yahya bin Ma'in. Yet, with that, we hardly find a narration for him in the known books of Hadith, to the extent that Al-Dhahabi said: 'I do not think he narrated anything other than stories' (1). Description of Imam Ahmad and His Appearance: Al-Khatib narrated with his chain of narration from Muhammad bin Al-Abbas bin Al-Walid Al-Nahwi who said: I saw Ahmad bin Hanbal as a man of handsome face, of medium build among men, dyeing with henna a dye that was not intense red, with black hairs in his beard. I saw his clothes were coarse but white. And I saw him turbaned with his Izar (lower garment) upon him. Ibn Al-Jawzi and others mentioned from Ibn Ja'far bin Dharih Al-Ukbari: I sought Ahmad bin Hanbal to ask him about an issue. I greeted him, and he was an old man, dyed, tall, dark-skinned, intensely dark. Ibn Abi Hatim mentioned from Abd Al-Malik Al-Maymuni saying: I do not know that I saw anyone with cleaner clothes, nor more attentive to himself regarding his mustache, the hair of his head, and the hair of his body, nor with purer clothes and intense whiteness than Ahmad bin Hanbal. Abu Bakr Al-Marwazi said: I saw Abu Abdullah, when he was in the house, his general sitting was cross-legged, humble. If he was outside, there did not appear from him
foot_note: 1. (1) Tadhkirat Al-Huffaz 2: 561, and see Introduction to Thiqat Al-Ijli by Professor Abd Al-Alim p. 54. (*)

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: intense humility as it was when inside. I used to enter upon him, and the section (Juz') was in his hand being read. When I sat, he closed it and placed it before him. People used to attend his gathering to learn good manners from him. Al-Hasan bin Isma'il said: I heard my father say: Around five thousand or more would gather in Ahmad's assembly; less than five hundred would write, and the rest would learn good manners and good comportment from him. His Clothing: Al-Maymuni said: Ahmad bin Hanbal's clothes, between the two garments, his wrap (Milhafah) was worth fifteen dirhams. It was a garment bought for a dinar or so; it did not have objectionable thinness nor objectionable coarseness, and his wrap was fringed. Al-Fadl bin Ziyad said: I saw Abu Abdullah in the winter wearing two shirts and a colored Jubbah (outer robe) between them, and perhaps he wore a shirt and a heavy fur coat. Perhaps I saw him in the severe cold wearing the fur over the Jubbah. And I saw him wearing a turban over the cap (Qalansuwah) and a heavy cloak (Kisa'). Ja'far bin Muhammad bin Al-Mughirah said: I saw Abu Abdullah in the summer wearing a shirt, trousers, and a Rida' (upper garment). Perhaps he wore a shirt and Rida' and wrapped the Rida' (ittashaha), and he often used to wrap it over the shirt. Salih bin Ahmad said: My father had a cap that he had sewn with his hand containing cotton. When he stood for the night prayer, he wore it. Humayd bin Zanjawayh said: I saw Ahmad bin Hanbal wearing a green Jubbah with a white wool patch in it.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: Hamdan bin Ali said: I saw Abu Abdullah wearing a Jubbah with a patch on it of a different color. Al-Marwazi said: Abu Abdullah wanted to patch his shirt and did not have a patch. He said: 'I will patch it from my Izar.' So we cut from his Izar and patched it. He needed rags more than once, so he would cut from his Izar. He gave me a boot (Khuff) of his to repair which he had worn for seventeen years; there were five or six places of stitching in it from patching. Such was his clothing and his footwear, may Allah have mercy on him. If we compare this state with his livelihood and means of sustenance, we do not find it unlikely. For he, may Allah have mercy on him, was an ascetic among the great ascetics in the world, content with the little sufficiency that came to him from the yield of his land and what came from the earning of his hand and his family, refraining from accepting prizes and gifts. His Asceticism and Chastity: Ahmad's asceticism is a well-known thing. We have seen the pattern of his living, his night and his day, how he lived as an ascetic far from luxury and ease. We believe that had he wanted the world, it would have come to him dragging its trails with positions and mandates. His grandfather had a prominent status, and his father was likewise in the service of the Abbasid Islamic State. Then he had reached the summit in knowledge, virtue, and leadership. He had followers among the commanders and the common people who would ransom him with their souls, let alone their wealth, and who saw it as an honor for them that he accept gifts from them. But the Imam did not cast his eye toward the world and its adornments. He did not accept mandates and positions, preferring obscurity for himself and choosing humility and contentment with what would cover his need at the lowest levels of living. Ibn Al-Jawzi mentioned from Al-Shafi'i his saying: When I entered upon Harun Al-Rashid, I said to him after the address: I left Yemen

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: lost, needing a judge. He said: Look for a man from those who sit with you so that you may appoint him to its judiciary. When Al-Shafi'i returned to his gathering, he saw Ahmad bin Hanbal as the most exemplary of them. He turned to him and said: 'I spoke to the Commander of the Faithful about appointing a judge in Yemen, and he ordered me to choose a man from those who frequent me. I have chosen you, so prepare yourself so that I may take you in to the Commander of the Faithful to appoint you to the judiciary of Yemen.' Ahmad turned to him and said: 'I only came to you to acquire knowledge from you, yet you order me to enter into the judiciary for them?' He rebuked him, so Al-Shafi'i felt shy. Ibn Abi Hatim narrated from Salih bin Ahmad who said: I entered upon my father, may Allah have mercy on him, one day during the days of Al-Wathiq—and Allah knows best in what state we were. He had gone out for the Asr prayer. He had a felt mat he used to sit on, upon which many years had passed until it was worn out. Underneath it was a paper, and in it was: 'It has reached me, O Abu Abdullah, what straitened circumstances you are in and what debt is upon you. I have directed four thousand dirhams to you at the hands of so-and-so for you to pay your debt and expand upon your family. It is not from charity or Zakat; rather, it is something I inherited from my father.' I read the letter and put it down. When I entered (or he entered), I said: 'O father, what is this letter?' His face turned red, and he said: 'I hid it from you.' Then he said: 'Go with its answer.' He wrote to the man: 'Your letter reached me, and we are in well-being. As for the debt, it is to a man who does not harass us. As for our family, they are in a blessing, and praise be to Allah.' I went with the letter to the man who had delivered the man's letter. After a while, a letter from the man came to him with the same message, so he returned the answer just as he had responded (before). When a year or less or more had passed, we mentioned it. He said: 'If we had accepted it, it would have been gone by now.' End quote.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
Muhammad bin Sulayman Al-Sarakhsi sent him ten thousand dirhams. Ahmad said to the messenger of Muhammad Al-Sarakhsi: 'May Allah reward him with good; we are in a state of sufficiency and abundance,' and he refused to take it. He urged him again, but he said: 'Let us remain dignified.'

Imam Ahmad's Livelihood:
Indeed, seeking knowledge and Fiqh was almost synonymous with poverty. To the extent that a person directs his concern and ambition towards seeking and acquiring knowledge, his share of the world decreases, unless he has a source of income other than personal earning. If natural asceticism and extreme contentment are added to that, then do not ask about the tightness of his livelihood. The ideal student of this Ummah and the Faqih of the Companions, Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, narrates to us about his condition during his seeking of knowledge, and then his poverty and need, in what Al-Bukhari reported in his Sahih in the Book of Knowledge. He said with his chain of narration: Abu Hurairah, may Allah be pleased with him, said: 'People say: Abu Hurairah narrates too much. Were it not for two verses in the Book of Allah, I would not have narrated a single Hadith.' Then he recited: "Indeed, those who conceal what We sent down of clear proofs..." to His saying "the Merciful." 'Indeed, our brothers from the Muhajirun were occupied by striking deals in the markets, and our brothers from the Ansar were occupied by working on their properties. But Abu Hurairah used to stick to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, for the filling of his stomach, attending what they did not attend and memorizing what they did not memorize.' Imam Ahmad was among those sincere in seeking and acquiring knowledge, and he did not devote himself to trade or a specific continuous job. Rather, he was content with the little that came to him from the rent of a house he owned and from his work with his own hand or the hand of his family. Ibn Al-Jawzi mentioned in *Al-Manaqib*:

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: Ahmad, may Allah be pleased with him, had a father who left him *Tiraz* (meaning shops for weaving, where clothes are woven) and a house he lived in. He used to rent out those shops and, through their rent, abstained from asking people. It seems he used to rent out part of the house as well. However, the rent of these shops and the house was not sufficient to cover his needs. As is apparent from what Muhammad bin Yunus Al-Baladi mentioned, he said: 'I was sitting with Abu Abdullah when one of his tenants came to him with a dirham and a half. When it fell into his hand, he left me and got up and entered his home, and I saw happiness on his face. I thought he had prepared it for an important need.' Since this yield was not sufficient for his expenditure, he used to go out for *Luqat* (gleaning leftover harvest). Abu Ja'far Al-Tarsusi said: The one with whom Abu Abdullah stayed told me, saying: 'When he stayed with me, he went out for *Luqat*. He came back having gleaned something small. I said to him: "You have eaten more than you have gleaned." He said: "I saw a matter I was shy of; I saw them gleaning, and a man would stand on all fours, and I was thinner when I gleaned."' Abu Bakr Al-Marwadhi said: Abu Abdullah said to me: 'I went out to the *Thaghr* (frontier) on foot, and we gleaned. I saw people spoiling people's farms; it is not befitting for anyone to enter a man's farm except with his permission.' Ishaq bin Rahwayh said: 'I and Ahmad were in Yemen with Abdul-Razzaq. I was above in the room, and he was below. Whenever I came to a place, I bought a slave girl.' He said: 'I learned that his funds had run out, so I offered him [money]. He refused. I said: "If you wish, as a loan, and if you wish, as a gift." He refused. I looked, and behold, he was weaving *Tikk* (waistbands/drawstrings), selling them, and spending [from that].' It has been mentioned previously that he was in need during some of his days, so he hired himself out to porters. Perhaps he was in need and poverty overwhelmed him, so he would copy books for people for a wage. It has previously been mentioned

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: what Abu Nu'aym narrated in *Al-Hilyah* from Ali bin Al-Jahm who said: 'We had a neighbor who brought out a book to us and said: "Do you know this handwriting?" We said: "Yes, this is the handwriting of Ahmad bin Hanbal." We said to him: "How did he write that?" He said: "We were in Mecca staying with Sufyan bin 'Uyaynah. We sought Ahmad bin Hanbal for days but did not see him. Then we went to him to ask about him. The people of the house he was in said to us: 'He is in that room.' We came to him, and the door was closed on him, and he had worn-out clothes on. We said to him: 'O Abu Abdullah, what is your news? We haven't seen you for days.' He said: 'My clothes were stolen.' I said to him: 'I have dinars; if you wish, take them as a loan, and if you wish, as a gift.' He refused to do so. I said: 'Will you write for me for it?' (Thus in the book, and it seems the correct reading is: 'for a wage'). He said: 'Yes.' So I brought out a dinar, but he refused to take it. He said: 'Buy a garment/fabric for me and cut it in two halves.' He gestured that he would wrap his lower body with one half and drape the other half over his upper body. He said: 'And bring me the remainder of it.' So I did, and I brought paper and a notebook, and he wrote for me. So this is his handwriting."' There was another weak source for Imam Ahmad's livelihood at times, which used to provide sustenance for him and his family. His wife, Umm Salih, used to spin [yarn] in the house. Ibn Abi Hatim narrated from Salih bin Ahmad who said: My father said: 'Your mother used to spin fine yarn during times of high prices, and she would sell the skeins for two dirhams, less or more, and that was our sustenance.' This limited income, which was also unstable, depicts for us the standard of living of the Imam and his family in food and clothing. We have seen in his description and appearance how his clothing was. As for food, Salih, the son of the Imam, narrated to us in what was narrated from him

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: by Ibn Abi Hatim, saying: 'I would often see my father, may Allah have mercy on him, take crusts [of bread], shake the dust off them, put them in a bowl, and pour water over them until they were soaked, then eat them with salt. I never saw my father buy a pomegranate, nor a quince, nor any fruit, unless he bought a melon, which he would eat with bread, or grapes or dates. As for other than that, I never saw him buy it.' He also said: 'Often bread would be baked for him, and he would put lentils, fat, and a few dates in an earthenware pot for two months. He would come to the children with a bowl, call out to some of them, and give it to them; they would laugh and eat. He frequently used vinegar as a condiment. The Imam once felt a chill in his extremities, and he said: 'I see this only from my condiment, eating vinegar and salt.'' Imam Ahmad's Generosity and Munificence Despite Poverty: Ibn Al-Jawzi narrated in *Al-Manaqib* from Abu Bakr Al-Marwadhi who said: 'Abu Abdullah would often share his own sustenance. Abu Sa'id Al-Darir (the Blind) came and complained [of need]. He said to him: "O Abu Sa'id, we have nothing but this beam." So a porter was brought to carry it. He said: "I took the beam and sold it for nine dirhams and two Daniqs."' And from Yahya bin Hilal Al-Warraq who said: 'I came to Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Numayr and complained to him. He brought out four dirhams or five dirhams to me and said: "This is half of what I own."' He said: 'And I came once to Abu Abdullah Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Hanbal, and he brought out four dirhams to me and said: "This is all that I own."' And from Harun Al-Mustamli who said: 'I met Ahmad and said: "We have nothing."

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: So he gave me five dirhams and said: "We have nothing other than them."' He would even spend from his food, which he was in more need of, on some animals, preferring them over himself, may Allah have mercy on him. Al-Marwadhi said: 'I was with Abu Abdullah on the road to Al-Askar. We stopped at a resting place. I brought out a loaf of bread and placed a jug of water before him. Suddenly, a dog came. It stood opposite him and began wagging its tail. He threw a morsel to it, and it began to eat. He kept throwing morsels to it. I feared it would harm his [own] sustenance, so I got up and shouted at it to drive it away from him. I looked at Abu Abdullah, and he had turned red and changed out of shyness, and he said: "Leave it, for Ibn Abbas said: 'It has a soul/craving [that is bad to deny].'"' Imam Ahmad's Family: Imam Ahmad did not marry until after he reached forty years of age, as narrated by Al-Marwadhi. His first wife was 'Abbasah bint Al-Fadl, Umm Salih; no one was born from her except his son Salih. Then he married Rayhanah, who is Umm Abdullah, and no one was born from her except him [Abdullah]. She was a righteous woman who saw happiness in her husband's pleasure. When she passed seven days [after marriage], she said to the Imam: 'How did you see [things], O cousin? Did you disapprove of anything?' He said: 'No, except that this sandal of yours squeaks.' In another narration, Ahmad's wife said to Ahmad days after she entered upon him: 'Do you disapprove of anything from me?' He said: 'No, except for this sandal which you wear; it was not present during the time of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace.' He said: 'So she sold it and bought a cut [shoe].' She was Umm Abdullah.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: His Concubines: Al-Khallal said: Zuhayr bin Salih told us saying: 'When Umm Abdullah passed away, he bought Husn. She bore him Umm Ali, whose name was Zainab. Then Al-Hasan and Al-Husayn were born as twins, and they died shortly after their birth. Then she bore Al-Hasan and Muhammad, and they lived until they reached about the age of forty. Then she bore Sa'id after them.' Ibn Al-Jawzi mentioned the two mentioned wives, Umm Salih and Umm Abdullah, and this slave girl, then said: 'We do not know that Ahmad, may Allah be pleased with him, married other than the two women we mentioned, nor did he take a concubine except this slave girl whose name was Husn. However, Ibn Al-Munadi mentioned in the book *Fada'il Ahmad* (Virtues of Ahmad) that Ahmad asked his family's permission to take a concubine seeking to follow [the Sunnah], so they permitted him. He bought a slave girl for a small price and named her Rayhanah, following the practice of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. According to this, he would have bought two slave girls, and one of them would have been during the life of his wife.' Al-Dhahabi weakened this statement of Ibn Al-Munadi in his *Tarikh*. The Children of Imam Ahmad: 1 - Salih, who is the eldest of his children; his Kunya is Abu Al-Fadl. He was born in the year 230 and died in Ramadan in the year 265 in Isfahan. 2 - Abdullah, and his biography will come separately. 3 - Al-Hasan bin Ahmad, who lived about forty years. 4 - Muhammad bin Ahmad, who lived about forty years. 5 - Sa'id bin Ahmad. 6 - Zainab bint Ahmad; she grew up and reached marriageable age. 7 - Another daughter was mentioned for him: Fatimah bint Ahmad.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
The Fitnah (Tribulation) of the Creation of the Quran and the Ordeal of Imam Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him:
The most prominent matter in the life of Imam Ahmad is his noble, courageous stance in the Fitnah of the statement regarding the creation of the Quran. A blind, reckless Fitnah whose poisonous winds blew during the reign of the Abbasid Caliph Ma'mun. Although its germs were ancient and its roots deep, its links connect to Jewish hatred and resentment against Islam and Muslims. This Fitnah was fed by Greek and Roman philosophy, which was translated with all its malice, filth, polytheism, and paganism. Had the translation been limited to medicine and other human sciences, and had Muslims benefited from them in their worldly affairs, it would have been a praiseworthy matter, for our religion is a religion of Fitrah (natural disposition) that commands us not to forget our share of the world. But history tells us that the translation included, or rather encompassed, false philosophical ideas related to creed and the Essence of the Creator, Mighty and Majestic, and His Attributes as well—matters for which Muslims had no need, as our Messenger, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, had explained them with the clearest explanation. The first generation of this Ummah understood them clearly without interpretation (*Ta'wil*), distortion (*Tahrif*), likening (*Tamthil*), conditioning (*Takyif*), or negation (*Ta'til*); they passed them on as they appeared. Do you find any of them, even if he was the most Arab of Arabs and the most immersed in Bedouin life, finding the verses of Names and Attributes problematic? No, and never. Muslims in every time and place have ample scope in understanding the Companions of

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: the Chosen One (Al-Mustafa), may Allah bless him and grant him peace, regarding this Hanif (monotheistic) religion in creed and conduct. The last of this nation will not be rectified except by what rectified its first. When corrupt ideas entered them, they caused among them the denial of Attributes partially or totally, or their interpretation, or negation, along with other doubts and suspicions. Just as Jahmism, Mu'tazilism, and Ash'arism occurred as creeds. In summary, the origin of this malicious doctrine is the influence of Judaism fed by disbelieving philosophy and sophistry. Its roots connect to the Jews who were in the era of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and used to speak of the creation of the Torah. Ibn Al-Athir said in his *Tarikh* in the events of the year 240: 'In it, Judge Abu Abdullah Ahmad bin Du'ad died in Muharram, twenty days after his son Abu Al-Walid. He was a caller to the statement of the creation of the Quran and other doctrines of the Mu'tazilah. He took that from Bishr Al-Marisi, and Bishr took it from Al-Jahm bin Safwan, and Jahm took it from Al-Ja'd bin Dirham, and Al-Ja'd took it from Aban bin Sam'an, and Aban took it from Talut, the nephew of Labid bin Al-A'sam and his son-in-law. And Talut took it from Labid bin Al-A'sam the Jew who bewitched the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Labid used to speak of the creation of the Torah. The first to write on that was Talut, and he was a Zindiq (heretic), so he spread Zandaqah (heresy) (1).' The men of this deviant chain are Jews or of Jewish origin. As for Bishr bin Ghiyath Al-Marisi, who took charge of this Fitnah in his time and was the eye of the Jahmiyyah, their head, and their scholar in his era, his father was a Jew.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: Al-Khatib narrated in his *Tarikh* from Ishaq bin Ibrahim, nicknamed Lu'lu', the truthful and trustworthy, who said: 'I passed by the road and found Bishr Al-Marisi with people gathered around him. A Jew passed by, and I heard him say: "He will not corrupt your Book for you as his father corrupted the Torah for us"—meaning that his father was a Jew (1).' Al-'Ijli said in his *Thiqat*: 'Bishr Al-Marisi, upon him be the curse of Allah once; a short shaykh, ugly in appearance, with dirty clothes, abundant hair, looking most like a Jew. His father was a Jew, a dyer in Kufa in the market of nursing mothers.' Then he said: "May Allah not have mercy on him, for he was a Fasiq (transgressor)" (2). Al-Marwadhi said: 'I heard Abu Abdullah mention Al-Marisi and say: "His father was a Jew; what thing do you see him becoming?" (3).' The summary of the Fitnah and the Ordeal is that Al-Ma'mun, the Abbasid Caliph, had been overtaken by a group of Mu'tazilah who deviated him from the path of truth and beautified for him the statement of the creation of the Quran and the negation of Attributes from Allah, the Mighty and Majestic. Al-Bayhaqi said: 'There was no Caliph before him among the Umayyads or Abbasids except that he was on the Madhhab of the Salaf, and among them [the deviants] was Jahm. When he [Ma'mun] assumed the Caliphate, these people met with him and incited him to that and beautified it for him. It happened that he went out to Tarsus to fight the Romans, so he wrote to his deputy in Baghdad, Ishaq bin Ibrahim bin Mus'ab, the chief of police, ordering him to call the people to the statement of the creation of the Quran. That happened to him at the end of his life, months before his death in the year 218.
foot_note:
1. Tarikh Baghdad 7: 58.
2. Thiqat Al-'Ijli 1: 247 - 248.
3. Siyar A'lam Al-Nubala 10: 201, Al-Mizan 1: 323. (*)

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: When the letter reached him, he summoned a group of Imams of Hadith and called them to that. They refused, so he threatened them with beating and cutting off their livelihoods, so most of them answered under coercion. Imam Ahmad bin Hanbal and Muhammad bin Nuh continued to refuse, so they were carried on a camel in a single litter, shackled between two balanced loads. When they were in the land of Al-Rahbah, a man from the Bedouins among their worshippers came to them. He was called Jabir bin Umar. He greeted the Imam and said to him: 'O you, indeed you are the delegate of the people, so do not be a bad omen for them. You are the head of the people today, so beware of answering them to what they call you to, lest they [the people] answer, and you bear their burdens on the Day of Resurrection. If you love Allah, then be patient with what you are in, for there is nothing between you and Paradise except to be killed. And if you are not killed, you will die anyway; if you live, you live praiseworthily.' The Imam said: 'His words were among what strengthened my resolve on what I was in of refusal.' When they approached the army of the Caliphate and camped a stage away from it, a servant came wiping his tears with the edge of his garment saying: 'It grieves me, O Abu Abdullah, that Al-Ma'mun has drawn a sword he has never drawn before, and he swears by his kinship to the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: If you do not answer him to the statement of the creation of the Quran, he will surely kill you with that sword.' He said: So Imam Ahmad fell to his knees and looked towards the sky and said: 'My Master, Your forbearance has deluded this sinner until he dared against Your Awliya (allies) with beating and killing. O Allah, if Your Speech is uncreated, then suffice us against his burden.' He said: Then the scream came to them announcing the death of Al-Ma'mun in the last third of the night. Ahmad said: 'So we rejoiced. Then the news came that Al-Mu'tasim had assumed the Caliphate and

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad had joined him, and that the matter was severe. We were returned to Baghdad in a ship with some prisoners, and I received much harm from them.' Muhammad bin Nuh died on the way, and Ahmad prayed over him. When he returned to Baghdad, he entered it in Ramadan and was deposited in prison for about twenty-eight months. He prayed with the people of the prison while chains were on his legs. Then he was brought out for beating before Al-Mu'tasim. When he was brought in to Al-Mu'tasim, they increased the shackles on him. The Imam said: 'I could not walk with them, so I tied them with my waistband (*Tikkah*) and carried them by hand. Then they brought me an animal, and I was carried on it, and I almost fell on my face from the weight of the chains, and I had no one to hold me. Allah saved me until we came to the house of Al-Mu'tasim. I was put into a room and it was locked on me, and I had no lamp. I wanted to perform ablution, so I extended my hand and found a vessel with water, so I performed ablution. Then I stood up, not knowing the Qiblah. When morning came, I was facing the Qiblah, and praise be to Allah. Then I was called and brought in to Al-Mu'tasim. When he looked at me and Ibn Abi Du'ad was with him, he said: "Did you not claim that he was young in age? This is a middle-aged Sheikh." When I approached him and greeted him, he said to me: "Come near." He kept bringing me nearer until I was close to him. Then he said: "Sit." So I sat, and the iron weighed me down. I remained for a while, then I said: "O Commander of the Faithful, to what did your cousin the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, call?" He said: "To the testimony that there is no god but Allah." I said: "Then I testify that there is no god but Allah." Then I mentioned to him the Hadith of Ibn Abbas regarding the delegation of Abd al-Qays. Then I said: "So this is what the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, called to." He said: Then Ibn Abi Du'ad spoke words I did not understand. Then Al-Mu'tasim said: "Were it not that you were in the hands of the one before me, I would not have interfered

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: with you." Then he said: "O Abdur-Rahman, did I not order you to lift the Inquisition?" Ahmad said: I said: "Allah is Great! This is a relief for the Muslims." Then he said: "Debate him, O Abdur-Rahman; speak to him." Long debates took place. Ibn Abi Du'ad said: "He, by Allah, O Commander of the Faithful, is a misguided misguider, an innovator. Here are your judges and jurists; ask them." So he said to them: "What do you say?" They answered with the like of what Ibn Abi Du'ad said. Then they brought him on the second day and debated him, then on the third day. In all of that, his voice would rise over theirs, and his argument would overcome their arguments. When they fell silent, Ibn Abi Du'ad would open the speech against them, and he was the most ignorant of them in knowledge and theology (*Kalam*). The issues varied with them in the argument, and they had no knowledge of transmitted texts (*Naql*). They began denying the reports (*Athar*) and rejecting their use as evidence. During all that, the Caliph would be sympathetic to him and say: "O Ahmad, answer me to this so I may make you among my elect and among those who tread my carpet." The Imam would say: "O Commander of the Faithful, let them bring me a verse from the Book of Allah or a Sunnah from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, so that I may answer them to it." When no argument stood for them against him, they resorted to using the status of the Caliph. They said: "O Commander of the Faithful, this is a disbelieving, misguided misguider." Ishaq bin Ibrahim, the deputy of Baghdad, said to him: "O Commander of the Faithful, it is not from the management of the Caliphate that you let him go while he overcomes two Caliphs." At that, he heated up and his anger intensified. He had been lenient towards them, thinking they were on something [correct]. Imam Ahmad said: At that, he said to me: "May Allah curse you! I hoped for you to answer me." Then he said: "Take him, drag him, and strip him."

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: The Imam said: 'I was taken, dragged, and stripped. The two torture posts (*'Aqabayn*) (1) and whips were brought while I looked. I had with me some hairs from the hair of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, tied in my garment. They stripped me of it, and I was placed between the two posts. I said: "O Commander of the Faithful, by Allah, by Allah! Indeed, the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: 'The blood of a Muslim man who testifies that there is no god but Allah is not lawful except for one of three reasons...' and I recited the Hadith. And that the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: 'I have been commanded to fight the people until they say there is no god but Allah; if they say it, they have protected their blood and wealth from me.' So by what do you make my blood lawful when I have not done any of this? O Commander of the Faithful, remember your standing before Allah like my standing before you." It was as if he held back. But they kept saying to him: "O Commander of the Faithful, he is a misguided misguider, a disbeliever." So he ordered regarding me, and I stood between the two posts. A chair was brought, and I stood on it. Some of them ordered me to hold the two woods with my hands, but I did not understand, so my hands were dislocated. The scourgers came with whips. One of them would strike me two lashes, and he—meaning Al-Mu'tasim—would say to him: "Harder! May Allah cut off your hands!" Then another would come and strike me two lashes, then the other likewise. They struck me with whips until I fainted and lost my mind repeatedly. When the beating stopped, my mind would return to me. Al-Mu'tasim stood up to me calling me to their saying, but I did not answer him. They started saying: "Woe to you! The Caliph is at your head." But I did not accept. They resumed the beating, then he returned to me, but I did not answer him. They resumed the beating, then he came to me a third time and called me, but I did not comprehend what he said due to the severity of the beating. Then they resumed the beating, and my mind went; I did not feel the beating. That terrified him regarding my condition. He ordered me, and I was released. I did not realize until I was in a room of a house, and the shackles had been released from my legs. That was on the twentieth day of Ramadan of the year two hundred and twenty-one. The total of what he was whipped was some thirty odd lashes, and it was said: eighty lashes, but
foot_note: 1. (1) Al-'Aqaban: Two pieces of wood between which the man is stretched for flogging. (*)

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: it was very severe, excruciating beating (1). Ashabadh, one of the executioners, says: 'I struck Ahmad bin Hanbal eighty lashes; if I had struck an elephant with them, I would have demolished it' (2). Abu Al-Arab Al-Tamimi mentioned in the book *Al-Mihan* from Abu Imran Musa bin Al-Hasan Al-Baghdadi Al-Siqilli (3) who said: 'I was present at the affair of Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Hanbal. When (Al-Mu'tasim) brought Ahmad and ordered the executioners, they suspended him between the sky and the earth. Sixty executioners stood for him, thirty on one side and thirty on one side... Al-Mu'tasim stood up to him and said: "Woe to you, O Ahmad! I ask Allah not to test me with you. What do you say regarding the Quran?" He said: "The Quran is the Speech of Allah, and the Speech of Allah is uncreated." So he ordered regarding him, and he was beaten. Then he asked him, and he repeated his first saying: "The Speech of Allah." So he ordered, and they repeated the beating on him. Then he stood up to him and implored him by Allah for his own sake. He ordered two cushions (4), and they were placed under his feet, so he was suspended between the sky and the earth. Then Al-Mu'tasim asked him about the Quran, and he said to him: "The Speech of Allah, and the Speech of Allah is uncreated." One of the executioners said to him: "O Commander of the Faithful, if you wish, I will strike him two lashes that will kill him." So he struck him two lashes that split his sides, and his intestines spilled out. So he ordered regarding him, and he was taken out of the iron and wrapped in a full garment. The people and the commoners shouted, and the executioners came out and said: "Ahmad has died." They mentioned to the commoners that they had taken the iron off his legs while he was on his face. Then Abu Is-haq, the enemy of Allah, came out of the palace, and Ibn Abi Du'ad, the Zindiq, in a great procession. The commoners stood between Abu Is-haq and the bridge until he feared for himself, and they let him hear what distressed him (5).'
foot_note:
1. (1) Tarikh Ibn Kathir with some abbreviation 10: 331 - 335.
2. Al-Manhaj Al-Ahmad 1: 41.
3. His biography is in Tarikh Baghdad 13: 46, and no criticism or praise was mentioned therein.
4. Al-Miswarah: A cushion made of leather.
5. Kitab Al-Mihan 439 - 440, verification by Yahya Al-Jubouri, Dar Al-Gharb Al-Islami edition 1403. (*)

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: When the Imam was carried from the House of the Caliphate to the house of Ishaq bin Ibrahim while he was fasting, they brought him *Sawiq* (barley mush) to break his fast due to weakness, but he refused that and completed his fast. When the Zuhr prayer arrived, he prayed with them while blood was on his garment. Ibn Sama'ah the Judge said to him: 'You prayed in your blood?' Ahmad said to him: 'Umar prayed while his wound gushed blood.' So he remained silent. I say: Indeed, the prayer that the Imam prayed in his blood is better, Allah willing, with Allah by thousands of degrees than their prayers with their complete apparent purifications, because their prayers were tainted with innovations and corruption of creed. As for the prayer of the Imam, it was pure from any impurity, adorned by the noble badge of wounds for Allah and in the path of Allah. This noble blood that flowed from him for the sake of Allah will come on the Day of Resurrection, Allah willing; the color is the color of blood and the scent is the scent of musk, by which Allah raises his ranks with Him. When the Imam returned to the house of Ishaq bin Ibrahim, the chief of police, a surgeon came to him and cut dead flesh from his body and began treating him. The deputy would ask about him all the time because Al-Mu'tasim regretted what he had done to Ahmad greatly and kept asking the deputy about him. The deputy would inquire about his news. When he recovered, Al-Mu'tasim and the Muslims rejoiced at that. When the Imam went after his recovery to his home, he remained like that for the duration of Al-Mu'tasim's Caliphate, and likewise in the days of his son Al-Wathiq. When Al-Mutawakkil 'Ala Allah assumed the Caliphate, people rejoiced at his Caliphate, for he was a lover of the Sunnah and its people. He lifted the Inquisition from the people and wrote to the horizons: 'Let no one speak of the statement of the creation of the Quran.' He honored the Imam with extreme honor, to the point that he wrote to his deputy in Baghdad to bring the Imam to him. The Imam excused himself, then he [the Caliph] insisted on him, as he wished to be comforted by his proximity and looking at him and obtaining blessing from his supplication. So the Imam traveled to him while he was ailing regarding some of his sons. He lodged him in a noble lodging in

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: extreme magnificence and honor. The Caliph wrote for his family and children every month four thousand dirhams. Abu Abdullah refused the Caliph, so the Caliph said: 'It must be so, and this is only for your son.' So Abu Abdullah withheld from refusing. Then he began to blame his family and his uncle. After days, the Imam departed and entered Baghdad secretly. The Caliph used to send for him regarding matters to consult him and seek his advice in things that occurred to him (1). When the ordeal was lifted from him and Allah replaced it with the recognition of his virtue by the elite and the commoners—indeed, even the Caliph listened to his counsel and guidance—and Allah empowered the Imam over his enemies who caused him harm, did he take revenge on anyone? No, never. It is not hoped from a man whom Allah has stamped with forbearance, asceticism, and seeking reward with Allah that he would seek revenge from anyone. When Al-Mutawakkil summoned him and he approached the camp, Wasif the Servant met him in a great procession. He greeted the Imam, and the Imam returned the greeting. Wasif said to him: 'Allah has empowered you over your enemy Ibn Abi Du'ad.' He did not return an answer to him. We do not find a mention that the Imam took revenge on him or ever desired that. Likewise, he absolved everyone who harmed him except the people of innovation. regarding that, he used to recite His saying, the Exalted: "And let them pardon and overlook" [the verse], and say: 'What benefits you that your Muslim brother is punished because of you?' And the Exalted said: "But whoever pardons and makes reconciliation - his reward is [due] from Allah. Indeed, He does not like wrongdoers." Hanbal said: I heard him say: 'Everyone who mentioned me is absolved except an innovator. And I have absolved Abu Is-haq—meaning Al-Mu'tasim.'
foot_note: 1. (1) Epistle of Salih bin Ahmad, Al-Bidaya wa Al-Nihaya 10: 338 and following, and Manaqib Ahmad 308 and following. (*)

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: In the narration of Ibn Abdullah from his father: He said: 'Al-Wathiq sent to me to absolve Al-Mu'tasim from his beating of me. I said: "I did not leave his house until I absolved him, and I remembered the saying of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace: 'No one will stand on the Day of Resurrection except one who pardoned,' so I pardoned him."' Nothing is expected from the Imam of the Sunnah except this noble stance. He did not harbor a grudge against anyone for himself, while his followers wanted to incite him in some days, but he did not deviate from the upright path by a hair's breadth. Hanbal bin Is-haq, the cousin of the Imam, said in the *Book of Al-Mihnah*: 'When Al-Wathiq manifested this doctrine, beat [people] for it, and imprisoned [them], a group of the jurists of Baghdad came to Abu Abdullah, among them Bakr bin Abdullah, Ibrahim bin Ali Al-Munajji, Fadl bin Asim, and others. They came to Abu Abdullah, so I entered upon him and asked permission for them. They entered upon him and said to him: "O Abu Abdullah, this matter has spread and worsened. This man does such and such, and he has manifested what he has manifested. We fear for him more than this." They mentioned to him that Ibn Abi Du'ad resolved to order the teachers to teach the boys in the Maktab (school) along with the Quran, the Quran is such and such [created]. Abu Abdullah said to them: "So what do you want?" They said: "We came to consult you regarding what we want." He said: "So what do you want?" They said: "That we are not pleased with his command nor his authority." Abu Abdullah debated them for an hour until he said to them: "So what harms them if this matter is not completed? Have you not gone from that to what is disliked? You must [deny] with your hearts, and do not withdraw a hand from obedience, and do not split the staff of the Muslims along with you, and do not shed your blood and the blood of the Muslims. Look into the outcome of your affair, and do not hasten. Be patient until the righteous rests or the wicked is rested from." Much speech circulated among them regarding that which I did not memorize. Abu Abdullah argued against them for this [stance].

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: Some of them said: 'We fear for our children; if this is manifested, they will not know other than it, and Allah will erase Islam and it will be obliterated.' Abu Abdullah said: 'Nay! Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, is the Helper of His religion, and indeed this affair has a Lord who will help it. Indeed, Islam is mighty and impregnable.' So they left Abu Abdullah and he did not answer them to anything of what they resolved upon (1). The ordeal of Imam Ahmad and his emergence from it patient and seeking reward after this severe harm was a matter by which Allah honored and ennobled this Imam and singled him out apart from his peers. Allah made it a remaining word in his progeny. Their word united in praising him for this majestic stance, and his personality emerged as a banner and a sign for the Sunnah and its people. Imam Al-Bukhari said: 'When Ahmad bin Hanbal was beaten, we were in Basra. I heard Abu Al-Walid Al-Tayalisi say: "If Ahmad were among the Children of Israel, he would have been a legend (*Uhdu'thah*)."' Al-Muzani said: 'Ahmad bin Hanbal on the Day of the Ordeal, Abu Bakr on the Day of Apostasy (*Riddah*), Umar on the Day of the Saqifah, Uthman on the Day of the House (*Al-Dar*), and Ali on the Day of the Camel and Siffin.' Qutaybah said: 'Sufyan Al-Thawri died and piety died; Al-Shafi'i died and the Sunan died; and Ahmad bin Hanbal will die and innovations will appear.' 'Indeed, Ahmad bin Hanbal stood in the Ummah in the station of Prophethood,' said Al-Bayhaqi, meaning in his patience over the harm that befell him for the sake of Allah. Bishr Al-Hafi said: 'Ahmad was put into the furnace (*Kir*) and came out as red gold.' Ibn Al-Mu'alla Al-Raqqi said: 'Allah favored this Ummah with four: Al-Shafi'i who understood the Hadiths, explained them, and clarified the general from the specific and the particular from the general and the abrogating from the abrogated; Abu Ubayd who clarified its strange terms; Yahya bin Ma'in who negated lies from
foot_note: 1. (1) See Mafatih Al-Fiqh Al-Hanbali 1: 247 and Tarikh Al-Islam by Al-Dhahabi, part of the biography of the Imam in Tala'i' Musnad Ahmad 1: 105. (*)

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
the Hadiths; and Ahmad bin Hanbal who stood firm in the Ordeal. Were it not for these four, the people would have perished.' Ibn Hibban said: 'Allah aided the Ummah of Muhammad, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, through him. That is because he stood firm in the Ordeal and offered his self for Allah until he was beaten with whips to be killed, so Allah, the Exalted, protected him from Kufr (disbelief) and made him a banner to be followed and a refuge to be resorted to' (1).
* - The Effect of the Ordeal on Society: The outcome is for the righteous. The Ordeal with whose fire the people of Hadith were burned, led by Imam Ahmad, was replaced by a gift from Allah, the Exalted. Instead of being in humiliation and testing at one time, the time came when the word was theirs, and they were honored with extreme honor. The star of the Mu'tazilah, who had previously taken over the authority and used force to harm the people of Sunnah and prevent them from narrating the narrations of Attributes and the Vision and their likes, set. Al-Mutawakkil summoned the Muhaddithin to Samarra, gave them abundant gifts, honored them, and ordered them to narrate the Hadiths of Attributes and the Vision. Abu Bakr bin Abi Shaybah sat in the Mosque of Al-Rusafah, and about thirty thousand souls gathered to him. His brother Uthman sat in the Mosque of Al-Mansur, and about thirty thousand souls gathered to him. The supplication of the creation for Al-Mutawakkil abounded, and they exaggerated in praising him and glorifying him, until one of them said... 'The three Caliphs are Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq in fighting the people of Apostasy, Umar bin Abdul-Aziz in returning injustices, and Al-Mutawakkil in reviving the Sunnah and killing Jahmism' (2).
foot_note:
1. (1) See Manaqib Al-Imam Ahmad by Ibn Al-Jawzi.
2. Mafatih Al-Fiqh Al-Hanbali 1: 230, which is from Tarikh Al-Khulafa by Al-Suyuti p. 346. (*)

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
Conversely, the matter turned against the heads of the Mu'tazilah, and the circle turned on them. Al-Mas'udi mentioned in the events of the year 239 that he (Al-Mutawakkil) became angry with Ahmad bin Du'ad and his son Abu Al-Walid Muhammad bin Ahmad, who was in charge of the judiciary. He took from Abu Al-Walid one hundred thousand dinars and twenty thousand dinars and jewels worth forty thousand dinars. He attended to Baghdad, and Abu Abdullah Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad had become paralyzed forty-seven days after the death of his enemy Ibn Al-Zayyat. Ibn Al-Athir mentioned in *Al-Kamil* in the events of the year 237: 'In it, Al-Mutawakkil became angry with Ahmad bin Abi Du'ad, seized his estates and properties, and imprisoned his son Abu Al-Walid and the rest of his children. He charged Abu Al-Walid one hundred thousand and twenty thousand dinars and jewels whose value was twenty thousand dinars. Then he was reconciled after that for sixteen thousand dirhams [annually/monthly?], and he made them all witness the sale of their properties' (1).
* - Imam Ahmad's Rebuke: He hoped and requested from the companions who had a known status among the people in knowledge and piety that they not hasten in *Taqiyyah* (dissimulation) and not agree to the statement of the creation of the Quran. He saw that if they had been patient, they would have had regard with the State, and it would not have hastened to execute what the Mu'tazilah wanted from it. But when they hastened to use *Taqiyyah*, and the Imam and a few others who did not have great status among the people remained, it became easy for the State to take them on the pretext that the majority of scholars and jurists were with it. Just as their agreement became a cause for shaking the ideas of the common people and their disturbance as well. The Imam's indignation was especially upon those who did not enter into the ordeal and did not

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: they were not afflicted with little or much harm; rather, they feared the future and backed down. Therefore, he used to seek excuses for Sajjadah and Al-Qawariri, to the exclusion of others. Al-Maqrizi said: Abu Abdullah used to uphold their excuse and say: 'Were they not imprisoned and shackled? Allah the Almighty said: (Except for one who is forced while his heart is secure in faith).' Abu Abdullah said: 'Shackles are coercion, imprisonment is coercion, and beating is coercion. But if one is not afflicted with something disliked, there is no excuse for him' (1). He did not excuse those who hastened to use Taqiyyah (dissimulation) when they had not yet been afflicted with harm in this path. Ibn Al-Jawzi narrated with his chain of narration from Abu Bakr Al-Marwazi saying: Yahya bin Ma'in came and entered upon Ahmad bin Hanbal while he was sick. He greeted him, but he did not return the greeting. Ahmad had sworn by the covenant not to speak to anyone who had answered [the Inquisition] until he met Allah the Almighty. Yahya kept making excuses and saying: 'The Hadith of Ammar, and Allah the Almighty said: (Except for one who is forced while his heart is secure in faith).' I saw Ahmad turn his face to the other side. Yahya said: 'Uff,' and stood up, saying: 'He does not accept an excuse from us.' I went out after him while he was sitting at the door. He said: 'What did Ahmad say after me?' I said: 'He said: He uses the Hadith of Ammar as proof, but the Hadith of Ammar is: I passed by them while they were cursing you, so I forbade them, so they beat me. Whereas you, it was said to you: We intend to beat you. So I heard Yahya say: 'By Allah, under the sky, there is no one more knowledgeable in the religion of Allah than you' (2). He [Ali bin Al-Madini] also answered in the Mihnah (Inquisition) out of fear of harm and killing, may Allah have mercy on him. He did not limit himself to the extent of answering, but grew close to them and wanted to please Ibn Abi Du'ad by abandoning narration from the Imam, and he used to order people to strike out his Hadiths.
foot_note:
1. (1) See Mafatih Al-Fiqh Al-Hanbali 1: 242. 
2. Manaqib Ibn Al-Jawzi 389. (*)

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: It was said to Ibrahim bin Ishaq Al-Harbi: 'Was Ali bin Al-Madini accused of any lying?' He said: 'No, but he would narrate a Hadith and add a word to his report to please Ibn Abi Du'ad with it.' He was asked: 'Did Ali bin Al-Madini used to speak against Ahmad bin Hanbal?' He said: 'No, but if he saw a Hadith from Ahmad in a book, he would say: Strike this out, to please Ibn Abi Du'ad with it, although he had heard from Ahmad and in his book was written: I heard Ahmad, Ahmad said, and Ahmad told us' (1). For this reason, Al-Uqayli included him in 'Al-Du'afa' (The Weak Narrators) and said: 'He inclined towards Ibn Abi Du'ad and the Jahmiyyah' (2). Ibn Al-Jawzi narrated from Abu Bakr Al-Marwazi who said: We entered the military camp until we left; Abu Abdullah did not taste cooked food or fat. He said: 'How much did those people enjoy themselves—meaning Ibn Abi Khaythamah, Ibn Al-Madini, and Abd Al-A'la—I wonder at their greed for the world; how they circulate at their doors' (3). Ibn Rajab said in Sharh Al-Ilal in the biography of Ibn Al-Madini: He sought closeness to Ibn Abi Du'ad, as he won him over with his worldly wealth, accompanied him, and honored him. Due to that, he fell into difficult matters, to the extent that he used to speak against a group of the notables of the People of Hadith to please Ibn Abi Du'ad thereby, so Imam Ahmad shunned him for that (4). Since the stance of some scholars was as mentioned, and the Imam saw that they neglected the trust of the Call (Dawah) and standing by the side of the Truth and supporting it, it was natural that anger for the sake of Allah would arise within himself.
foot_note:
1. (1) Tarikh Baghdad 11: 470. 
2. Du'afa Al-Uqayli folio 297. 
3. Manaqib Ahmad 390. 
4. Sharh Ilal Al-Tirmidhi p. 187. (*)

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: Let us mention his saying when his uncle urged him to use Taqiyyah: 'If the scholar answers out of Taqiyyah and the ignorant remains ignorant, when will the truth appear?' For that reason, he abandoned narrating from those who answered during the Mihnah. Al-Uqayli said in 'Al-Du'afa': I read to Abdullah bin Ahmad the book 'Al-Ilal' from his father, and I saw in it many stories from his father from Ali bin Abdullah, then his name had been struck out, and written above it was 'A man told us,' then the entire Hadith was struck out. So I asked Abdullah, and he said: 'My father used to narrate to us from him, then he withheld his name and would say: A man told us, then he abandoned his Hadith after that.' It might be said: Those who chose Taqiyyah have their excuse, which is coercion, and they chose a permissible matter, so why did Ahmad shun them? Ibn Al-Jawzi answered this matter saying: The answer is from three aspects: First, the people were threatened and not beaten, so they answered, and a threat is not coercion (and this has become clear by what we mentioned of the Hadith of Yahya bin Ma'in). Second, he shunned them by way of discipline, so that the gravity of the statement they answered to would be known, thus preserving them from deviation. Third, it is said: Most of the people, when they answered, accepted money, frequented the people (oppressors), and sought closeness to them, so they did what is not permissible; therefore, they deserved blame and shunning (1).
foot_note: 1. (1) Manaqib Ahmad by Ibn Al-Jawzi p. 390. (*)

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: The truth is that the Imam's shunning of those who answered in the Mihnah was only for discipline and to denounce their action, and it was not an invalidation of their probity (Adalah) in any way. His abandonment of narration from Ali bin Al-Madini and his striking out of his Hadiths is carried upon this same matter. It appears to me that abandoning narration from Ibn Al-Madini was temporary, then he narrated from him later. The clearest example of this is that we find many texts from him narrated by the Imam in this book (Al-Ilal), just as we find many narrations from him in 'Al-Musnad'. It is possible that he struck out his Hadiths and then permitted them, so his students narrated them from him. We also find many narrations from Abdullah's additions and his narrations in his father's books and his book 'Al-Sunnah' from Ibn Ma'in. It is known that Abdullah would not write Hadith nor narrate except from whom his father was pleased with and permitted him to take from. Furthermore, it is inconceivable that the Imam pardoned those who caused him harm out of blind following, yet remained angry at those who chose Taqiyyah. Yes, since his anger was for Allah and in the path of Allah, he did not pardon the innovators who made the statement of the creation of the Quran a religion for themselves and due to it harmed him with all harm, like Ibn Abi Du'ad, the head and foot of the Fitna, as previously mentioned. * - The Illness of Imam Ahmad and His Death: After a life full of knowledge and Jihad, the Imam fell ill with his fatal illness on the night of Wednesday, with two nights passed of the month of Rabi' al-Awwal in the year 241. He passed away on the tenth day of his illness, on Friday, the twelfth of Rabi' al-Awwal. He was buried after Asr, and a massive crowd, estimated at one million souls, prayed over him. May Allah have mercy on him and raise his ranks with the Prophets, the Truthful, and the Martyrs. Amen.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: Description of the Book 'Al-Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal' (The Defects and Knowledge of Men) This includes identifying the name of the book, documenting its attribution to Imam Ahmad, describing the copy, mentioning its location and scribe, and a brief introduction to the book's materials. 1 - The Name of the Book: We find on the back of the book its name as follows: 'Kitab Al-Ilal wa Ma'rifat Al-Rijal' (The Book of Defects and Knowledge of Men) by Abu Abdullah Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Hanbal. Narration of Abu Ali Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Al-Hasan Al-Sawwaf. From Abu Abd Al-Rahman Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Hanbal. From his father. Hearing of Ubaydullah bin Ahmad. It appears that this is the name of the book by which Imam Ahmad, or his son Abdullah, or Abu Ali bin Al-Sawwaf named it. Whichever of these three named the book, this name is the designated one. If the one who named it was Imam Ahmad, it is clear. If it was Abdullah bin Ahmad, then it is most likely that after collecting and arranging it, he presented it and read it to his father. Likewise, if the one who named it was Abu Ali bin Al-Sawwaf, he also must have read it to Abdullah with this name, and Abdullah approved it.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: Because the scribe of the book, Ubaydullah bin Ahmad, copied it from the original of Abu Ali, so he must have copied it with its name and then heard it from Abu Ali. We do not think the naming came from him. Therefore, we see that what is affixed to the back of the book is the name of the book, nothing else. Those who benefited from the book often shortened the mention of its name, calling it 'Al-Ilal' (The Defects). Some called it 'Al-Tarikh' (The History) because it includes the history of narrators, their births, conditions, and deaths, similar to how the three histories of Al-Bukhari and the history of Ibn Abi Khaythamah and others were named. Although these books include some defects of Hadith, since the predominant characteristic is the clarification of the conditions of men (narrators), they were named 'Tarikh'. 2 - Documentation of the Book's Attribution to Imam Ahmad: We find many scholars, both ancient and modern, who are engaged in the science of Hadith or who work on mentioning authored works in sciences and arts, when mentioning works on 'Al-Ilal' and 'Jarh wa Ta'dil' (Disparagement and Praise), or when writing the biography of Imam Ahmad, they mention the book 'Al-Ilal' attributing it to the Imam, specifically the narration of his son Abdullah—this one which is in our hands. Furthermore, the materials quoted from Abdullah bin Ahmad from his father from the book 'Al-Ilal' within the books of the predecessors align with what this book contains, as is apparent to the one looking into their sourcing. Therefore, we do not doubt that this book 'Al-Ilal' originates from the works of Imam Ahmad because the matter has become famous, indeed Mutawatir (mass transmitted), such that it leaves no room for doubt. Perhaps a speaker might say: It was not a book authored by Imam Ahmad in this sense; rather, they are questions Abdullah directed to his father, and his father answered them, so the book should be attributed to Abdullah.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: We say that among the methods of spreading authorship in those days was that the student would write from the Sheikh while he dictated to him, or the student would ask the Sheikh sometimes and the Sheikh would answer him from his memory or from his book, so the book would spread through the student. In this way, most of the books of the Salaf (Predecessors) reached us. In this same way, Abdullah transmitted this book from his father, then added additions to it. This does not mean that the Imam did not have a book or a composition by him on this subject. What we conceive is that he had a book on Defects and Knowledge of Men in his own handwriting, like the Musnad and others. He dictated some of it to Abdullah, and some of it Abdullah asked him about, and he answered from his memory or from his book sometimes. This is indicated by those many narrations in which Abdullah says 'My father dictated to me,' and in some he says: 'I found in my father's book in his handwriting and I did not hear it.' So those he did not have dictated to him and those he found in his father's book, he appended later to the book. In any case, the existence of a book on the subject of Defects and Conditions of Men authored by Imam Ahmad is established for us, which his son Abdullah took from him by reading, dictation, and Wajadah (finding), and into which he inserted additions from his Sheikhs other than his father. Among those who mentioned the book 'Al-Ilal' of the Imam: 1 - Among the earliest of them, as far as I have seen, is Al-Uqayli Muhammad bin Umar bin Musa bin Hammad (died 322) in his book 'Al-Du'afa', where he said: I read to Abdullah bin Ahmad the book 'Al-Ilal' from his father, and I saw in it many stories from his father from Ali bin Abdullah (meaning Ibn Al-Madini), then his name had been struck out and written above it 'A man told us,' then the entire Hadith was struck out. So I asked

And he said in the biography of Wasil bin Abd Al-Rahman Abu Hurrah: Abdullah bin Ahmad said in 'Al-Ilal': Yahya bin Ma'in told me (6).

text: And he said in the biography of Abu Bakr bin Abi Musa Al-Ash'ari: Abdullah bin Ahmad said in 'Al-Ilal': I said to my father: So Abu Bakr bin Abi Musa (1)... And he said in 'Al-Talkhis': Ahmad said in 'Al-Ilal': Muhammad bin Ja'far told us, Hammam told us (2)... 11 - Al-Sakhawi Shams Al-Din Muhammad bin Abd Al-Rahman (died 902) mentioned it from some of the later scholars, saying: Al-Layth bin Sa'd authored in History in the second century in 'Al-Tabaqat', and in the third century Ahmad or the two Sheikhs and Al-Nasa'i (3)... 12 - Al-Kattani Muhammad bin Ja'far bin Idris (1274 - 1345) mentioned it in 'Al-Risalah Al-Mustatrifah': Kitab Al-Ilal by Al-Bukhari and by Muslim... and by Ahmad bin Hanbal and by Ali bin Al-Madini (4). As for transmission from the book with its chain of narration, it is found abundantly in the books of Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi: 'Taqyid Al-Ilm', 'Tarikh Baghdad', 'Al-Muwaddih li Awham Al-Jam' wa Al-Tafriq', 'Al-Jami'', and others. There are also very many quotes in 'Al-Jarh wa Al-Ta'dil' and 'Ilal Al-Hadith' by Ibn Abi Hatim from what Abdullah wrote to him from his father. Likewise, we find many quotes in 'Al-Ikmal' by Ibn Makula from Imam Ahmad, and these texts and quotes are present in the book. We also find Imam Al-Bukhari quoting extensively in 'Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir' from the speech of

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: Imam Ahmad, especially in places of disagreement regarding names, Kunyas, and death dates, as if he prefers his speech over the speech of others. I have pointed out these places in the 'History' during the extraction (Takhrij). These quotes from Al-Bukhari could have been received from the Imam orally, or he could have taken them from the book 'Al-Ilal' by Abdullah's narration or by other narrations. And Allah knows best. We also find Ibn Rajab in his explanation of 'Ilal Al-Tirmidhi' relying heavily on the statements of Imam Ahmad via Abdullah and others. As for the chain of narration (Isnad) of the book: We should mention what appeared in the title of the first part, which is: 'The First Part of Kitab Al-Ilal wa Ma'rifat Al-Rijal. From Abu Abdullah Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Hanbal, may Allah have mercy on him. Narration of Abu Ali Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Al-Hasan Al-Sawwaf from Abu Abd Al-Rahman Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Hanbal from his father Abu Abdullah. Hearing of Ubaydullah bin Ahmad. Then it belonged to Abu Al-Hasan Ali bin Al-Hasan bin Ahmad Al-Muqri. And he heard it by his reading to the Sheikh Abu Al-Fath Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Abi Al-Fawaris from Abu Ali bin Al-Sawwaf, and that was in Al-Muharram of the year four hundred and twelve. Also hearing all of it were Muhammad bin Khayran bin Al-Hussein Al-Mazari' and Abd Al-Wahid...

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: Abu Abdullah bin Ahmad Al-Bardi by the reading of Abu Al-Hasan Al-Muqri in the date (history)... Then it became property by purchase to Muhammad bin Nasir bin Muhammad bin Ali Al-Baghdadi, may Allah benefit him with it. He heard this part and the one after it from the glorious Sheikh Abu Ghalib Ahmad bin Al-Hasan bin Ahmad bin Abdullah bin Al-Banna from Abu Talib Muhammad bin Ali bin Al-Fath Al-Harbi Al-Ashari, may Allah have mercy on him, from Abu Al-Fath bin Abi Al-Fawaris and Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Bishran, both from Abu Ali bin Al-Sawwaf, may Allah have mercy on him and them. And he collated it.' End quote. This is a Sahih (authentic) chain; its men are known and trustworthy. As for Abdullah, the son of Imam Ahmad, he was born in Jumada al-Akhirah of the year 213. He grew up at the hands of his father, taking knowledge, piety, and asceticism from him with an ample share of memorization and intelligence. Then he took from the known Imams of knowledge in his era and attained a great status in the science of Hadith, until his father, the Imam, acknowledged his virtue. Abu Zur'ah said: Ahmad bin Hanbal said to me: 'My son Abdullah is fortunate in the science of Hadith—or in his memorization of it—he rarely discusses with me anything but what I do not memorize.' He also said: 'Abu Abd Al-Rahman has comprehended much knowledge' (1). Ahmad bin Al-Munadi said: There was no one in the world who narrated more from his father than him...

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: We still see our senior Sheikhs bearing witness to his knowledge of Men, Defects of Hadith, Names, and Kunyas, and his perseverance in seeking Hadith in Iraq and elsewhere. It is mentioned from their predecessors that they acknowledged this for him, to the extent that some of them went to great lengths in praising him for knowledge and increasing hearing of Hadith from his father (1). Al-Daraqutni was asked about him and about Hanbal bin Ishaq, so he said: 'Two noble trustworthy ones' (2). Abu Bakr Al-Khallal said: 'Abdullah was a righteous man, truthful in speech, very shy' (3). Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi said: 'He was trustworthy, firm, understanding' (4). He has authored works, the most important of which is 'Kitab Al-Sunnah' (5), which Sheikh Al-Kawthari named in his articles 'The Book of Deviation'. He attacked Abdullah and branded him with idolatry and anthropomorphism because of it, as he quoted from 'Kitab Al-Sunnah' some texts that contradict his creed, then said: 'Did the sayer of these words leave anything of idolatry and anthropomorphism?' (6). And he accused him of lying in his rebuke, saying: 'And Abdullah bin Ahmad, the author of 'Kitab Al-Sunnah', what his book contains is sufficient

2. Al-Tahdhib 5: 143. 
3. Tabaqat Al-Hanabilah 1: 183. 
4. Tarikh Baghdad 9: 375.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: to know the man. The likes of him is not believed regarding Abu Hanifa, and lying has been worn out in him' (1). The great verifier scholar, the Dhahabi of the era, Sheikh Abd Al-Rahman Al-Mu'allimi, has sufficed the burden and paid the debt of the Ummah in defending Abdullah and others of the Salaf and in refuting this man. So let his book 'Al-Tankil' be looked at. As for us, we say about Abdullah bin Ahmad what Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr used to answer the people of the Levant with when they taunted him as the son of the 'One with Two Waistbands': 'Yes, by Allah / And that is a defect whose shame is far from you' (2). We want the Sunnah and we love it; may Allah raise its flags and elevate its lighthouse in every time and place, and may the eyes of the innovators not sleep. Abdullah bin Ahmad died on the twenty-first of Jumada al-Akhirah in the year 290 and was buried in the cemetery of Al-Qati'ah (3). As for Ibn Al-Sawwaf, he is Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Al-Hasan bin Ishaq bin Ibrahim bin Abdullah Abu Ali, known as Ibn Al-Sawwaf. He was born in the year 270 and heard Hadith from Ishaq bin Ibrahim Al-Harbi, Bishr bin Musa, and Abdullah bin Imam Ahmad, among others. Al-Daraqutni, Abu Al-Hasan bin Bishran, and Muhammad bin Abi Al-Fawaris narrated from him. Al-Daraqutni said: 'My eyes have not seen the likes of Abu Ali bin Al-Sawwaf.' His student Ibn Abi Al-Fawaris said: 'He was trustworthy, safe. Among the people of caution (taharruz), I have not seen the likes of him in caution.'
foot_note:
1. (1) Quoted from the book Al-Tankil 1: 284. 
2. See Sahih Al-Bukhari 9: 53 Foods. 
3. Tarikh Baghdad 9: 379. (*)

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: Abu Ali died on the third of Sha'ban in the year three hundred and fifty-nine (359) (1). As for the narrator from Abu Ali for the book 'Al-Ilal', he is Ubaydullah bin Ahmad bin Muhammad Abu Al-Fath Al-Nahwi, known as 'Jakhjakh'. He was born in the year 286 and heard from Abu Al-Qasim Al-Baghawi and his class, and Abu Bakr bin Durayd and those after him. He narrated a small amount. Abu Al-Hasan bin Al-Furat and Muhammad bin Abi Al-Fawaris heard from him, and he narrated from Ibrahim bin Makhlad. Al-Khatib said: 'He was trustworthy, with a correct book.' He died on the night of Friday and was buried on Friday, the tenth of Jumada al-Akhirah in the year three hundred and fifty-eight (2). Sharing with him in narrating the book from Abu Ali based on this copy were both Abu Al-Fath bin Abi Al-Fawaris and Ibn Bishran, as mentioned in the hearing. Abu Talib Muhammad bin Ali bin Al-Fath Al-Ashari narrated from them both. Ahmad bin Al-Hasan Al-Banna narrated from him. Muhammad bin Nasir Al-Salami narrated from him. We establish their biographies below as well. * Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Faris bin Sahl, Abu Al-Fath bin Abi Al-Fawaris. Al-Khatib said: He was born at the dawn of Sunday, with eight days remaining of Shawwal in the year thirty-eight

1. (1) Tarikh Baghdad 1: 289, Tabaqat Ibn Abi Ya'la 1: 164, Al-Muntazam 7: 52 - 53. 
2. See Tarikh Baghdad 10: 358, Al-Muntazam 7: 5. (*)

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: and three hundred. He heard from Abu Bakr Muhammad bin Al-Hasan Al-Naqqash and Abu Ali bin Al-Sawwaf. He traveled seeking Hadith to Basra, the land of Fars, and Khurasan. He wrote much and collected. He possessed memorization, knowledge, honesty, and was trustworthy, famous for righteousness. He died on Wednesday, the sixteenth of Dhu al-Qi'dah in the year four hundred and twelve (412) and was buried in the cemetery of Bab Harb (1). * As for Ibn Bishran, he is Abu Al-Hussein Ali bin Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Bishran bin Muhammad bin Bishr bin Mahran Abu Al-Hussein Al-Mu'addil. Ibn Al-Jawzi said: He was truthful, trustworthy, firm, of good character, and complete chivalry. He died in Sha'ban of the year 415 (2). * And Muhammad bin Ali bin Al-Fath bin Muhammad bin Ali Abu Talib Al-Harbi, known as Ibn Al-Ashari. He heard Ali bin Umar Al-Sukkari, Abu Hafs bin Shahin, Abu Al-Hasan Al-Daraqutni, and a multitude from this class. Al-Khatib said: I wrote from him, and he was trustworthy, pious, righteous. His birth was in Al-Muharram of the year 366, and he died on Tuesday, the twenty-ninth of Jumada al-Ula of the year 451 (3).
