2. Al-Muntazam 8: 18. 
3. Tarikh Baghdad 3: 107, Al-Muntazam 8: 214. (*)

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: * As for Ahmad bin Ali bin Al-Hasan bin Ahmad bin Abdullah bin Al-Banna Abu Ghalib, he was born in the year 445 and heard Abu Muhammad Al-Jawhari, Abu Al-Hussein bin Hasnun, Abu Ya'la, and a large multitude. He was trustworthy. He died in the year 527, stated by Ibn Al-Jawzi (1). * And Muhammad bin Nasir bin Muhammad bin Ali bin Umar Al-Salami, Al-Baghdadi Abu Al-Fadl. He was born in the year 467. Abu Musa Al-Madini said: He is the leader of the People of Hadith in his time in Baghdad. Al-Silafi said: Ibn Nasir heard much with us. He is Shafi'i Ash'ari, then he moved to the Madhhab of Ahmad in fundamentals and branches and died upon it. He possesses excellence, precision, and good knowledge, and he is a firm Imam. Ibn Al-Jawzi said: He was a Hafiz (preserver), precise, exact, trustworthy, from the People of the Sunnah with no fault in him. Ibn Al-Najjar said: He was good in transmission, correct in recording, with much memorized. He had an extended hand in knowledge of grammar and language. His originals were of the utmost correctness and precision. He was trustworthy, noble, a proof, of good path, pious, poor, abstinent, clean, and integrous. He endowed his books to the People of Hadith. He died in the year 550 and left no offspring (2). When Did the Authoring of the Book 'Al-Ilal' Occur: I found a text in Al-Uqayli indicating that Ahmad, may Allah have mercy on him, authored the book 'Al-Ilal' before the Mihnah (Inquisition) in the Fitna of the creation of the Quran.
foot_note:
1. (1) Al-Muntazam 10: 31. 
2. Al-Muntazam 10: 162, Tadhkirat Al-Huffaz 4: 1289, Wafayat Al-A'yan 4: 293, Al-Bidayah wa Al-Nihayah 12: 233. (*)

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: Al-Uqayli said in the biography of Ali bin Al-Madini: 'I read to Abdullah bin Ahmad the book Al-Ilal from his father, and I saw in it many stories from his father from Ali bin Abdullah, then his name had been struck out and written above it: 'A man told us,' then the entire Hadith was struck out. So I asked Abdullah and he said: My father used to narrate to us from him, then he withheld his name, and he would say: 'A man told us,' then he abandoned his Hadith after that' (1). In this is clear evidence that the authoring of 'Al-Ilal' occurred before the Imam's entry into the Mihnah, because during the days of the Mihnah he was detained and imprisoned, finding no opportunity to author a large book like this. Furthermore, the book consists of questions directed from Abdullah to his father in most cases, and Abdullah was not with him in prison. 3 - Description of the Copy: We have not found a complete copy of the book 'Al-Ilal' by Abdullah's narration other than this unique copy that is in our hands now. The twelfth part was mentioned for it by the narration of Mukram Al-Bazzar, and its description will follow. As for this copy of ours, it is from the preservation of the 'Aya Sofya' library in Turkey, registered therein with number (2380) (2). It comprises (180) leaves, size (30 x 17 cm), divided into eight parts. Each part comprises 24 leaves. Face 'A' of each part includes the title of the book and the hearings, except for the eighth part, which is in a fine script different from the script of the first seven parts.
foot_note:
1. (1) Al-Du'afa by Al-Uqayli folio 298. 
2. History of Arabic Heritage by Sezgin 2: 204. (*)

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: The number of lines in the seven parts ranges between (28 and 33) lines on each page. As for the eighth part, the number of lines in it comes between (50 and 60) lines on each leaf. The script is Naskhi, usual according to the method of old scripts. As for the scribe of the book, we did not find an explicit text with his name, but some indications suggest that the scribe of the first seven parts is Ubaydullah bin Ahmad known as 'Jakhjakh', the auditor of this copy and its owner, and his biography has passed. The indication for that is the phrase established at the top of leaf (170 A) of the eighth part, which is: 'This part (meaning the second part [sic - context implies the part written by Ibrahim]) is in the handwriting of Ibrahim bin Muhammad bin Yaqub bin Al-Hasan bin Al-Ma'mun; he used to listen with Abu Al-Hasan bin Furat and Ubaydullah bin Ahmad Al-Nahwi 'Jakhjakh', to whom this copy belonged. Ibn Nasir wrote it.' So the statement of Ibn Nasir, who is the firm trustworthy one, indicates that the first owner of the complete copy is Ubaydullah bin Ahmad, the holder of the hearing from Abu Ali bin Al-Sawwaf. Also indicating what is sought is the phrase established at the top of leaf (24 B): 'Read to Abu Ali bin Al-Sawwaf, on Monday, the sixth of Rajab in the year three hundred and forty-three, while I was looking at the original.' This phrase is in the handwriting of the original of the copy, with no difference whatsoever. Therefore, we see that its scribe is Ubaydullah bin Ahmad; he copied it from the original of Abu Ali

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: bin Al-Sawwaf, and owned it, and he used to listen and collate with Abu Ali bin Al-Sawwaf, and his copy would be in his hand. As for his taking the original of Ibn Al-Sawwaf as a source for his copy during transcription, it is indicated by the margin placed by Ubaydullah on folio (26 B) at the beginning of the second part with the following phrase: 'End of the second part of Abu Ali bin Al-Sawwaf, the original, and we reached it in hearing.' And what came in folio 62 B right margin: 'Thus in the original of Abu Ali and in the book of Ibn Khalid...' As for the eighth part, it is not in the handwriting of Ubaydullah, but in the handwriting of his peer and companion, Ibrahim bin Muhammad bin Yaqub bin Al-Hasan bin Al-Ma'mun (the Caliph), as Ibn Nasir Al-Salami confirmed to us. We did not find a separate independent biography for this Ibrahim, except that Al-Khatib Al-Baghdadi said in the biography of his father Muhammad bin Yaqub: 'He had a son called Ibrahim who wrote much Hadith. Muhammad bin Abi Al-Fawaris mentioned that this Muhammad bin Yaqub died on Tuesday, the second night of Al-Muharram in the year 356, and his son Ibrahim died after him suddenly by a week.' He said: 'His birth was in the year three hundred and five (305), and I do not think he narrated' (1). It appears that he wrote it by agreement with Ubaydullah and by referral from him near the time of writing the previous parts. What indicates this is that the back of leaf (170 A) which contains the title of the eighth part...

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: written in the handwriting of the first scribe, who is Ubaidullah bin Ahmad. So we imagine that Ubaidullah handed over the writing to his companion in the hearing (*Sama'*), Ibrahim, for some reason, perhaps due to a shortage of paper, because Ibrahim, as it appears, was distinguished by the ability to write and the quality of calligraphy along with its precision and the smallness of his letters. Therefore, we see that this eighth part took up only (10) papers instead of (24) papers, had it been written in the previous handwriting. Thus, it is not thought that this part was written later to complete a deficiency. We can infer this by the existence of appendices (*Alhaq*) in the margins of folios (170 b), (172 b), (174 a and b), (176 a), and (178 a) of the eighth part. The handwriting of these appendices and corrections differs completely from the handwriting of the part and resembles the handwriting of the previous seven parts. As for what came at the end of the book on the last folio (180), we do not doubt that it is in the handwriting of the scribe of the first parts. It is his statement: "Praise be to Allah alone, and may Allah bless and grant peace to Muhammad the Prophet and his family. The end of the sixth part of the parts of Abdullah, and it is the end of the book." Therefore, we see that some reason occurred to Ubaidullah bin Ahmad, the owner of the copy and its scribe, so he transferred the writing and copying to his companion Ibrahim bin Muhammad. When Ibrahim finished copying, Ubaidullah undertook the comparison and correction, so he established the appendices and wrote the conclusion. As for the date of copying, no explicit, clear evidence indicated it either, except that certainty is attained that the copying of the book occurred before Rajab of the year three hundred and forty-three. As we mentioned previously by the context of what appeared at the top of folio (26 b): "Read to

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
Abu Ali Al-Sawwaf on Monday, the sixth of Rajab, the year three hundred and forty-three, while I was looking at the original." And as established on the back of folio (146 a) under the title of the seventh part, the hearing of Ubaidullah bin Ahmad in the handwriting of the original is as follows: "And our hearing was on Wednesday, with eight [nights] remaining of Dhu al-Hijjah, the year three hundred and forty-three." And at the top of folio (146 b), the following phrase appeared: "Read to Abu [Ali] bin Al-Sawwaf in Dhu al-Hijjah, the year three hundred and forty-three, and I heard: In the name of Allah, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful..."

**The Care of Scholars for this Copy:**
It is from the miracle (*Karamah*) of Imam Ahmad that Allah, the Mighty and Majestic, preserved his feats and writings in a documented form, even if there was only one copy of them. We find that scholars have cared for it from the very beginning of its copying through hearing and reception. I have previously worked on investigating the book *Fada'il al-Sahabah* (Virtues of the Companions) and I did not find for it except one copy, but it was extremely clear in handwriting and correction, and it had numerous hearing certificates (*Sama'at*) over the span of two centuries. This is the second book of Imam Ahmad's books for which I did not find another copy, but this unique copy was cared for by scholars from the first days of copying with extreme care regarding hearing and correction. Furthermore, it was compared (*Mu'aradah*) against two or more copies by the scribe himself, as will be seen.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: Even though more than one thousand and fifty years have passed since its copying, no change has occurred to it. Allah preserved it from the accidents of time and the fluctuations of days throughout these long centuries, fresh and tender as it was written. Nothing was lost from it except some hearing certificates in the margin due to unskillful wrapping and binding by later people. The copy of the book was in the possession of its scribe and owner, Ubaidullah bin Ahmad Al-Nahwi. Then it transferred to the possession of Abu Al-Hasan Ali bin Al-Hasan bin Ahmad Al-Maqri (1). We do not know how the copy transferred to him, but after him, Al-Dhahabi possessed it and heard it by his reading to Sheikh Abu Al-Fath Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Abi Al-Fawaris, who is one of its narrators from Abu Ali bin Al-Sawwaf. Thus, the sequence of narration is established for us without interruption. Then it did not appear to us where this copy was after the death of Al-Maqri in the year 449, nor who owned it until it became the property, through purchase, of Muhammad bin Nasir bin Muhammad bin Ali Al-Salami (467 - 550). He heard it from Sheikh Abu Ghalib Ahmad bin Al-Hasan Ibn Al-Banna, who heard it from Abu Talib Al-Ashari, and he narrates it from Abu Al-Fath bin Abi Al-Fawaris and Muhammad bin Abdullah [bin] Bishran, and both of them narrate it from Abu Ali bin Al-Sawwaf. It appears that Abu Al-Fadl Muhammad bin Nasir Al-Salami made it an endowment (*Waqf*) for students of knowledge, according to his noble habit of endowing his books to the people of Hadith, as mentioned in his biography. Confirming the endowment of the copy to us is what came at the end of the established hearing on folio

I wrote from him, and he was truthful (*Saduq*). He died on the ninth of Rabi' al-Akhir in the year 449." (Tarikh Baghdad 11: 391). (*)

text: 25 b from Abu Al-Faraj Ibn Al-Jawzi and others, and at its end is the phrase "and it is Waqf." People followed in succession in hearing it in the years 562, 563, and 575, as established in the hearing certificates. It appears to us that the book had several copies copied by the students of Abdullah bin Ahmad, among them the copy of "Ibn Khalid" and the copy of "Makram." And that Ubaidullah bin Ahmad compared this copy of his against these two copies. We infer this from what appears in several places in the margin of the copy, the phrase: "Thus in the original and in the book of Ibn Khalid..." See folio (35 b), and in it: "In the copy of Ibn Khalid and others." And folios (48 b), (51 a), (63 a), (71 b), (75 a), and (83 b), and in them is the following phrase: "In the book of Ibn Khalid [it is] 'Ali' and it is not in the original; it fell from it." And (85 a), (109 a), (110 a), (122 b), (123 b), and (123 b) as well, and in it: In the original "I asked my father..." while in the margin it is thus: "In the copy of Makram and Ibn Khalid: I asked Yahya." All these comparisons and corrections are in the handwriting of the original [scribe] of the copy. We infer that Ibn Khalid was among the students of Abdullah from what appeared in the margin of folio (48 b): "Ibn Al-Sawwaf said: In the book of Ibn Khalid, which is ours by license (*Ijazah*) from Abdullah, Abu Abdur-Rahman said: My father did not narrate from Is-haq other than this." The handwriting of this phrase is different from all other handwritings, and I think this is the handwriting of Ibn Al-Sawwaf himself. He would have written it during the hearing and presentation to him on the copy. And Allah knows best. This text proves to us that Ibn Khalid is from the students of Abdullah, not from the students of

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: Ibn Al-Sawwaf, as the investigator of the printed part understood. And that Ibn Khalid was among those who possessed a copy of the book. As for Ibn Al-Khalid, who is he? Whose son is he? I have not been guided to him after wonder and research. It is also proven to us that "Makram" also had a complete copy of the book *Al-'Ilal*, and he is also one of the students of Abdullah. The scribe compared his copy with it. This Makram is: Makram bin Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Makram, Abu Bakr, the Judge (*Qadi*), the Cloth Merchant (*Bazzaz*). He heard from Yahya bin Abi Talib, Ahmad bin Ubaidullah Al-Narsi, Ahmad bin Ali Al-Abbar, and others. Al-Khatib said: He was trustworthy (*Thiqa*). He died on Thursday, the fifth of Jumada al-Ula in the year three hundred and forty-five (1). One might deduce from the phrases that appeared in the margins: "Beginning of the part... from the parts of Abdullah," or "End of the part..." that the scribe of this copy, Ubaidullah bin Ahmad, undertook the comparison of his copy with the copy of Abdullah bin Ahmad as well. However, I see that this deduction is not correct, and I do not think that Ubaidullah bin Ahmad found or saw the copy of Abdullah, the son of Imam Ahmad. For had he found it, he would have compared his copy with it and established the differences or corrected his copy in light of it, and we do not find any indication of this matter. So I consider it more likely that he found in the copy of Abu Ali bin Al-Sawwaf—who differed in his division from the division of Abdullah bin Ahmad, so he (i.e., Ibn Al-Sawwaf) established the beginning and end of Abdullah's parts—written like this. So when he copied his copy from it and differed in his division from the division of Ibn Al-Sawwaf, he established what he found written in the margin from the division of Abdullah, just as he established the division of Abu Ali bin Al-Sawwaf as well.

text:
Yes, it appeared in the margin of folio (45 a) on the left: "End of the second part of the copy which has the hearing of Al-Ashari from Ibn Abi Al-Fawaris and Ibn Bishran from Ibn Al-Sawwaf, and it was compared with it and it agreed." We did not find the name of its writer with this phrase, but it appears to be in the handwriting of Ibn Nasir. It indicates that Ibn Nasir found another copy that had the hearing of Al-Ashari, so he compared this copy—which was in his possession—with it and found agreement between them. Also, the following phrase appeared in the margin of folio (57 a) in a later handwriting, not the original handwriting: "In the original of Ibn Al-Sawwaf: from Al-Taimi instead of Al-Sha'bi." This indicates that some of the later scholars, perhaps Ibn Nasir or those after him, found the copy of Ibn Al-Sawwaf and compared this copy with it for increased documentation and correction. Thus, the extreme care that the people of Hadith exerted on this copy of ours becomes apparent.

**As for the twelfth part of Makram's copy:**
It is among the holdings of the Al-Zahiriyah Library. Yusuf Al-'Ush mentioned it in the catalog of manuscripts of Dar Al-Kutub Al-Zahiriyah. History and its appendices. He said: "The twelfth part of the book *'Ilal al-Hadith wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal* from Abu Abdullah Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Hanbal Al-Shaybani, may Allah be pleased with him, from what his son Abu Abdur-Rahman Abdullah bin Ahmad narrated from him. Questions regarding the men of Hadith. Its beginning: Judge Makram bin Ahmad bin Makram informed us by reading to him in the year three hundred and forty-one. He said: Abu Abdur-Rahman Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Hanbal told us, saying:

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: I said to my father, may Allah be pleased with him: Abdullah bin Abi Najih, did his father hear from any of the Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace? He said: Perhaps from Abdullah bin Amr.' The copy is defective (*makhrumah*) at its end, which is: 'My father told me, saying: Rawh told us, saying: Shu'bah told us, saying: I heard Habib bin Abi Thabit.' In a collection number 544 from folio 98 to 106 (1). The scholar Al-Albani mentioned it in the catalog of Al-Zahiriyah manuscripts selected from Hadith manuscripts under number 785 - 1048 with a summary description. But the regret is that it was not possible to obtain this part so that it could be compared with the book, except that we are of the prevailing opinion that the scribe of the copy has sufficed us this burden, as previously indicated.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
**A Brief Summary of the Book's Materials and Contents:**
The book *Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal* is one of the ancient books. It contained subjects of defects (*'Ilal*) of Hadith, conditions of men (*Rijal*), and hadiths in various chapters that, at first glance, do not seem to have a relation to the subject of the book in some instances. It appears that Imam Ahmad used to record these various materials in days, and even in different years, so he did not observe, or rather: it was not possible for him to have a special arrangement for narrators in classes (*Tabaqat*), nor in alphabetical letters, nor in Sheikhs and students, and other considerations of arrangement. Similarly, he did not observe arrangement and categorization in the Fiqh-based hadiths, whether defective or non-defective. Imam Ahmad narrated this collection to Abdullah as it is. This section is expressed by Abdullah with his saying: "I heard my father..." Also, the large part of the book consists of Question and Answer. Abdullah directed the question to his father regarding the various daily issues that would confront him regarding narrators and their hadiths, and the Imam answered it, so Abdullah recorded it and placed it beside what his father narrated to him on different occasions without a question from him. This section is what Abdullah expresses with his saying: "I asked my father."

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: It is possible that in this section there is a question from someone other than Abdullah directed to the Imam, so he answered it, and Abdullah was in the gathering, so he heard it and recorded it. This section also, as it appears, is expressed by Abdullah with his saying: "I heard my father..." Also, a fair portion of the book contains what Abdullah heard or asked about from other than his father, interspersed among the materials of the book. Since its recording happened over different days and years, this is the secret behind the repetition of some texts, as it appears to me. Yes, we find at times some arrangement in certain subjects, such as when he mentioned a large portion of Hushaym's narrations, especially to clarify his Tadlis (obfuscation) in them. He mentioned them from text (2125) to (2269), all of them from the hadith of Hushaym, saying in most of them... "Hushaym did not hear it from Sayyar," for example. And he may list the names of those who narrated from Umar among the people of Mecca, those who narrated from him among the people of Basra, those who narrated from Ali bin Abi Talib among the people of Basra, those who narrated from Uthman bin Affan among the people of Medina, and those who narrated from Umar among the people of Kufa... so he lists the narrators as if he is trying to be comprehensive. See texts (464, 465, 466, 467, 468) in order. I saw in one place in the book that he created a chapter on grammatical error (*Lahn*), but he did not mention in it except one text, which is number (645).

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: He may arrange some materials for specific purposes. Such as when he said: "These men are those whom Mis'ar narrated from among the people of Kufa and others, and Shu'bah did not hear from them..." And he said in another place: "And these are those whom Shu'bah narrated from and Sufyan did not narrate from..." And he said in another place: "From Shu'bah that he said: I saw Muhammad bin Al-Muntashir and Habib bin Salim," so he listed those whom Shu'bah saw. And he said in another place: "These are those whom Sufyan narrated from and Shu'bah did not narrate from..." so he mentioned them. This is regarding the arrangement of subjects. As for the types of materials and subjects, we can assert that the book comprised the majority of the sciences of Hadith. Regarding defects (*'Ilal*) of Hadith, he mentions hadiths from every chapter and indicates the type of defect in them, such as *Irsal* (disconnection at the end), *I'dal* (omission of two or more consecutive narrators), *Inqita'* (disconnection), and being *Shadh* (odd) or *Munkar* (denounced) or from the unique reports (*Afrad*) of the narrator, and disturbance (*Idtirab*), interpolation (*Idraj*), misreading (*Tashif*), distortion (*Tahrif*), and others. He also mentions regarding narrators: births and deaths, trustworthy and weak, confused (*Mukhtalit*) and obfuscator (*Mudallis*), the creed of the narrator—Sunnah, Shi'ism, Qadar (free will), Nasb (hatred of Ali)—and Kunyas, names, lineages, and tribes, Kunyas of those known by names, names of those known by Kunyas, the Agreeing and Dispersing (*Al-Mu'talif wa Al-Mukhtalif*) and the Resembling (*Mutashabih*), ambiguous names (*Mubhamat*), and other than that. He may mention the chain of narration (*Isnad*) in full and mention its text (*Matn*) at length, and the purpose of it is to clarify the hearing and reporting of a Mudallis, for example, or another purpose. Such as what is said: In the first text in the book, and in it also is an indication that Hushaym was the first from whom the author heard

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: Hadith. Just as mentioned in the biography of Imam Ahmad. He may mention the Isnad and not mention the Matn with it, and the purpose of it is to clarify the lineage of the narrator or his Kunya, or something else; see text (46). He may mention a text and no relevance to the subject of the book appears for it, but with scrutiny and precision, the relevance and benefit appear. An example of that is what he said in text (16): "My father told me: Hushaym told us, saying: One of them claimed to me, saying: Al-Hajjaj wrote that Ibrahim bin Yazid should be taken to his governor. When the letter came to him, he said: So he wrote to him: 'We have before us Ibrahim bin Yazid Al-Taymi and Ibrahim bin Yazid Al-Nakha'i, so which of them shall we take?' He said: So he wrote: 'Take them both.' Hushaym said: As for Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i, he was not found until he died, and as for Ibrahim Al-Taymi, he was taken and died in prison." This narration, on its surface, is not related to defects and knowledge of men, but if we look closely, we find that it was cited for important Hadith benefits, among them clarifying the Agreed and Separated (*Al-Muttafiq wa Al-Muftariq*) of names, and how they can be distinguished. When Ibrahim bin Yazid was mentioned absolutely, it became ambiguous and the intended one was not designated. When each one was attributed with his specific lineage, the distinction occurred. And among them is clarifying the contemporaneity between them and their being in one city, for example. He may mention a narration to clarify a defect or infirmity in the narrator, for example, he said in text (128 a) from Yazid bin Harun from Abdul-Malik bin Abi Sulaiman, who said: "A man used to invite me and Sa'id bin Jubayr for the whole month of Ramadan. He said: So they mentioned the night of Nabidh (date wine). Sa'id said: I do not see any harm in it in the water-skin (*Siqa'*), but I dislike it in the green jar (*Al-Jarr Al-Akhdar*). He said:

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: So I said: Then by Allah, we will not obey you; we will surely drink it in the green jar (*Al-Jyy Al-Akhda* - lisping pronunciation). He said: Sa'id said to me: 'Al-Jyy Al-Akhda' - mimicking his language, meaning Abdul-Malik. Yazid said: And Abdul-Malik had a lisp (*Althag*)." The intent is that the book *Al-'Ilal*, despite its specialization in the subject of defects and knowledge of men, includes most types of Hadith sciences, and we will make a special index for it with the numbers of the texts, Allah willing.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
**My Work in Investigating and Referencing This Book:**
1 - The first work I undertook was copying the book from its unique copy.
2 - I compared the copied version with the original with a precise comparison according to my capacity.
3 - I numbered the texts with a serial numbering.
4 - Then I began investigating and verifying the correctness of the texts. Since I did not find another copy for the book, the need increased to review its texts in the books of the art which quoted these texts from the Imam. I was successful with most of them in the books available to us, and I established their locations by designating the volume and page in the footnote. There is no doubt that comparing several copies of a book, if they exist, and collating them with the original corrects the text or brings it closer to correctness. However, the need remains to reference the texts in their likely sources if the investigator seeks precision and honesty in investigation and correction. When copies are missing, the importance of returning to the likely places and sources that benefited from the book increases, and in this work, there is fatigue, hardship, and spending of time of which Allah is Aware. So I reviewed the texts as much as possible, and if I found a difference among those quoting from him, I drew attention to it.
5 - I wrote brief biographies for the men of the chain of narration, mentioning the oldest references for them and mentioning *Al-Tahdhib* if the biography was found in it.
6 - I extracted (*Kharrajtu*) the hadiths and judged them as Authentic (*Sahih*), Good (*Hasan*), and Weak (*Da'if*).

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
And if they were among the defective hadiths, I mentioned the sayings of the scholars regarding them in explaining their defects.
7 - If Ahmad authenticated or weakened a narrator, I searched for him and about him. If Ahmad opposed him [consensus/others], I indicated it, or if I found a report about the narrator from Ahmad contradicting it, I established it in the footnote.
8 - If the Imam said about a narrator "I do not know," I searched for him in various books; perhaps someone knew him and recognized him. If someone agreed with him, I indicated it, and if I found someone who spoke about him contrarily, I established it.
9 - If he was asked about the name or Kunya of a narrator and said: "I do not know," I searched for it; if I found him named or given a Kunya by others, I established it.
10 - If he named him with a name or gave him a Kunya, I searched whether anyone named him or gave him a Kunya other than this name and Kunya. If others agreed with him, I said: "And thus Al-Bukhari named him and gave him a Kunya in *Al-Tarikh Al-Kabir*, and *Al-Jarh*, and Muslim gave him a Kunya, and Al-Dawlabi gave him a Kunya..." for example. And if anyone opposed him, I established it. I did the same regarding if he attributed him to a tribe or a city or mentioned him with an infirmity, and so on. So I searched, and if I found someone agreeing with him, I mentioned it, and if he was opposed, I established that as well.
12 - If the author said: "He has two hadiths from so-and-so, for example... he heard one of them and did not hear the other," then I search for the two hadiths, and if I succeed in finding the objective, I mention it.
13 - If the author indicated a hadith of the narrator and did not mention its text, I searched for the hadith and mentioned it if I found it.
14 - There is erasure of some words in the copy in not a few places, especially at the edges of the papers and their beginnings and ends. So during the search for these

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
texts, if I came across it, I established what was between the parentheses () and indicated that there is erasure in the original and the established text is from book such-and-such.
15 - I explained the strange Hadith, strange words, places, tribes, and the like.
16 - I created several indexes, because the book is not arranged, so it cannot be benefited from except by the following various indexes:
a - Index of Verses.
b - Index of Hadiths and Reports (*Athar*) by the first letters.
c - Index of Hadiths and Reports by Fiqh arrangement.
d - Indeed, speech about a single narrator may be found scattered in different, distant texts, and it cannot be benefited from except by collecting these texts in one place. I intended to arrange these texts in their original form. Then I shifted away from that to indicating their meanings to avoid lengthening the indexes. For example, there is a text in the birth of Hushaym, then after many texts another text on his death, then after several texts a text on his Tadlis, then a text or texts mentioning his hadiths... So I collected these texts by their meanings in one place, indicating the numbers of the texts.
e - Index of Narrators detailed by designating the numbers of the texts in which their names appeared or mention of them appeared by any way, attributed, nicknamed, or given a Kunya.
f - Index of strange words and strange Hadith.
g - Index of places and countries.
h - Index of tribes and sects.
i - Index of references.
It does not escape me to mention that half of the book, or close to it, is printed, and the professors

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
Dr. Talat Koç Yiğit and Dr. Ismail Cerrahoglu undertook its verification, and it was printed in Ankara in the year 1963. May Allah reward them with good. It was possible for my work to be on the part that was not investigated and not printed, as some brothers indicated, but regarding my new plan in the work, I saw fit to work on it from the beginning of the book. Then, by a quick comparison of the printed version with the original, some errors appeared to me, most of which go back to reading the words. It was possible to arrive at the correct reading after scrutiny in some of them, and after reviewing the texts in their likely sources in others. There is no doubt that the errors, relative to the effort the two noble investigators exerted, are not considered many. They deserve all thanks and appreciation for bringing out the book. I had recorded some of these observations at the first start of work on the book; I establish them here.
* It appeared on p. (5) Text (10): "When Al-Mukhtar bin Anas sent Umar bin Sa'd". And the correct reading is: "When Al-Mukhtar sent with the head of Umar bin Sa'd..." and behind it is a story.
* And it appeared on p. (5) also, Text (13): "Uthman told us, saying: Hammad told us..." And the correct reading is: "Affan (with 'Fa') told us..."
* And it appeared on p. (6), Text (15): "So which of them shall he take? He said: So he wrote to take them both..." And the correct reading is: "So which of them shall we take? So he wrote: That take them both." And it is clear in the original.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
* And it appeared on p. (6) Text (16): "He was sad, *Rahim* Allah..." And the correct reading is: "*Rahimahu* Allah" (May Allah have mercy on him).
* And it appeared on p. (7) Text (21): "*Ahfazu*" (*)... and he said in the comment: In the original *Al-Hifz* is a mistake." The correct reading is that the word in the original is not *Al-Hifz*, rather it is "*Atahaffazu*" (I memorize/preserve), and it is clear in the original.
* And it appeared on p. (22) Text (104): "...and Ibn Shihab regarding the *Sheikha*." And the correct reading is: "...regarding the *Mashyakha*" (Sheikhs), with the Mim before the Shin.
* - And it appeared on p. (24) Text (114): "*Lais* told us..." And the correct reading is: "...*Laith* told us" with the three-dotted Tha, and perhaps it is a typographical error.
* And it appeared on p. (26) Text (128): "And indeed Allah *Yastakhlifukum*..." And the correct reading is: "...*Mustakhlifukum*."
* And it appeared on p. (30) Text (154): "...so we said to him, nay..." And the correct reading is: "So I said no, nay..."
* And it appeared on p. (30) also, Text (155): "...I have never *Ista'abtu* (with Ba after Ain) a hadith ever." And the correct reading is: "...*Ista'adtu*" from *Isti'adah* (seeking repetition/review).
* And it appeared on p. (49) Text (289): "...we used to *Nuwaqqi'uha*..." And the correct reading is: "We used to *Narfa'uha*" (raise it), with Ra after Nun.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)

* And it appeared on p. (138) Text (849): "...so he had a story... he said: *qassa bihi*..." And the correct reading is: "...he said: *fadarbahu* (so he hit him)..."
* And it appeared on p. (115) Text (692): "I saw the Mushafs in their hands and the swords * while they were running," and the investigator commented that in the place of the asterisk was the word "their hands" and it is a mistake so he deleted it. The correct reading is to establish: "in their hands" once again...
* And it appeared on p. (146) Text (887): "...he has goodness in his body (*badan*)..." And the correct reading is: "...goodness in his religion (*din*)."
* And it appeared on p. (146) Text (907): "...she was - or what my father said - (between two dashes)" and apparently the meaning of the word was not clear to the investigator so he put it between two dashes. The correct reading is: "*La narza'uka*" (We do not diminish you/take from you).
* And it appeared on p. (177) Text (1105): "...meaning *bi'uss* so I guessed it (?) or nine..." The word would appear with a little scrutiny; the correct reading in the place of the question mark is: "eight pounds or nine..." *ya'ni bi'uss* so I guessed it eight pounds or nine.
* And it appeared on p. (188) Text (1161): "Abdullah bin Hakim..." And the correct reading is: "Abdullah bin Ukaym," with the un-dotted Ain.

Al-Rijal'... The correct reading is: '...about Al-Ra'y Al-Rijal'. * And on page (199), Text (1232) 'Lakan ala 'unuqi (?)'. And in the original, it is clearly 'shat ta'kul al-dhibban' (a sheep eating flies) (a strange distortion?). * And on page (281), Text (1819) 'Hina ja'ahu - meaning Al-Nu'man Ibn Muqarrin -' thus between two dashes. book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text:
Part One of the Book of Defects and Knowledge of Men [by] Abu Abdullah Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Hanbal, may Allah have mercy on him. Narration of Abu Ali Muhammad bin Ahmad bin Al-Hasan Al-Sawwaf, from Abu Abd Al-Rahman Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Hanbal, from his father Abu Abdullah. Hearing of Ubaydullah bin Ahmad.

Part One of the Book of Defects and Knowledge of Men

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 1 - Abu Abd Al-Rahman Abdullah bin Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Hanbal bin Hilal bin Asad told us, he said: My father, may Allah have mercy on him, told me, he said: Hushaym bin Bashir told us, he said: Al-Awwam informed us, from Ibrahim Al-Taymi who said: When it was the Day of Dhi Qar, Bakr bin Wa'il exacted revenge from the Persians. That reached the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, so he said: 'They exacted revenge from them.' Bakr bin Wa'il from the Persians and their likes. He said: 'This is the first day in which Allah scattered the soldiers of Persia by means of knights from Dhuhl bin Shayban.' 2 - Hushaym said: And a Sheikh from Qays called Hafs bin Mujahid, who was knowledgeable about people's news, informed me, he said: It reached me that the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, said: 'Through me they were aided.' He said: And that was at the time of the mission (Mab'ath) of the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 3 - My father told me, he said: Hushaym told us, he said: Abu Bishr informed us, from Sa'id bin Jubayr that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, killed three men from Quraysh on the Day of Badr in captivity (Sabran): Al-Mut'im bin Adi, Al-Nadr bin Al-Harith, and Uqbah bin Abi Mu'ayt. 4 - My father told me, he said: Hushaym told us, he said: Mujalid informed us, from Al-Sha'bi who said: The slain on the Day of Badr were sixty-nine and the captives were seventy-one. He said: So he ordered regarding Uqbah, and he was killed in captivity.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 5 - My father told me, he said: Sulayman Abu Dawud told us, from Shu'bah, from Mu'awiyah—meaning Ibn Qurrah—who said: My father used to narrate to us from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, but I do not know if he heard from him or narrated about him. 6 - I heard my father say: Abdul Hamid, the companion of Al-Ziyadi, is Ibn Kardid.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 7 - My father told me, he said: Yazid bin Muslim Al-Hamdani told us, he said: I am one hundred and thirty-five years old. He said: And Muhammad bin Yusuf arrived while I was five years old in the year seventy-three, while others said in the year seventy-two. 8 - My father told me, he said: Yazid bin Muslim told us—and it was said to him: Did you see Hammam bin Munabbih? He said: Yes, and I gifted him a black ram (meaning coal-black). He said: The head of Wahb—meaning Ibn Munabbih—was white. 9 - My father told me, he said: Yazid bin Muslim told us, he said: I asked Wahb—meaning Ibn Munabbih—How should I pray? He said: According to your busyness. He said: Then how [much] remembrance (Dhikr)? He said: According to your desire [for Allah]. I said: Indeed my desire is great. He said: There is no limit to remembrance; remember Me standing, sitting, on your sides, and in the sleeping places. 10 - My father told me, he said: Abd Al-Razzaq told us, he said: Ma'mar informed us, he said: Uthman Al-Jazari informed me, from Miqsam. Ma'mar said: He used to be called 'Uthman Al-Mushahid'. I wrote two scriptures (Sahifahs) from him regarding Maghazi (Expeditions). A man borrowed them from me and went away with them, and I had not lent a book before them.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 11 - My father told me, he said: Abd Al-Razzaq told us, he said: Sa'id bin Qumadhin informed us, from Uthman bin Abi Sulayman who said: When Al-Mukhtar sent the head of Umar bin Sa'd bin Abi Waqqas to Medina, it was thrown before Ali bin Al-Hussein, and he fell down prostrate.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 12 - I heard my father say: These are the children of Abdullah bin Mas'ud: Abu Ubaydah, Abd Al-Rahman bin Abdullah, and Utbah bin Abdullah. Yahya bin Ma'in narrated from some of them, saying: Abdullah bin Mas'ud died when Abd Al-Rahman bin Abdullah was six years old or thereabouts. 13 - My father said: And Al-Mas'udi is Abd Al-Rahman bin Abdullah bin Utbah bin Abdullah bin Mas'ud. And Abu Al-Amis is his brother, Utbah bin Abdullah bin Utbah bin Abdullah bin Mas'ud. And Al-Qasim bin Abd Al-Rahman bin Abdullah bin Mas'ud is his brother [meaning brother of Ma'n], [son of] Abd Al-Rahman bin Abdullah bin Mas'ud. And Al-Qasim bin Ma'n bin Abd Al-Rahman bin Abdullah bin Mas'ud.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 14 - My father told me, he said: Affan told us, he said: Hammad bin Salamah told us, from Thabit, from Ibn Abi Layla that Usayd bin Hudayr is Abu Atik.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 15 - I heard my father say: Raja' bin Haywah is Abu Al-Miqdam. And Nawf Al-Bakali is Abu Yazid. And Abd Al-Khaliq bin Salamah is Abu Ruh. And Isa bin Dinar is Abu Ali. And Al-Mustazill bin Husayn is Abu Al-Maytha'. And Al-Qasim bin Muhammad is Abu Abd Al-Rahman.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 16 - My father told me, he said: Hushaym told us, he said: One of them claimed to me, he said: Al-Hajjaj wrote that Ibrahim bin Yazid be taken to his governor. When the letter came to him, he said: He wrote to him: 'We have before us Ibrahim bin Yazid Al-Taymi and Ibrahim bin Yazid Al-Nakha'i, so which of them shall we take?' He said: So he wrote to take them both. Hushaym said: As for Ibrahim Al-Nakha'i, he was not found until he died. As for Ibrahim Al-Taymi, he was taken and died in prison. 17 - My father told me, he said: Hushaym told us, he said: Al-Awwam claimed, he said: When Ibrahim Al-Taymi was brought to us, he said: When he ended up at the prison door, he said: It was said to him: Do you have any need to convey to the Amir? He said: Mention me to a Lord who is better than the lord of Yusuf's companion. 18 - My father told me, he said: Hushaym told us, he said: Some of our companions claimed, he said: When he was put into prison, he said—and he was sorrowful, may Allah have mercy on him—he said: He used to command them to have patience and say: Indeed relief is near, until they used to say: If the door were opened for us, we would not leave it.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 19 - My father told me, he said: Hushaym told us, from Abu Bishr, he said: Sa'id bin Jubayr said: Al-Hajjaj will surely kill me. He said: I said: How do you know that? He said: A dream I saw. 20 - My father told me, he said: Hushaym told us, from Abu Bishr, from Abu Nadrah, from Abu Sa'id, he said: Discuss Hadith, for indeed Hadith stirs up one another. 21 - My father told me, he said: Hushaym told us, he said: Shu'bah used to narrate this Hadith to us from Sahm Al-Fara'idi from Aws bin Thabit. He said: When I arrived in Basra, I was informed that he was alive, so I came to him. So Aws bin Thabit narrated it to me from Hakim bin Aqqal that a woman died and left two cousins (sons of her paternal uncle), and he narrated the Hadith.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 22 - My father told me, he said: Hushaym told us, he said: Hajjaj and Ibn Abi Layla informed us, from Ata' who said: We used to be with Jabir bin Abdullah, and he would narrate to us. When we left his presence, we would discuss his Hadith. He said: Abu Al-Zubayr was the best memorizer of Hadith among us.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 23 - Abdullah told us, he said: Harun bin Ma'ruf told us, he said: Sufyan told us, from Abu Al-Zubayr who said: Ata' used to put me forward for them when with Jabir, to memorize the Hadith for them. 24 - My father told me, he said: Hushaym told us, some of our companions said, from Al-Zuhri that the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, used to tie the banners on Thursday. 25 - My father told me, he said: Hushaym told us, he said: Yunus bin Ubayd informed us, from Ammar, the client of Banu Hashim, who said: I witnessed the death of Umm Kulthum bint Ali and Zayd bin Umar. He said: Sa'id bin Al-As prayed over them both, and he put Umm Kulthum in front of Zayd bin Umar.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text: 26 - My father told me, saying: Hushaym told us, saying: Husayn informed us, saying: 'Utbah, meaning Ibn Farqad, had witnessed Khaybar. He said: A share was allotted to him, and he received arrows (shares) from it. He said: So he assigned it to his paternal cousins for a year and to his maternal uncles for a year. He said: Banu Sulaym used to come one year and take it. He said: And Banu Fulan used to come one year and take it. He said: So it was like that. Hushaym said: There was kinship between Husayn and him, meaning 'Utbah bin Farqad.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
27 - My father told me, saying: Hushaym told us, saying: Mughirah informed us from Abu Wa'il, who said: The collector [of charity] of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, came to us, and I was a boy at that time. He used to take one she-camel from every forty camels. He said: So I brought him a ram of mine and said: 'Take this as charity.' He said: 'There is no charity [due/accepted] in this.'
28 - My father told me, saying: Waki' told us, saying: Isra'il told us from Jabir from 'Amir, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, married fourteen women.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
29 - My father told me, saying: Waki' told us, saying: Zakariya told us from 'Amir regarding His saying, Mighty and Majestic: {You, [O Muhammad], may put aside whom you will of them or take to yourself whom you will}. He said: They were women who gifted themselves to the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. He consummated marriage with some of them and deferred others; he did not marry them [consummate]. Among them was Umm Sharik Al-Dawsiyyah.
30 - My father told me, saying: Waki' told us from Sharik from Jabir from Al-Hakam from Ali bin Husayn that the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, married Umm Sharik Al-Dawsiyyah.
31 - I heard my father say: Al-Hasan Al-Urani did not hear anything from Ibn Abbas.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
32 - I heard my father say: Khaythamah did not hear anything from Abdullah bin Mas'ud; he narrated from Al-Aswad from Abdullah.
33 - My father told me, saying: Waki' told us from Sufyan from Jabir from 'Amir from Masruq, who said: Umar said to me: 'What is your name?' I said: 'Masruq bin Al-Ajda'.' He said: 'Al-Ajda' (the mutilated) is a devil. You are Masruq bin Abdur-Rahman.'
34 - My father told me, saying: Waki' told us from Sufyan, saying: 'Amr bin Murrah told us, he heard it from Abu Al-Hasan, his father said—meaning Hilal bin Yasaf—from the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, that in Friday there is surely an hour...

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
35 - My father told me, saying: Waki' told us from Sufyan from Abu Qais, who said: I saw Ibrahim as a one-eyed boy with a shaved head. Sufyan said: I think he said: He was holding the stirrup for 'Alqamah on the day of Friday.
36 - My father told me, saying: Waki' told us, saying: Mis'ar told us from Al-Hakam, who said: Abu 'Isa said: 'Do not argue with your friend nor joke with him.' My father said: Meaning Abdur-Rahman bin Abi Layla is Abu 'Isa.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
37 - I heard my father say: Hushaym died in the year [one hundred and] eighty-three. I went out to Kufa in those days. When we arrived in Kufa, we went to Waki'. Waki' said to us: 'What did Hushaym have regarding a man strangling another man?' I remained silent, or I said: 'He did not have anything regarding it,' or 'He did not memorize anything regarding it,' or something like this.
38 - My father told me, saying: Waki' told us from Sufyan from Abu Hashim from Ibrahim, who said: If he imprisons him until he kills him, he is killed for it.
39 - My father told me, saying: Waki' told us, saying: Isra'il informed us from Jabir from 'Amir, who said: If he strangles him and does not let go of him until he kills him, he is killed for it. And if he lifts [his hold] from him and then he dies, it is a heavy blood money (*Diyah Mughallazah*).
40 - My father told me, saying: Waki' told us, saying: Sufyan told us from Ya'la bin 'Ata, who said: A Bedouin asked Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib about *Al-Tila' Al-Munassaf* (wine reduced to half by boiling). He disliked it and said: 'Stick to milk.'

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
41 - I heard my father say: Waki' once said: 'I heard Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib.' So I said to Waki': 'Heard Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib?' He said: 'A Bedouin asked Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib,' and he did not say 'I heard.'
42 - My father told me, saying: Waki' told us, saying: Al-Awza'i told us from Musa bin Sulayman from Al-Qasim bin Mukhaimirah, who said: The likeness of the one who steps over the necks of people... My father said: In our copy, it was Sulayman bin Musa, so Waki' said: Musa bin Sulayman.
43 - I heard my father say: Mahdi bin Maymun is trustworthy, trustworthy (*Thiqa Thiqa*).
44 - I heard my father say: Waki' told us, saying: 'Isa bin Hafs bin 'Asim, the uncle of Ubaydullah bin Umar, told us. My father said: Waki' did not hear anything from Ubaydullah bin Umar. When he narrated from 'Isa bin Hafs, the uncle of Ubaydullah bin Umar, he would say: 'Isa bin Hafs, the uncle of Ubaydullah bin Umar, told us.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
45 - Abu Abdur-Rahman said: Waki' did not catch him. He narrated from Abdullah. Waki' was younger than Abu Usamah and Ibn Numayr in age. Between him and Abu Nu'aym was a year; he is older than Abu Nu'aym by a year. Waki' was born in the year twenty-nine, and Abu Nu'aym in the year thirty.
46 - My father told me, saying: Waki' told us, saying: 'Amr bin Hassan Al-Musli told us from Wabrah Abu Khuzaimah bin Abdur-Rahman.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
47 - My father told me, saying: Waki' told us, saying: Dawud bin Sawwar told me from 'Amr bin Shu'ayb from his father from his grandfather, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, said: 'Order your boys to pray when they reach seven.' My father said: They opposed Waki' regarding the name of this Sheikh, meaning Dawud bin Sawwar. My father said: Al-Tafawi said Muhammad bin Abdur-Rahman, and Al-Barsani said Sawwar Abu Hamzah.
48 - My father told me, saying: Ibn 'Uyaynah told us from Yahya bin Sa'id, if Allah wills, he said: I heard Sa'id bin Al-Musayyib say: I was born when two years had passed of the Caliphate of Umar.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
49 - My father told me, saying: Ibn 'Uyaynah told us, saying: Yahya said: I narrated the hadith of 'Amrah to Al-Qasim, so he said: 'By Allah, she brought you the hadith exactly as it is,' meaning regarding the Hajj of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace.
50 - My father told me, saying: Ibn 'Uyaynah told us from Yahya, who said: Umar bin Abdul-Aziz, while he was governor, wrote to Abu Bakr bin Muhammad: 'Write to me the hadith that is established with you from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, and the hadith of 'Amrah.'
51 - My father told me, saying: Sufyan told us, saying: Wa'il did not sit with Al-Zuhri, but he sat with his son, Al-Zuhri. My father said: Wa'il is trustworthy (*Thiqa*); he heard from Ibrahim, and he narrates from his son from Al-Zuhri. My father said: Wa'il is trustworthy, trustworthy.
52 - My father told me, saying: Sufyan told us, saying: Abu Husayn had a white head and beard.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
53 - My father told me, saying: Sufyan told us, saying: Yunus bin Abi Ishaq said: A man died among us in Al-Qila'. A man stood up and said: 'Do you know who this is? This is Muhassir (or Mujassir?); no, by Allah, no one could bear his prayer,' meaning Ibn Ma'qil.
54 - My father told me, saying: Sufyan told us, saying: Sulayman bin Abi Al-Mughirah Abu Abdullah is trustworthy, good (*Khiyar*). Abu Abdur-Rahman said: This is Sulayman bin Abi Al-Mughirah Al-Absi, a Kufan; Shu'bah narrated from him.
55 - My father told me, saying: Sufyan said: He was among the best of those we saw, meaning Ibrahim bin Muhammad bin Al-Muntashir.
56 - I heard my father say: Shu'bah said: Abu Maryam said to Abu Husayn: 'Did Yahya bin Wathab narrate to you that Masruq narrated to him that Abdullah narrated to him?' He said: And he was bold against him. He said: So Abu Husayn said: 'Yes.' Shu'bah said: 'If I had spoken to him or repeated it to Abu Husayn, he would have slapped my eye.'
57 - I heard my father say: Thabit Al-A'raj is Thabit bin Iyad, the Mawla (freed slave) of Abdur-Rahman bin Zaid.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
58 - My father said: I have not seen anyone who retained knowledge more than him, nor memorized more, meaning Waki' bin Al-Jarrah. My father said: I never saw Waki' doubt a hadith except one day. He said: 'Where is Ibn Abi Shaybah?' as if he wanted to ask him or verify with him. My father said: And I never saw a book or a note with Waki' ever.
59 - I heard my father say: Ali bin Abi Talhah is Kufan. Hasan bin Salih and Sufyan narrated from him. Hajjaj Al-A'war said: 'I saw him,' meaning this Ali.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
60 - My father told me, saying: Sufyan told us the hadith of 'Asim from Zirr from Safwan bin 'Assal. Sufyan said: 'Does anyone remain who narrates it?' A man said: 'Abu Bakr bin Ayyash.' So Sufyan narrated the hadith, and when he reached: 'He used to order us when we were on a journey (*safar*) or travelers (*musafirin*),' he doubted in this place. Sufyan said: 'I see myself taking what I said [first],' and Sufyan narrated the hadith.
61 - I heard my father say: Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Qattan used to choose Mulazim bin 'Amr over 'Ikrimah bin 'Ammar; he would say: He is more established (*Athbat*) in hadith than him.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
62 - My father told me, saying: Sulayman bin Harb told us from Hammad bin Zaid from Yunus bin Ubayd, who said: I saw Abu Ubaydah bin Abdullah on his saddle as if his face was a Dinar (gold coin).
63 - My father told me, saying: Isma'il bin Ulayyah told us from Khalid from a man who said: Abu Qilabah saw me with Abdul-Karim Abu Umayyah and said: 'What is the matter with you and this insignificant one (*Al-Han*), this insignificant one?'
64 - My father told me, saying: Ibn Ulayyah told us from Mansur bin Abdur-Rahman Al-Ghudani, who said: I spoke to Al-Sha'bi regarding an issue in which Al-Hakam bin 'Utaybah had said such-and-such. So Al-Sha'bi said: 'Is there no limit to this Ibn 'Utaybah? Is there no limit to this Ibn 'Utaybah?' And Ibn Ulayyah raised his voice and extended it.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
65 - My father told me, saying: Isma'il told us from Ayyub, who said: A man would narrate a hadith to Muhammad bin Sirin, so he would say: 'Indeed, by Allah, I do not accuse you, nor do I accuse that one—meaning the man who is from the Companions of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace—but I accuse the one who is between you two.'
66 - My father told me, saying: Yahya bin Abi Bukayr told us, saying: Hammad bin Salamah told us from Humayd that he took the books of Al-Hasan, copied them, and then returned them to him.
67 - My father told me, saying: Yahya bin Abi Bukayr told us, saying: Hammad bin Salamah told us from Ali bin Zaid, who said: There were three of his companions who, if they heard the hadith, would raise it [to the Prophet] (*Raf'uhu*): Al-Hasan, Abu Al-Aliyah, and he mentioned another man.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
68 - My father told me, saying: Yahya bin Abi Bukayr told us, saying: I heard Shu'bah say: Sufyan never narrated a hadith to me from a person and I asked him [the person] about it, except that it was [exactly] as he had narrated it to me.
69 - My father told me, saying: Abu Bakr bin Ayyash told us from Abdul-Malik bin Umayr, who said: I saw a *Burnus* (hooded cloak) on Abu Musa Al-Ash'ari.
70 - My father told me, saying: Waki' told us, and he mentioned Ali bin 'Asim, so he said: 'Take from his hadith what is authentic, and leave what he erred or made a mistake in.' Abu Abdur-Rahman said: My father used to argue with this and would say: 'He used to err and make mistakes, and there was obstinacy (*Lajaj*) in him, but he was not accused of lying.'
71 - My father told me, saying: Mu'ammal told us, saying: Abu Mawdud is Bahr bin Musa.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
72 - My father told me, saying: Humayd Al-Ru'asi told us, saying: Zuhayr told us from Abu Ishaq from Al-Tamimi, who said: I never heard of a land in which there was knowledge except that I came to it. My father told me, saying: Abu Ahmad Al-Zubayri told us from Isra'il, who said: The name of Al-Tamimi whom Abu Ishaq narrated from is Arbadah.
73 - My father told me, saying: Abdur-Rahman bin Mahdi told us from Mu'awiyah bin Salih from Al-Ala' bin Al-Harith from Makhul from Wathilah bin Al-Asqa', who said: If we narrate the hadith to you according to its meaning, then that suffices you.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
74 - My father told me, saying: Abdur-Rahman told us from Mu'awiyah from Rabi'ah bin Yazid, who said: When Abu Darda narrated a hadith and finished it, he would say: 'O Allah, unless [it is] like this or similar.'
75 - My father told me, saying: Abdur-Rahman told us from Mu'awiyah from Al-Ala' bin Al-Harith from Makhul, who said: I and Abu Al-Azhar entered upon Wathilah. We said to him: 'O Abu Al-Asqa', narrate to us a hadith you heard from the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace.' He said: 'We only heard the hadith once or twice. If we narrate the hadith to you according to its meaning, then that suffices you.'
76 - My father said: And I saw Abu Bakr bin Ayyash in Kufa on the day of Friday. He came to the mosque riding on a donkey. He said: So he dismounted then came to one of the pillars of the mosque and started prayer. He remained standing praying. He said: Then he uncovered the sleeve of his shirt, and I looked at his forearm; nothing remained on it except skin on bone. I marveled at his patience in standing and his weakness.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
77 - My father told me, saying: Zaid bin Al-Hubab told us, saying: Mu'awiyah bin Salih told me, saying: Abu Al-Zahiriyyah told me from Namran Abu Al-Hasan. My father said: Zaid narrated it to us from his book as 'Namran' and from his memory as 'Nimar'. My father told me, saying: Zaid bin Al-Hubab told us, saying: Mu'awiyah bin Salih informed me from Abu Al-Zahiriyyah Hudayr bin Kurayb.
78 - My father told me, saying: Ahmad bin Abdul-Malik told us, saying: Zuhayr told us, saying: Abdul-Malik bin Umayr told us, saying: I saw Abu Musa wearing a *Muqatta'ah* (cut garment) and a *Mutraf* (bordered garment).

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
79 - My father told me, saying: Waki' told us, saying: Umm Ghurab told me from Bananah, who said: Uthman never dyed [his hair/beard].
80 - My father told me, saying: Abdur-Razzaq told us, saying: My father informed me, saying: I saw Wahb bin Munabbih and Mughirah bin Hakim not changing the grey hair [with dye].
81 - My father told me, saying: Abdur-Razzaq told us, saying: My father informed me, saying: It was said to Wahb: 'Who was more knowledgeable, Abdullah bin Salam or Ka'b Al-Ahbar?' He said: 'I have seen one who gathered the knowledge of Abdullah and the knowledge of Ka'b to the knowledge of other than them both; is he more knowledgeable or are they?' As if he means himself.
82 - My father told me, saying: Abdur-Razzaq told us, saying: I heard Ma'mar say: The Caliphate was in Medina, then in Sham (Syria), then in Iraq.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 83 - I heard my father say: Sa'id bin Ubayd Al-Ta'i is Abu Al-Hudhayl. Ali bin Rabi'ah is Abu Al-Mughirah. Amir bin Abdah is Abu Iyas Al-Bajali. Khalid Al-Hadhdha' bin Mihran is Abu Manazil. Ismah is Abu Hakimah [Al-Basri?], and Qurrah narrated from him. And I think Al-Taymi, Mubarak bin Fadalah Abu Fadalah narrated from him. Ash'ath bin Abd Al-Malik is Abu Hani. Maymun bin Mihran is Abu Ayyub. Mujahid bin Jabr, and it is said bin Jubayr, is Abu Al-Hajjaj. Ash'ath bin Sawwar is called Ash'ath Al-Najjar (the Carpenter), and he is also called Al-Afraq.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 84 - My father told me, he said: Hashim bin Al-Qasim told us, he said: Al-Mas'udi told us, he said: Abu Yahya Umayr bin Sa'id told me. 85 - My father said: Habib bin Abi Thabit is Abu Yahya. Abu Al-Hayyaj Al-Asadi is Hayyan bin Husayn, and Mansur bin Hayyan is his son; Ibn Uyaynah, Al-Thawri, and Yazid bin Harun narrated from him. Zirr bin Hubaysh is Abu Maryam. Abdullah bin Awn bin Artaban is Abu Awn. My father said: Sakan bin Abi Karimah, I do not see any harm in him; my father said: Waki' told us from him. My father said: Abd Al-A'la bin Hilal Abu Al-Nadr told me.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 86 - I heard my father say: Ibn Mahdi had abandoned the Hadith of Abu Al-Yaqzan Uthman bin Umayr. My father said: He went out in the tribulation of Ibrahim bin Abdullah bin Hasan, and the defeat was in the year one hundred and forty-five. My father said: Whoever heard from Sa'id bin Abi Arubah before the defeat, then his hearing is good, and whoever heard after the defeat, my father considered them weak. I said to him: Was it because Sa'id became confused (mixed up)? He said: Yes. Then he said: Whoever heard from him in Kufa, like Muhammad bin Bishr and Abdah, it is good. Then he said: Sa'id came to Kufa twice before the defeat. 87 - My father said: Ibn Uyaynah said: Two righteous men through whom rain is sought: Ibn Ajlan and Yazid bin Yazid bin Jabir.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 88 - My father told me, he said: Ibn Uyaynah told us, from Ayyub, from Ikrimah, from Abu Hurayrah, he said: I narrate to you things from the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, so it has become that a man should not drink from the mouth of the waterskin. 89 - My father told me, he said: Ibn Uyaynah told us, he said: Ayyub said: When we first sat with him—meaning Ikrimah—he began saying: 'Your understanding is good,' regarding something like this. Al-Hudhali said to me: Al-Hasan refrained from interpreting the Quran when he arrived, meaning Ikrimah. 90 - My father told me, he said: Sufyan told us, he said: I heard Ayyub say: I came to—meaning Tawus—and I saw him between two, as Allah willed, meaning Abd Al-Karim and Layth.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 91 - My father told me [sic] Sufyan told us, from Ayyub, he said: He asked Al-Hasan, and it became difficult for him. He said: 'If you were an Arab, you would have known it.' 92 - My father told me, he said: Sufyan told us, he said: Ayyub said to me: This is from the good Hadith, the Hadith of Muhammad bin Sirin which he heard from Alqamah: 'We were with Abdullah, and a man came to him on a horse and said: I divorced my wife the number of the stars.' So Sufyan mentioned the Hadith. 93 - My father told me, he said: Ibn Uyaynah told us, he said: Ayyub said: Indeed, the death of a man from my brothers reaches me, and it is as if a limb from my limbs drops off. 94 - My father told me, he said: Sufyan told us, from Duhayr, he said: When death was mentioned, every limb of Ibn Sirin would die individually. It was said to Sufyan: Did you sit with Muhammad? He said: No.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 95 - My father told me, he said: Ibn Uyaynah told us, from Ayyub, from Ibn Sirin, he heard it from Abu Al-Ajfa: I heard Umar... So Sufyan mentioned the Hadith. Sufyan said: They say 'Aliqa al-qirbah' (he hung the waterskin), meaning: I tasked myself to come to you until I hung the waterskin due to the distance. 96 - My father told me, he said: I heard Ibn Uyaynah, and he mentioned Ayyub, he said: He did not use to treat me as others treated me, and I used to think that what prevented him was that my father was a wealthy man, so he disliked being informal with me. I was in that state and it distressed me, so I abandoned Hajj for a year and did not perform Hajj. When the next year came, I performed Hajj, and what things he did for me and what things he said to me! 97 - My father told me, he said: Ibn Uyaynah told me, he said: Ayyub said to me: 'I say: I will write for you and ask him for you, for if I were alone, he would not answer me,' meaning Amr bin Dinar. Sufyan said: So I wrote Hadiths for him from Yahya bin Sa'id—and he intended to go to Medina and was impressed by Yahya. Sufyan said: Then I was informed that he said: 'The paper fell (was lost).' 98 - My father told me, he said: I heard Ibn Uyaynah, from Ayyub—either from Muhammad or from Hafsah—that Umm Atiyyah, when she narrated from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, she would say: 'Bi-aba' (My father be ransomed for him), mentioning the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 99 - My father told me, he said: Ibn Uyaynah told us, he said: We did not see an Iraqi who resembled Ayyub in his knowledge. And he used to say to me: 'Were it not for me, would you be performing Tawaf?' I would say: 'No.' So he would say: 'Go.' Sufyan said: He used to arrive 'Mujammam' (rested or with abundant hair) and would not perform Umrah except from Qarn, meaning Ayyub. 100 - My father told me, he said: Sufyan said: 'Hal 'asa al-ghuwayra bu'sa' (Perhaps the little raid brings misery); I heard Al-Zuhri saying it as a proverb coined by the people of Medina. 101 - I heard my father say: I heard Sufyan say, and he narrated the Hadith

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: of Ibn Abi Khuzamah in the year eighty-seven, the year Fudayl—meaning Ibn Iyad—died. He said: From Ibn Abi Khuzamah from his father. My father said: And Yahya bin Abi Bukayr and Husayn bin Muhammad told us, from Sufyan, from Al-Zuhri, from Abu Khuzamah, from his father. My father said: The Hadith is only narrated from Abu Khuzamah from his father; Yunus and Al-Zubaydi—meaning Muhammad bin Al-Walid—narrated it, and it is the more correct of the two.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 102 - Abdullah told us, he said: Abu Musa Al-Ansari Ishaq bin Musa told us, he said: Al-Walid bin Muslim told us, he said: I heard Al-Awza'i preferring Muhammad bin Al-Walid Al-Zubaydi over everyone who heard from Al-Zuhri. 103 - My father told me, he said: Sufyan told us, he said: Things used to be presented (read) to Al-Zuhri. 104 - My father told me, he said: It was said to Sufyan: Indeed Malik says it is from Humayd—there is no doubt in it—from Abu Salamah. My father said: I heard from Sufyan four times the Hadith of Abu Hurayrah from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: 'Whoever fasts Ramadan.' Sufyan said once: 'Whoever stands (in prayer during) Ramadan.'

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 105 - My father told me, he said: I heard Sufyan say: Al-Hudhali said to me: Memorize this Hadith for me, and it is with Al-Zuhri, the Hadith of Abu Idris Al-Khawlani from Ubadah bin Al-Samit: 'We were with the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him, so he said: Pledge allegiance to me that you will not associate anything with Allah.' Al-Hudhali Abu Bakr said to me: We have not seen the likes of this one, meaning Al-Zuhri. 106 - My father told me, he said: Abd Al-Rahman bin Mahdi told us, he said: Hammad bin Zayd told us, from Burd, from Makhul, he said: I do not know anyone more knowledgeable about the past Sunnah than Ibn Shihab.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 107 - My father told me, he said: Abd Al-Rahman bin Mahdi told us, from Wuhib, he said: I heard Ayyub say: I have not seen anyone more knowledgeable than Al-Zuhri. Sakhr bin Juwayriyah said to him: Nor Al-Hasan? He said: I have not seen anyone more knowledgeable than Al-Zuhri. 108 - My father told me, he said: Abu Al-Qasim bin Abi Al-Zinad told us, he said: Abd Al-Rahman bin Abi Al-Zinad informed me, he said: My father informed me, he said: I and Ibn Shihab used to go around to the Sheikhs, and Ibn Shihab had with him boards and pages, and we used to laugh at him.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 109 - My father told me, he said: Abd Al-Razzaq told us, he said: I heard Ibn Al-Mubarak say: I have not seen anyone with more narrations from Al-Zuhri than Ma'mar, except for what was from Yunus, for Yunus wrote everything. 110 - My father told me [sic], I heard Uthman bin Umar say: I heard Yunus say: There is no one with more narrations from Al-Zuhri than Uqayl bin Khalid. 111 - My father said: It reached me from Yahya bin Sa'id, he said: I said to Salih bin Abi Al-Akhdar regarding the Hadiths of Al-Zuhri. He said: Some I heard, some were presented (read to him), and some I found in my books. 112 - I heard my father, and he mentioned Ibn Al-Himmani, so he said: He had written and sought [knowledge]; if only he had limited himself to what he heard.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 113 - My father told me, he said: Hasan bin Musa told us, he said: Zuhayr told us, he said: Abu Ishaq told us, from Qays, and he was the master of the Kharifis. 114 - My father told me, he said: Abd Al-Razzaq told us, he said: Ma'mar told us, from Qatadah, he said: I never said to a man: 'Repeat to me.' And Qatadah used to say: If a Hadith is repeated in a gathering, its light departs. 115 - My father told me, he said: Hasan told us, he said: Zuhayr told us, he said: Abu Ishaq told us, from Shurayh bin Al-Nu'man. Abu Ishaq said: And he was a truthful man.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 116 - My father told me, he said: Abd Al-Razzaq told us, he said: Ma'mar told us, from Qatadah, he said: Blessings never increased upon a people but that their enemies increased. 117 - My father told me, he said: Abd Al-Razzaq told us, he said: I used to narrate it, then I did not find it with me, so I doubted it—the saying, meaning of Tawus: 'The obligatory shares (inheritance law) are a third of knowledge.' 118 - I heard my father say: I entered Basra at the beginning of Rajab in the year one hundred and eighty-six. Mu'tamir died in the year eighty-seven, at its beginning. I entered the second time in the year ninety, and I entered the third time in the year ninety-four, and I left in the year ninety-five. I stayed with Yahya bin Sa'id for six months. And I entered in the year two hundred, and I did not enter it after that. I arrived in Basra in the year ninety-four, and Ghundar had died; it reached me that Ghundar died in the year ninety-three. And Al-Thaqafi Abd Al-Wahhab and Ibn Abi Adi [died] in the year ninety-four.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 119 - My father told me, he said: Al-Muttalib bin Ziyad told us, he said: Layth—meaning Ibn Abi Sulaym—told us, he said: I used to go early to Ata', and I would find Abdullah bin Al-Hasan had preceded me to him. 120 - My father told me, he said: Husayn bin Muhammad told us, he said: Jarir bin Hazim told us, from Ayyub, he said: I said to him: You used to dislike that Hadiths be written from you, yet I see them today presenting books to you and you correct them for them? He said: I am upon my original opinion, but since they wrote from me, for them to present them to me and I correct them for them is more beloved to me than leaving them in their hands [with errors]. Meaning he says: They should not write error from me. 121 - I asked my father about Abu Uthman whom Mutarrif narrated from: What is his name? He said: Amr bin Salim. My father told me, he said: Abu Tumaylah told us, he said: My father informed me, he said: I saw Abu Uthman Amr bin Salim judging at his door. My father said: And he is the one whom Mutarrif narrated from.

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 122 - My father told me, he said: Yahya Abu Zakariya Al-Saylahini told us, he said: Hazm bin Mihran informed me, and he is Hazm bin Abi Hazm Al-Quta'i. 123 - My father told me, he said: Mu'awiyah bin Hisham told us, he said: Sufyan told us, from Aslam, he said: A Bedouin came to us asking about something, so we sent him to Sa'id bin Jubayr. He began saying: 'Where is Abu Muhammad?' twice. Sa'id said: 'We have no standing here with Ata' [present].'

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 124 - My father told me, he said: Isma'il told us, from Ayyub, he said: I asked Sa'id bin Jubayr about a Hadith after he stood up. He said: 'Not every time do I milk and drink.' 125 - My father told me, he said: Ibn Uyaynah told us, he said: I heard Abd Al-Malik bin Umayr saying: By Allah, I narrate a Hadith and I do not leave out a single letter of it. 126 - My father told me, he said: Ibn Uyaynah told us, he said: Al-A'mash said: An elephant that you carry dead is not heavier than some sitting companions. 127 - My father told me, he said: Ibn Uyaynah told us, from Al-A'mash, he said: Whenever we increase in knowledge, we increase in [awareness of] ignorance. 128 - My father told me, he said: Ibn Uyaynah told us, he said: Al-A'mash said: Al-Hasan continued to contain wisdom until he spoke it. 129 - My father told us, he said: Ibn Uyaynah told us, he said: I came to Al-A'mash, so he said: A man came to me and said: I sat with Al-Zuhri and mentioned you to him, so he said: Do you have anything of his Hadith? 130 - My father told me, he said: Ibn Uyaynah told us, he said: It was said to Al-A'mash: O Abu Muhammad, what was the age of Al-Ma'rur? He said: You have started casting seeds [asking trivial/detailed questions].

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 131 - My father told me, he said: Ibn Uyaynah told us, he said: Al-A'mash said: We struggled with Ibrahim to make him sit by a pillar (to teach), but he refused. 132 - My father told me, he said: Yahya bin Sa'id Al-Qattan told us, from Sufyan bin Uyaynah, from Al-A'mash, he said: We struggled with Ibrahim, but he refused the like of it. 133 - My father told me, he said: Ibn Uyaynah told us, he said: Al-A'mash used to ask me about the Hadith of Iyad, the Hadith of Ibn Ajlan, meaning the Hadith of Abu Sa'id from the Prophet, peace and blessings of Allah be upon him: 'Indeed the world is sweet and green, and indeed Allah makes you successors in it,' and he mentioned the Hadith. 134 - My father told me, he said: Sufyan told us, from Yazid—meaning Ibn Abi Ziyad—he said: I heard Ibn Abi Layla saying to Abdullah bin Shaddad: May Allah have mercy on you and reward you with good, for how many Hadiths have you revived from my chest (memory).

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 135 - My father told me, he said: Ibn Uyaynah told us, he said: I heard Mansur narrating from Shabib, he said: They said he was alive, so I went to him and asked him. He said: Hibban bin Al-Harith informed me: I came to Ali while he was encamped at Dayr Abi Musa, and I found him eating Suhur... and he mentioned the Hadith. 136 - My father told me, he said: Ibn Uyaynah told us, from Abu Al-Za'ra, he heard it from his uncle Abu Al-Ahwos, he heard Abdullah say: 'Abusing a Muslim is Fusuq (disobedience/evil-doing) and fighting him is Kufr (disbelief).' And from his uncle Abu Al-Ahwos, he heard Ibn Mas'ud saying: 'Glory be to Allah, the number of the pebbles.' And he heard Abu Al-Ahwos, his uncle, say: I heard Ibn Mas'ud: 'The wretched one is he who was wretched in his mother's womb, and the happy one is he who takes admonition from others.'

book_title: The Defects and Knowledge of Men (Narrators)
text: 137 - Abdullah told us, he said: My father said: Ubaydah told us, from Abu Al-Za'ra, from Abu Al-Ahwos, he heard Ibn Mas'ud. From what Sufyan told us, he said: I heard Ibn Mas'ud. Abdullah said: My father dictated these Hadiths to me, and that is because I said to him: A man from the People of Hadith claimed that Abu Al-Ahwos does not say in his Hadiths 'I heard Ibn Mas'ud.' He said: Yes [he does], then he dictated these Hadiths to me. The name of Abu Al-Za'ra is Amr bin Amr, and Al-Thawri says Amr bin Amir. 138 - My father told me, he said: I heard Waki' say: Abu Miskin's name is Al-Hurr; I see him as Ibn Miskin. 139 - My father told me, he said: Abd Al-Hamid bin Rafi' is a trustworthy Sheikh, Al-Thawri narrated from him.

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
140 - I heard my father say: Amr bin Abi Sufyan is the brother of Hanzalah bin Abi Sufyan; Al-Thawri narrated from him.
141 - My father told me, saying: Ibn Mahdi told us from Sufyan from his father from Musa bin Abdullah bin Yazid, who said: My father would not entrust his hadith to his family (i.e., didn't let them hear it). He used to seclude himself and his companions in a room and they would converse.
142 - My father said: It reached me that Sufyan said to Hammad bin Salamah: "O Abu Salamah, did you write from Salamah bin Kuhayl? He was a smart Sheikh."
143 - My father told me, saying: Yunus bin Muhammad told us, saying: Hammad bin Zaid told us from Amr bin Malik, who said: I heard Abu Al-Jawza say: "I lived as a neighbor to Ibn Abbas for twelve years, and there is not a verse in the Quran except that I asked him about it."

book_title: Al-'Ilal wa Ma'rifat al-Rijal (The Defects and Knowledge of Men)
text:
